college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

This course surveys the portfolio choice literature with a focus on the (econometric) methodology. We use both classical as well as Bayesian techniques to model future asset returns and to come up with optimal portfolios.
The content of the course can be split in 2 parts. The first part deals with short-term asset allocation (how to divide money over many individual securities). We start with efficient set mathematics and mean-variance analysis. Then we proceed by assessing the performance of the allocations out-of-sample. Finally, we analyze more sophisticated (econometric) techniques to improve performance.
The second part deals with long-term strategic asset allocation (i.e. how to divide money over different asset classes and how to change the allocations over time). We first analyze the standard methodology to understand the difference between short-term and long-term investors. Next, we critically assess the plausibility and performance of the outcomes. Finally, we consider more plausible specifications that incorporate realistic aspects such as parameter uncertainty and model instability.

Leerdoelen
  • You learn about the newest academic insights regarding the calculation, interpretation and implementation of optimal portfolios.
  • You learn about (solutions to) the implementation issues that one encounters when implementing optimal portfolios in practice.
  • You learn about new econometric techniques (such as shrinkage estimators) for modeling asset returns that are especially important for portfolio choice.
  • You learn how to calculate (analytically and numerically), interpret and implement optimal portfolios for short-term and long-term investors.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Additional research papers are included and discussed to keep the course material up to date with relevant academic works.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. A Giudici', 'dr. C Harter', 'dr. L Meherishi', 'dr. LM van der Lugt', 'E Mohammadi Hosein Hajlou, MSc', 'prof.dr. AW Veenstra', 'prof.dr. H Geerlings', 'prof.dr. RA Zuidwijk', 'prof.dr.ir. R Dekker', 'R van den Berg, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
The seaport of Rotterdam is the main gateway to the European market, although it is much more than a node in which cargo is transferred between ship and shore. The quality and competitiveness of the port is determined by its position in networks, both at a local level, and at a global level. These networks are transport links with the other major ports in the world – Singapore, Shanghai, Dubai, New York/New Jersey, and the major ports in Europe Antwerp, Hamburg, Bremen, Le Havre, and multimodal transport links with the main destinations in the European hinterland. In addition, the port is also a network of industrial activity that facilitates a large number of supply chains with transport, storage, production and other activities. Finally, the port is embedded in a network of information exchange that enables safe and secure port operations, the efficient management of transportation in and around the port, and the smooth flow of goods through the port. 

This course aims to provide a sound understanding of the role of the port in global networks, and let students gain experience with the development of new and innovative solutions for current problems that exist in this complex context. The elective will provide a variety of perspectives on the port from a number of disciplines, such as port management, legal aspects, public administration aspects, and business economic aspects. The assessment consists of an individual assignment, four team assignments, and participation. 

Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
Upon completion of this course students are able to: 
  • Reflect upon the development of innovative container transport systems;
  • Distinguish various container handling operations and terminal designs; 
  • Analyse the role of port authorities and port strategies; 
  • Reflect on green port policies and corporate social responsibility in port context; 
  • Reflect on secure trade and the role of customs in global trade.

course_title: Positive Organizational Psychology - Engaged Employees and Employee Empowerment in Flourishing Organizations
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud

It is currently widely recognized that for organizations to flourish, be successful and have competitive advantage on the market, employees play a crucial role. In a fast changing and competitive environment, organizations’ performance largely depends on the dedicated, engaged and proactive behaviors of their employees at work. Organizations can no longer ignore the bottom-up processes of employees creating their own jobs, innovating daily work processes, or even creating entirely new organizational units. Modern organizations need to stimulate such positive organizational behaviors through invigorating job design and leadership. Building on a positive organizational perspective, this minor will unravel how organisations can build an engaged and proactive workforce. Examples of topics that will be covered are employees’ psychological capital, work engagement, positive emotions, employee and team performance, proactive work behaviour (job crafting and corporate entrepreneurship), positive human resource management, leadership, strengths use, coaching, and mindfulness.

This minor provides students who are interested in work and organizational psychology a unique opportunity to learn about the latest insights from the fields of positive organizational psychology, positive organizational behaviour and organizational health psychology, applied to relevant issues in performance management, personnel selection, and human resource management. The minor has unique added value to the knowledge gained in economics and business administration.

The minor will be open for international students. For this reason, all the material and activities will be in English. The language used in all tutorial groups will in principle be English. The exam will be in English only, however, it will be possible to answer open ended questions on the exam in Dutch.

Students from all educational backgrounds are admissible for this minor. Students who do not have a background in problem-based learning (PBL) will need to know the didactical model of PBL will be used in this course. Before the course, a short introduction will be provided in PBL for these students.
 

Overview minor modules:

1. Engaged Employees in Flourishing Organizations
2. Employee Empowerment

The first Module of this Minor focusses on optimizing human potential in the workplace through designing positive, healthy and invigorating work environments. Students will learn about the role of personal resources and emotions in predicting job performance. Next, students will learn about activating jobs that create opportunities for personal growth, stimulate work engagement and employee proactive work behavior (such as job crafting and employee intrapreneurship). Students will also learn how positive organizational psychology can be used to prevent employee burnout. This part will conclude with implications for Positive Human Resource Practices.

The second Module focuses on employee empowerment. Employees who feel self-efficacious and able to use their strengths are more likely to feel enthusiastic about their work, with optimal performance as a consequence. The role of the leader is taken into account as well. A constructive leader can offer social support and is able to coach followers towards goal attainment. Transformational leaders inspire their followers, and stimulate followers intellectually. Additionally, leaders can help their followers to identify their strengths, and apply these strengths in their work. Recently, scholars brought the mindfulness concept to the work floor. Mindfulness contributes to recovery from work during off job hours, but can also help cope with job stress.

Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures.
Teaching materials:  Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.
Contact hours: 5 hours per week

Method of examination:
Both modules will be concluded with a final exam consisting of True / False and open-end Questions. The grades of both modules count equally in the final grade. The exam is in English, but Dutch students are allowed to answer in Dutch to the open ended questions.
In order for students to pass the course, both parts of the exam need to be graded with 5.0 or higher, and the average of both grades needs to be 5.5 or higher. That means students can to some extent compensate insufficient grades for one part of the minor.

Students will be offered the possibility to review their answers for each part of the exam shortly after the grades have been announced.

Leerdoelen Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:
  1. Personal resources (psychological capital, positive emotions) and their role in organizational settings, such as their relationship with team performance.
  2. The relationships between job design, work engagement and employee health and well-being.
  3. Predictors and outcomes of employees’ proactive work behaviour (e.g., job crafting, idiosyncratic deals (I-deals), and employee corporate entrepreneurial behaviour).
  4. Positive human resource practices. What HR practices contribute to both high performance and sustainable employability?
  5. Leadership. How can leaders inspire and empower their followers, and how can leaders contribute to follower well-being and performance?
  6. Strengths use. How can employees identify their strengths, and how can they apply their strengths in their daily work?
  7. Coaching. How can we make a team out of a group of individuals? And how can we coach employees to empower themselves and optimize their job performance?
  8. Mindfulness. How can mindfulness help to cope with job stress and psychological detachment from work during off-job hours?

course_title: Positive behavior change in the digital age
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['B Simoski', 'dr. CR Smit', 'dr. D van de Bongardt', 'dr. DJ Blok', 'dr. E Rozendaal', 'dr. I Merkelbach', 'dr. RO Lutkenhaus', 'dr. TJ van Woudenberg', 'HY Chuck, MSc', 'JA Schlicht', 'prof.dr. MA Buijzen', 'prof.dr. S Denktas']
text:
Inhoud

In this minor students dive into the world of behavioral change in the digital age. Students become familiar with the unprecedented possibilities digital media offer for supporting positive behavior change. Also, they learn how behavioral and communication strategies can be used to promote happy, healthy and sustainable lifestyles. Topics covered include but are not limited to eHealth, online peer interaction, social influence, social network campaigns, artificial intelligence (e.g., targeting and tailoring, data analytics), influencer marketing, and gamification.

In small, interdisciplinary teams, students are challenged to identify a pressing behavioral issue in the field of physical/mental health or sustainability in an urban environment (the city of Rotterdam) and come up with an effective solution (e.g., digital communication campaign or intervention) taking into account the unique characteristics of the target population and societal context. Examples of issues are:
- How do you encourage healthy behaviors (e.g., food choices or sexual behaviors) among Rotterdam teenagers?
- How do you promote fair food or fashion consumption among Rotterdam students?
Solutions are designed in co-creation with relevant stakeholders (i.e., citizen-science approach) and assessed by a jury consisting of both academics and societal organizations.

While working on the solution is a team effort, students will be working on their personal-professional development as well. All students are individually asked to determine personal learning goals and think about how they want to achieve those goals by developing activities within the course. Students receive guidance and coaching from a broad team of EUR academics specialized in digital media, communication and behavior change. Moreover, several behavior and communication professionals will host activities.


Overview content per week

Week 1:                Identifying behavioral issues in the domain of health and sustainability in an urban environment
Week 2-3:             Introduction in behavior change and persuasive/ strategic communication theory
Week 4:                Citizen science: cocreating solutions to behavioral issues with stakeholders
Week 5:                Mini conference: Communication and behavior change toolbox
                             The purpose of this mini conference is to inspire students how to use different behavioral and communication strategies in combination with digital technologies to come up with an effective solution for their chosen behavioral issue. Topics covered include but are not limited to eHealth,                                       online peer interaction, social influence, social network campaigns, artificial intelligence (e.g., targeting and tailoring, data analytics), influencer marketing, and gamification.
Week 6-9:             Designing an effective solution to a complex behavioral issue
                             In teams, students work on the design of an evidence-based solution to a behavioral issue of their choosing. Part of this process is setting up and conducting a co-creation session with stakeholders
Week 10:              Closing event and presentation of solutions to a jury of academics and professionals

A more detailed schedule will be provided over summer.

Method of examination

There is no written final exam. The following components together result in a grade:

  • Weekly in-class assignments (depending on the assignment, this will be graded on the team or individual level)
  • Presentation of the solution, e.g., intervention/ communication campaign (graded on the team level, but includes an individual component as well)
  • Short report in which the solution to the behavioral issue is scientifically substantiated (graded on the team level, but includes an individual component as well)
  • Individual reflection on personal-professional development (no grading; sufficient/insufficient)

Feedback by the lecturers and peer feedback will be provided in class and through Canvas.


The minor will be open for international students. For this reason, all the material and activities will be in English. The language used in class will be English. The assignments should be made in English (reflections on personal-professional development may be made in Dutch).

Because this minor is interdisciplinairy in nature, we encourage students from all educational backgrounds to participate.

Leerdoelen After completing this minor, you will be able to:
  1. Define, explain and critically discuss complex behavioral issues in the domain of health and sustainability by applying relevant theoretical and empirical insights from (health) psychology and behavioral science.
  2. Systematically design a solution to tackle a complex behavioral issue in the domain of health or sustainability by applying relevant theoretical and empirical insights from (health) psychology, behavioral science, communication science, and data science.
  3. Showcase the solution (e.g., intervention/ communication campaign) in a professional and persuasive presentation to convince fellow students, teachers and societal stakeholders of your ideas.
  4. Independently set up personal-professional learning goals and substantiate how you want to achieve those goals by developing activities within the course.

course_title: Post-Colonial Theory: Critical Perspectives from the Global South
college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud
This course will engage with theoretical discussions in postcolonial studies. Through texts by some of the major theorists of the field, such as Edward Said, Homi Bhabha and Gayatri Charkavorty Spivak, we will critically examine the cultural logic of colonialism, neo-colonialism and imperialism as well as their present-day remnants. In addition, we will explore processes of decolonisation, not only of lands, but also of cultures, identities and minds. The Other, hybridity, orientalism and the subaltern are among the concepts that we will take up and mobilise to these ends. In the most general sense, this course will provide a framework to critically assess notions of Western modernity, civilisation and historiography.
Leerdoelen After this course, students will be able to:
- Conceptually define colonialism, neo-colonialism, imperialism and postcolonialism.
- Understand and describe some of the major ideas in postcolonialism, like Edward Said's Orientalism.
- Understand and describe some of the major theoretical debates within postcolonialsm.
- Understand and describe some of the concepts that are linked to decolonisation of culture, land and the mind.
- Understand and describe the present-day relevancy of the vantages that postcolonialism offers.

course_title: Poverty and Inequality: Concepts, Measures and Policies within Contemporary Development Agendas
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. I Gusc', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. S Bertrand', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'prof.dr. RD Futselaar']
text:
Inhoud The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, then students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:
 
Term 2: eight plenary meetings
-  discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
-  design of a research proposal
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
 
Term 3: three plenary meetings
-  carrying out research
-  critical discussion of the research proposals
-  discussion of and information on possible research methods




-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
 
Term  4: three plenary meetings
-  wrapping up research
-  discussion of case studies and other work in progress
-  one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
-  presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June 2021
-  participation in discussions following presentations
 
The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4.

Theme: Power, Politics, and Sovereignty
The present world order, as based on the 1941 Atlantic Charter, finds its expression in US hegemony and is organized under the aegis of the system of the United Nations. The balance of power that sustains this world order is changing; while the Western hegemony seems on the decline, the center of economic and hegemonic gravity is steadily moving towards Asia. This change implies a reevaluation and a critical and historical analysis of the world order. Also, if we consider that the world order typically creates a hierarchy in (inter)national relations, we can assume that this brings forth resistance when moving towards oppression.

This seminar addresses this resistance against the hierarchy of the world order by examining the historical origins of sovereignty. We will analyze sovereignty in three ways or tiers, namely internationally through ‘international law,’ nationally through the nation-state, and socially by examining citizenship. This seminar will help the students to reckon with the complex history of power relations by examining these three different tiers of sovereignty and the way they are interlinked in both national and international affairs.
 
In terms of period, the seminar will predominantly focus on the long twentieth century, with exception of the analysis of the different sovereignties dating back to the seventeenth century. Concerning themes, it will thoroughly and rigorously examine various political, economic, and social issues related to power and sovereignty, i.e. self-determination and political independence. The seminar will address themes such as hegemony, world order, imperialism, colonialism, diplomacy, emancipation, the legacy of slavery, Pan-Africanism, and racial discrimination. The seminar will address some of the main theories that underpin a holistic framework that students can use to further analyze the historic origins and contemporary manifestations of power relations.    

These main theories will be presented utilizing a theoretical and historical debate on the origins of economic and political hegemony so students can critically engage with the material and further analyze phenomena such as the rise of Asia, the decline of US hegemony, and the decolonization of the African continent. In exploring the historiographical debate on sovereignty and power relations, students will be invited to critically engage with relevant primary sources. In this way, the seminar will provide insight into historic and contemporary (inter)national power relations, hegemony and sovereignty, and the way in which they underpin the world order and its current transformation.  

Further information at the Thesis Market in October

Note: The maximum number of participants is 8.

  Leerdoelen
  • Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
  • Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
  • Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
  • Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
  • Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
During the Academic Writing Skills II practical, students will work both from home and during the practical sessions on a scientific literature report, in which the emphasis will be on critical processing of the literature based on a scientific research question.
Students will attend a number of practical sessions, while also working on their article about a psychology topic of their choice. During the writing process, students will be supported through feedback from fellow students as well as from their practical trainer. Central topics during Year 2 are: formulating a central question; the systematic search for literature and describing the strategy used in searching; organising literature, in which literature will be discussed critically and links are made between the various sources; writing in a scientific style; writing to the American Psychological Association (APA)'s style requirements. During the mandatory library practical, students will learn to use advanced search techniques to find scientific information on a specific research question.
 
Retaking the practical
1. Students who participated in this practical in a previous academic year have to choose a new topic from this year’s list of topics. The topic subscription is additional to the formal registration and is mandatory for all students. Topic subscription takes place during course 6 and will be announced on the Canvas page of P2.7. When a student retakes this practical and has already met the attendance requirement, then a student may choose to register for uploading only the final report. This means that the student does not attend any meetings, does not hand in any homework assignments and also does not receive any intermediate  feedback. When, on the other hand, a student wants to receive intermediate feedback, then he or she must register for the practical sessions and also comply with all associated requirements concerning presence and homework.

2. Students who retake this practical within the same academic year may improve their original practical report.

Leerdoelen Being able to write a scientifically argued review article is central to the Academic Writing Skills II practical. This practical is part of the academic writing trajectory, which is comprised of the following: year 1: Writing Skills I, year 2: Writing Skills II, year 3: Bachelor thesis, year 4: Master thesis. Within this trajectory, students first learn about basic writing skills (such as structuring paragraphs and creating links between paragraphs), after which they learn more advanced skills (such as sound argumentation based on scientific sources, as well as creating links between various sources).
A second important skill used in academic writing is the giving and processing of feedback. Finally, a series of library practicals is featured in which students learn how they can systematically get an overview of scientific literature within a specific field of research.
  Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

course_title: Practical Applied Multivariate Data Analysis using SPSS
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Assignments
Seven assignments have to be written for this course. You work in a small group that you form during the first tutorial meeting. You will get a (group) grade for the final report of all seven assignments, which you have to upload on Psyweb.
 
Computer Sessions
You will be working with the software package SPSS version 23. For all techniques, you will perform the necessary assumption tests and the main analyses. Conceptual questions will guide you towards a correct interpretation of the output. Four computer sessions are scheduled. All of them will cover one or two themes.
Your practical knowledge of SPSS will be tested with the SPSS exam.
The practical comprises two sections, explained below:

1. Each week there is an SPSS session where students learn to apply the analysis techniques to research data. Interpreting the research results using SPSS output is also covered extensively. An SPSS exam is held after the four sessions. This exam is done on the computer and is intended to test mastery of the SPSS skills.

2. On the basis of seven practical assignments, each student works with one or two fellow students: an existing research article must be replicated with their ‘own’ data, which will be provided by the tutor, and a research report must be written about it that complies with the APA norms. During the obligatory tutorial meetings these assignments will be presented and discussed. Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud

In this practical, we will work on a workbook that comprises multiple figures, illustrations and schematic representations of the brain and its structures. We will name the structures and focus on their location within the brain. By working on the different parts of this workbook, you will create a brain atlas that illustrates the most important brain structures. These involve brain structures seen from the outside (workbook part 1), brain structures inside the brain (workbook part 2), and multiple sections through the brain in coronal, horizontal and sagittal direction (workbook part 3). We will use digital atlases and have a look at material of brain dissections which is most instructive in getting a 3-dimensional overview of the brain.

Leerdoelen
At the end of this practical you will have profound knowledge of the anatomy of the human brain. Also, by making the assignments in this workbook, you will have made your own atlas, which might be very useful during the later courses in the Master B&C.
You will be able to identify and describe:
  • the four cerebral lobes and the main gyri and sulci of the lobes
  • the structures on the midsagital plane
  • the white matter tracts in the brain
  • the structures that belong to the ventricular system
  • the structures that belong to the limbic system
  • the structures that belong to the basal ganglia
  • the structures of the diencephalon ( de tussenhersenen )
  • the structures of the brain stem and the cerebellum
  • the layers that protect the brain from the outside
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. LP Dekker', 'dr. RER Van der Hallen']
text:
Inhoud During this practical we will focus on CBT’s rationale, learn how to distinguish between thoughts, emotions and behaviour, how to conduct a CBT case assessment, including how to conduct a CBT assessment interview, and how to compile a CBT case formulation, including the maintenance cycle, a chain analysis and the ABC technique. In addition to that, students will learn how to recognise different types of cognitive distortions, how to understand these distortions in light of different psychological and psychiatric conditions, and how to challenge a client’s disrupting thoughts in a helpful and constructive manner.
Students will use pen-and-paper exercises as well as role play in order to learn and practice these assessment techniques and become familiar with CBT case assessment.
  Leerdoelen The aims for this practical are to learn all about Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), its rationale as well as how to read, understand and analyse a case or client in terms of the underlying (dysfunctional) cognitive and behavioural patterns.

lecturers: ['dr. LP Dekker', 'dr. RER Van der Hallen']

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In dit practicum leren de studenten dat het anamnestisch interview een belangrijk instrument is om een DSM diagnose te stellen. Ze leren hierbij om symptomen van psychopathologie te herkennen en om op basis daarvan een adequate DSM diagnose te stellen. Tevens leren ze om differentiaal-diagnostisch te denken. Tenslotte oefenen de studenten in rollenspelen met het zelf uitvoeren van (delen van) een anamnestisch interview. Hierbij is het interview opgesplitst in de klachtenanamnese, de psychiatrische anamnese, de biografische anamnese en de sociale anamnese.
 
Het practicum is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP). Leerdoelen
Het doel van het practicum ‘Anamnestisch Interview’ is
  • het leren voeren van een anamnesegesprek,
  • het op basis van deze gespreks- en observatiegegevens kunnen stellen van een DSM-(5-)diagnose,
  • het op basis van deze diagnose kunnen voorstellen van een voorlopig behandelplan
  • het kunnen rapporteren van deze gegevens in een diagnostisch (anamnestisch) rapport.

 
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
De basishouding en de basisgespreksvaardigheden, die men nodig heeft voor het voeren van een professioneel gesprek, worden geoefend in 'tweegesprekken', dat wil zeggen: gesprekken waarbij slechts twee personen betrokken zijn. De setting is er vaak één, waarin iemand zich met een persoonlijk probleem of een probleem op het werk tot een hulpverlener wendt. Het gaat dan om een eerste gesprek tussen de hulpverlener en de cliënt. Een dergelijk probleemverhelderingsgesprek leent zich goed voor het oefenen van de basishouding en de basisvaardigheden, die van belang zijn voor mensen die beroepsmatig gesprekken met cliënten moeten voeren.
 
Leerdoelen Het doel van het practicum Gespreksvoering I is het vergroten van kennis van en inzicht en vaardigheid in effectief communiceren. Studenten leren een aantal veelgebruikte basisgespreksvaardigheden toe te passen en verdiepen hun inzicht in de theoretische kennis door het zelf oefenen in gesimuleerde, professionele gesprekken.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Communicatieve vaardigheden zijn niet louter uit een boekje te leren. Daarvoor is ook praktische oefening en feedback nodig. De aanpak waarvoor wij gekozen hebben, is gebaseerd op de cumulatieve microtraining methode (CMT) van Lang en Van der Molen (1992). Deze methode is op haar beurt weer gebaseerd op de sociaal-leertheoretische benadering van Bandura (1977, 1986). In die benadering wordt ervan uitgegaan dat sociaal en cultureel gedrag aangeleerd is en dat eventuele inadequate sociale gedragingen ook afgeleerd kunnen worden. Hieronder bespreken we hoe we deze methode in het practicum zullen gebruiken.

Cumulatieve microtraining (CMT)
De CMT-methode is gebaseerd op de microtraining methode van lvey (1971). Deze Amerikaan ontwikkelde de methode in het kader van de opleiding van hulpverleners.
Kenmerkend voor de methode is de opvatting dat het mogelijk is in gesprekken verschillende soorten vaardigheden (skills) te onderscheiden en dat deze ook systematisch geoefend kunnen worden. De opvatting van lvey was dat men deze vaardigheden het beste afzonderlijk kan aanleren; vandaar de benaming ‘microskills’.

Met deze methode is in Nederland veel ervaring opgedaan (Lang & Van der Molen, 1984; 1991; 1998; Van der Molen, Smit, Hommes & Lang, 1995), onder andere bij de training van aspirant-hulpverleners, psychologen, maatschappelijk werkers, enzovoorts. Daarbij bleek dat de oorspronkelijke benadering van lvey om steeds slechts één vaardigheid tegelijk te oefenen voor cursisten soms niet zo bevredigend was. Zij hadden er juist behoefte aan hun arsenaal aan vaardigheden 'op te bouwen'. In de in Nederland ontwikkelde trainingen werd daarom voor een opbouw gekozen waarbij steeds een nieuwe vaardigheid werd toegevoegd aan de reeds geleerde vaardigheden. Vandaar de benaming 'cumulatieve' microtraining. Hieronder geven we aan welke stappen in de CMT-methode worden onderscheiden en hoe deze in dit practicum zullen worden toegepast.

1. Bestudering van theorie
Voorafgaand aan iedere practicumbijeenkomst bestudeer je het betreffende deel in Bijlage 1 van deze practicumhandleiding. Voor de aard en functie van de verschillende vaardigheden bestudeer je de Hoofdstukken 2, 6 en 7 uit Psychologische Gespreksvoering: Een basis voor hulpverlening van Lang & van der Molen (2008). Voor het gespreksmodel bestudeer je van ditzelfde boek de Hoofdstukken 5 en 8. Ter verdieping van de rollen die je speelt tijdens de bijeenkomsten kun je Hoofdstukken 10 en 16 uit Borra, Van Dijk en Rohlof (2002) bestuderen. Deze hoofdstukken zijn beschikbaar via PsyWeb.

2. Bekijken van videovoorbeelden (modeling)
De nuancerende gespreksvaardigheden en het gespreksmodel worden gedemonstreerd aan de hand van videovoorbeelden. Deze voorbeelden zijn verwerkt in het computerprogramma die je voor alle bijeenkomsten doorloopt (ViP). In dit programma leer je aan de hand van interactieve oefeningen de verschillende gespreksvaardigheden onderscheiden en leer je inzien wat het effect van de toepassing ervan is. Daarnaast bevat het programma een videovoorbeeld van een hulpverleningsgesprek waarin de drie fasen - Probleemverheldering, Probleemnuancering en Probleembehandeling - worden gedemonstreerd. Tot slot is een aantal oefeningen opgenomen dat bedoeld is om de basisvaardigheden, waar je in practicum 1.6 ‘Gespreksvoering’ al kennis mee hebt gemaakt, op te frissen.

3. Rollenspelen
In de bijeenkomsten die je onder begeleiding van een trainer volgt, leer je de afzonderlijke vaardigheden toe te passen in hulpverleningsgesprekken met betrekking tot werkgerelateerde gezondheids- en (re)integratieproblemen en angstklachten. Je oefent het gebruik van de deelvaardigheden in deze situaties aan de hand van een rollenspel.

4. Feedback
In de nabespreking van een rollenspel krijgt degene die als hulpverlener geoefend heeft feedback van een medestudent op de wijze waarop hij de vaardigheden en het gespreksmodel heeft toegepast. Daarbij wordt eerst aandacht besteed aan wat er goed ging, dat wil zeggen het correct gebruik van de vaardigheden in relatie tot het doel van het gesprek. Daarna worden suggesties voor verbetering aangereikt. Feedback wordt gegeven met behulp van het driekolommensysteem zoals geleerd in practicum 1.6 (zie Bijlage 2).

5. Formulering van leerpunten
De nabespreking resulteert in het aanduiden van goede acties van de student (positieve bekrachtiging), maar ook in het noemen van een aantal zwakke acties en in suggesties hoe die verbeterd kunnen worden. Zo ontstaan individuele 'leerpunten' waaraan je in volgende bijeenkomsten speciale aandacht kunt schenken.
Verder wordt het eindgesprek dat je als hulpverlener voert, opgenomen. Het opgenomen gesprek gebruik je om te reflecteren op het gesprek dat je gevoerd hebt. Leerdoelen
Het algemene doel van dit practicum is om je professionele vaardigheid in het voeren van hulpverleningsgesprekken te vergroten. Deze algemene doelstelling kan in de volgende concrete leerdoelen worden uitgewerkt. Na afronding van dit practicum ben je in staat: 
 
  • De gespreksvaardigheden en het gespreksmodel toe te passen in een   
    hulpverleningsgesprek
  • Dergelijke gesprekken te observeren en adequaat feedback te geven op het 
    gedrag van je medestudenten
  • Gespreksdoelen te formuleren en deze systematisch na te streven
  • Verschillende rollen van een psycholoog in de onderscheidende fasen van 
    het hulpverleningsgesprek te herkennen en te benoemen
  • Onderscheid te maken in verschillende fasen van hulpverleningsgesprekken
  • Op je handelen in hulpverleningsgesprekken te reflecteren en je handelen 
    theoretisch te onderbouwen
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Leerdoelen Het practicum is gericht op psychologische observatie- en meetmethoden binnen de context van arbeidsorganisaties.
 
Het practicum is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Enkele feiten en schattingen: werknemers in Nederland besteden 15-20% van hun tijd aan conflicten en conflicthantering. Tienduizenden mensen raakten zelfs arbeidsongeschikt als gevolg van een arbeidsconflict (De Dreu, 2001). Conflicten komen overal voor: op het werk, in familieverband, onder vrienden, op straat, enzovoort. In dit practicum gaan we in op een aantal algemeen geldende basiskenmerken en principes van conflicten en mediation. In Nederland is mediation sinds de jaren negentig van de vorige eeuw in opkomst als methode van conflicthantering. Het is een vorm van conflicthantering waarbij de conflictpartijen zelf, onder begeleiding van een mediator, proberen tot een oplossing te komen. De toepassingsgebieden van mediation zijn talrijk. Zo wordt mediation veel ingezet voor conflicten tussen familieleden (bijv. echtscheidingen), burenruzies, arbeidsconflicten, bij pestgedrag in scholen en voor politieke crisissituaties. Mediation is echter niet altijd en overal een geschikte interventie. Men gaat er bij mediation bijvoorbeeld van uit dat de conflictpartijen bereid en in staat zijn om samen aan de oplossing van het conflict te werken en dat het in stand houden van de relatie tussen de partijen belangrijk is. Als aan dergelijke vooronderstellingen niet wordt voldaan zijn andere interventies meer geschikt.
Dit practicum is een eerste kennismaking met het vakgebied van conflicthantering en mediation. Aansluitend bij het brede toepassingsgebied van mediation komen de voorbeelden en opdrachten in het practicum uit verschillende hoeken. We behandelen een aantal basisprincipes met betrekking tot conflict en al doende ervaar je hoe mediation in zijn werk gaat.

Leerdoelen
Na afloop van dit practicum:
  • heb je kennis van:
    • verschillende manieren om conflicten systematisch te diagnosticeren.
    • de verschillende stijlen van conflicthantering en de specifieke omstandigheden waarin de verschillende stijlen het meest effectief zijn.
    • de grondbeginselen van mediation (definitie, kenmerken, voorwaarden).
    • wat vooraf gaat aan de daadwerkelijke mediation (voorbereidingsfase en openingsfase).
    • de basisprincipes van onderhandelen.
    • het mediationproces en in het bijzonder de vijf subfasen van de mediationfase.
    • de rol van de mediator in elke fase van het mediationproces.
    • aandachtspunten en valkuilen bij elke subfase van de mediationfase.
       
  • en ben je in staat om:
    • conflictstijlen te herkennen en te bepalen welke stijl in welke situatie meer of minder effectief is.
    • zowel de structuur als het proces in conflictsituaties systematisch te analyseren.
    • je eigen manier van omgaan met conflicten te analyseren en aan te passen aan de eisen van de situatie.
    • als mediator door middel van een openingsstatement een goede basis te leggen voor het mediationproces. 
    • een onderhandelingsproces voor te bereiden en te structureren.
    • een mediationproces in gang te zetten
    • als mediator enkele basisinterventies toe te passen.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

course_title: Practical Developing 21st century skills and education
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In this practical 21st century education will be the central topic. This practical is related to course 3.6 E&D ‘21st Century Education’. Next to the more theoretical account covered in the course, the practical will stimulate you to look at educational practice and apply the theoretical knowledge from the course. This will be done in the main assignment of the practical in which you will write a proposal for developing educational materials or tools to support 21st century skills or education. Also, you will be challenged to look at your own knowledge and skills, how you could develop yourself further and reflect on your personal development.
 
 
 
Leerdoelen After this practical, students should be able to …
  • Create a proposal for developing educational materials or tools to support 21st century skills or education.
  • To reflect upon one’s own personal development in relation to learning experiences during the practical.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In het practicum Onderwijspsychologie in de praktijk maak je kennis met verschillende beroepsperspectieven van afgestudeerde onderwijspsychologen. Je gaat in groepsverband een kijkje in de keuken nemen bij een organisatie waar onderwijspsychologen werkzaam (zouden kunnen) zijn en presenteert aan elkaar wat het werk bij die organisatie inhoudt. Tevens oefen je met het schrijven van een projectplan door met je groep een projectplan (plan van aanpak) op te stellen voor een authentieke vraag of opdracht waarmee onderwijspsychologen die werkzaam zijn bij de bezochte organisatie mee te maken krijgen.
Leerdoelen Na dit practicum hebben jullie:
  • Kennis van verschillende beroepsmogelijkheden voor afgestudeerde onderwijspsychologen
  • Geoefend met het schrijven van een projectplan
De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud

You will learn about the following experimental paradigms used to study the biological and/or cognitive processes involved in perception and attention.

  • Ponzo illusion
  • Simon task
  • Attentional blink
  • Visual search
Leerdoelen This course has the following learning goals. At the end of the course, students
  • are familiar with a number of basic paradigms used by scientists to study perception and attention
  • have a basic understanding of the relation between theory and data
  • are able to analyze data from basic experimental designs
  • are able to present experimental research in a coherent fashion in an oral presentation
  • are able to report experimental research in a written report following the basic standards of the field

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication

course_title: Practical Intercultural Sensitivity and Intercultural Competences
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['AS Dias - Broens, MSc', 'R de Lima - van Gent']
text:
Inhoud The aim of the practical ‘Intercultural sensitivity and competence’ is to support students and give students tools to become aware of, develop and strengthen their own intercultural sensitivity and competences in society, and in the daily practices within education. Firstly, students will work on the ability to observe cultural differences. They will make use of intercultural incidents they encountered themselves and they will reflect on these encounters together. In this way, the intercultural environment of the student is used as a starting point in the process of becoming aware of and developing intercultural sensitivity and competences. Next, students are asked to investigate daily practices and challenges professionals in urban education encounter via qualitative research. In particular, students will interview professionals working in the field of education in the urban context of Rotterdam. The interviews will be transcribed, coded and analyzed by the students. Finally, the students are asked to apply the gained knowledge and skills with regard to acting sensitive and competent in intercultural settings in practice via an educational advice and in a role-play situation. The assessment of this practical is based on students’ critical reflection on their intercultural sensitivity and competences throughout this practical.
Leerdoelen Following completion of this course, students are able to do each of the following:
  • Describe cultural differences in society and in daily educational practice;
  • Describe their own cultural frame of reference;
  • Assess the consequences of their actions in an intercultural setting;
  • Investigate, by means of qualitative research, the dilemmas professionals in the urban educational context encounter;
  • Assess and translate intercultural problems from daily educational practice into interventions, programmes and/or policies;
  • Apply professional, ethical and legal codes of conduct in a simulated situation of intercultural conflict.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud De hele stage- en scriptieperiode overziend zijn er drie varianten:
  1. Je doet in deze periode een onderzoeksstage ter waarde van 32 ECTS (896 uur → 22,4 weken op basis van een 40-urige werkweek).
  2. Je doet in deze periode een onderzoeksstage ter waarde van 20 ECTS (560 uur → 14 weken op basis van een 40-urige werkweek), omdat je de overige 12 ECTS (336 uur → 8,4 weken op basis van een 40-urige werkweek) wilt besteden aan een praktijkstage (FSWP4051).
  3. Je combineert de onderzoeksstage met de praktijkstage, in welk geval je onderzoeksstage tenminste 20 ECTS (560 uur → 14 weken op basis van een 40-urige werkweek) waard moet zijn.
 
De studenten K en KK&J kunnen de GZ praktijkstage lopen ter waarde van 19 ECTS (FSWP4054)
 
Studenten B&C doen in beginsel variant 1. Studenten K, KK&J, A&O en HLP hebben de vrijheid zelf een variant te kiezen.
 
De stagehandleiding met informatie over de onderzoeksstage, praktijkstage en scriptie vind je op PsyWeb. Leerdoelen De praktijkstage is bedoeld om ervaring op te doen in het werkveld van de psycholoog, als voorbereiding op het werken in de praktijk. Die stap biedt ook de mogelijkheid om diagnostiekcasussen uit te werken, die nodig zijn voor de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek.

text:
Inhoud
Dit practicum is bedoeld als eerste kennismaking met deze neuropsychologische diagnostiek. De basisprincipes en enkele bekende neuropsychologische tests zullen aan bod komen.
Toetsvorm: Verslag

Het practicum is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).
Leerdoelen
In het practicum zal worden ingegaan op de neuropsychologische diagnostiek. Het betreft hier een klinische vaardigheid: door middel van neuropsychologische diagnostiek kan worden nagegaan wat de gevolgen van een hersenbeschadiging zijn op het gedrag.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. JL Panman', 'dr. RER Van der Hallen']
text:
Inhoud
Het practicum bestaat uit een training van het afnemen en scoren van neuropsychologische tests. Je zult tests oefenen die verschillende functies van het brein meten. Naast het daadwerkelijk afnemen en scoren van de tests zal je ook getraind worden om de test-score te interpreteren en om een neuropsychologisch rapport te schrijven. Dit practicum is een essentieel onderdeel van de voorwaarden voor het verkrijgen van de basisaantekening psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut voor Psychologen (NIP, veldspecifiek deel K&G).

Leerdoelen Na het voltooien van het practicum ‘Neuropsychologische diagnostiek’ heb je:
  • inzicht in diverse diagnostische methoden binnen de neuropsychologie
  • geleerd waar je op moet letten bij het kiezen van neuropsychologische tests
  • ervaring opgedaan met het afnemen van diverse tests
  • geleerd je hoe je testresultaten moet interpreteren
  • geleerd hoe je testresultaten moet rapporteren in een verslag.
Je krijgt gelegenheid om te oefenen met al deze onderdelen. Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.
