college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. LAL de Meijer', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc']
text:
Inhoud The internship is an introduction with the professional practice and an exercise in the skills which are relevant in the profession. The students gain experience in applying knowledge and at the same time acquire new knowledge and skills. During the internship 7 points for attention are central. These 7 points are important during the internship and the reporting of the internship. At each point of attention is formulated a number of objectives. These objectives apply to all forms of internship. The starting point is that all objectives be realized during the internship at the institution. However, due the nature of the different forms of internship certain objectives will be more or less on the foreground. The internship committee determines whether there can be met within the placement to the different objectives (based on the internship request). Leerdoelen
The Master internship is an important component of the Master Family Pedagogy. During the first phase of the Master you have gained pedagogicalal knowledge and skills, now is the time to apply this acquired knowledge and skills into practice. The internship is the opportunity to deepen or broaden your content. This internship can give you a good overview of the labor market, the field and the requirements of employers. You can gain work experience and make valuable contacts, which you can use in your future career.

Knowledge and insight
The student has knowledge and insight of:
• work within the pedagogical and/or educational profession at local level and/or at (inter)national level and the way in which these activities are relate to other institutions that directly or indirectly deal with issues in education and parenting.
• current pedagogical and/or educational issues and the current state of science and/or practice.
• the policy, protocols and/or processes of professionals in the pedagogical and/or educational professions.
• diversity issues within the pedagogical and/or educational practice and/or science.
• ethical and legal frameworks for pedagogical and/or educational act.
• performing and interpreting scientific pedagogical and/or educational research.

Application of Knowledge and insights
The student is able to:
• apply the scientific knowledge (acquired during the study) in the professional practice.
• translate complex pedagogical and/or educational problems to (potential for) suitable interventions, programs and/or policies and to carry a valid basis.
• share professional development with professionals in the field.

Critcal appraisal
The student is able to:
• reflect scientifically on pedagogical and/or educational ethical issues.
• reflect scientifically and ethical on the interaction between the interest of science, policy and practice.
• oversee the research process and the diagnostic cycle.
• make responsible ethical and procedural decisions during the diagnostic and research cycle.
• reflect critical on their own insights and skills and those of others.

Skills
The student is able to:
• apply, under supervision, (diagnostic) instruments, even at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• report, scientifically sound, in written and oral form about plans and research (both focused on treatment/ intervention and research itself) and resulting recommendations, problems and solutions.
• assume an academic / advisory role in a cooperative relationship with professionals.
• select relevant scientific literature.
• set up, execute and evaluate a research or intervention or training programme in the field of education and/or parenting problems, preferably also at individuals and groups with different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds.
• provides a scientific contribution to (developing) policy, practice or research within an pedagogical context.

Communication
The student is able to:
• work in a multidisciplinary group in pedagogical and/or educational practice.
• cooperate and communicate with different target groups (such as children, parents, teachers, policymakers and scientists).
• cooperate and communicate effectively and respectful with individuals with different backgrounds (such as nationality, culture, socio-economic environment and scientific discipline).

Learning skills
The student is able to:
• directing their own learning process.
• ask for feedback on the work carried out, and here to receive to deal adequate with it.
• reflect on their own learning (and development herein) and to determine what are personal goals and interests.

Personal goals
In addition to the objectives set out the course, the student will also formulate personal goals to encourage the professional development.

The domains, independence (ig. Mostly know him/her to do, take action itself), establish contacts (ig. Can cooperate professionally with different target groups), communication (ig. Has good listening and communication skills) and professionalism (ig. respects appointments, is open to and processed on an adequate feedback), are important aspects herein.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. LAL de Meijer', 'RJ Zijderveld, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
The master’s thesis is the final part of the master program. During this final phase, students apply their knowledge and skills in the field of pedagogical and educational research. By formulating relevant academic research questions and carrying out a subsequent research, students contribute to the collective knowledge base of professionals and academics in the field of pedagogy and education.
The master thesis is an academic written product, an academic aptitude test in which students reflect their academic level. The master thesis describes empirical research in form of an academic article and contributes to the knowledge of pedagogical or educational science.
Leerdoelen
After finishing the master's thesis
Students have knowledge of:
  • current insights, key theories, empirical findings, and national and international developments, both within the chosen specialization and at the interface of the three specializations (i.e. ortho pedagogy, family pedagogy and educational sciences);
  • cultural (i.e. ethnic-cultural, ethical and/or legal), economic, social and/or political developments within the chosen specialization, and related issues, problems and findings (including empirical findings);
  • advanced methods and models used in the process of signaling and identifying complex, multi-problem pedagogical situations and providing appropriate guidance and support, both at the level of the individual and at the level of systems and institutions;
  • intervention (or treatment) models of complex, multiple pedagogical problems, including their effectiveness and their application in a diverse context (i.e. diversity in ethnic-culture, social-economic status, legislation, language, gender);
  • advanced designs and methods for social sciences research.
Students are able to:
  • assess and translate complex pedagogical problems into interventions, programs and/or policy, and  analyze and evaluate them;
  • carry out research within the chosen specialization and at the interface with other related sub disciplines of the pedagogical sciences;
  • analyze complex questions, issues and developments in the field of upbringing and education and form a well-reasoned opinion by integrating existing knowledge and their own understanding with the ability to reflect on the limitations of their knowledge and on the influence of their own and other people’s culture-based norms and values;
  • carry out their pedagogic and scientific work with an awareness of ethical and culture-related aspects, in respect of clients as well as test subjects, and to oversee the consequences of their own professional actions;
  • work in a multidisciplinary group in a pedagogical context, and competently take on either a leading role or a team role;
  • communicate complex themes, either orally or in writing, in a clear and comprehensible way, with the ability to differentiate between different target groups (e.g. children, parents, teachers, policymakers, scientists and other professionals) and accounting for diversity;
  • keep up with subject-related developments and developments in society in order to contribute to change processes in pedagogic practice and to innovation in the field of pedagogy; independently engage in a further specialist study program and continue working on their professional development.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. I Fragkos', 'dr. LP Veelenturf', 'dr. M Tekin', 'dr. WN Phillips']
text:
Inhoud

Course overview 

This course focuses on the further development of applied analytical skills. The emphasis is on solving specific business problems in a structured way. It starts with formalizing the problem in terms of decisions to be made, constraints and objective function. Then the required data is collected and analyzed before step wise procedures and optimization techniques are used to find feasible and high-quality solutions to the problem. As a final and very important step, these solutions and their implications for the business problem need to be interpreted and presented. As a result, this course will build upon courses like quantitative decision making (besliskunde) and Supply Chain Management. More importantly this course continues on the previous courses within the Analytical Decision Makers tracks.  

Prescriptive analytics is about making informed decisions to solve business problems using data and mathematical models. Prescriptive analytics also helps to improve current performance of the problems. How can we improve KPI’s like cost and efficiency by using the available data? In this course we will provide the necessary skills to answer this question by using examples from different application domains, like logistics, project management and revenue management.  

The course starts with how to translate a business problem into an optimization problem. Key concepts of optimization problems, such as decision variables, constraints and creating an objective function will be discussed. Then the next step is being able to solve these optimization problems, meaning that a good and feasible solution to the problem must be found. This can be done using algorithms (step-wise procedures) and optimization techniques. In the course we will discuss how to develop and implement these algorithms. These algorithms require data as an input and an important decision is on how to take the uncertainty of the input into account. How are we going to make our decisions under uncertainty? Are we going to minimize the average or worst-case cost? 

The theory for this course will be provided via short online videos. There will be weekly Q&A sessions to discuss questions about these videos. Next to that, tutorial video’s will be made available on how to implement the theory on real problems by using programming languages (R). The course consists of multiple assignments and/or quizzes on which students work individually and on group basis. To provide support on these assignments weekly tutorial workshops are organized in which the students can work on their assignments and ask any questions that may arise.  

Leerdoelen Learning Goals 
  • After following this course, the student is able to: 
  • Translate a business problem into an optimization problem, formulated in terms of decisions to be made, constraints, objective function and required data. 
  • Incorporate uncertainty (discovered in the data) into the objective of the optimization problem. 
  • Think algorithmically. That is to formulate stepwise procedures to find a solution which is feasible (a set of decisions adhering to the constraints) and of high quality for an optimization problem (with and without uncertainty). 
  • Apply these procedures using programming skills. 
  • Translate the outcomes of the optimization problem to advices for the company to solve the real business problem.  
  • Critically reflect on the outcomes of the algorithms, its implications and its limitations and present it individually but also in a team.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Session One (whole group):
  • Introductions
  • Feedback exchange
  • Managing nervousness
  • Body parts (including voice)
  • Getting their attention
  • Introducing yourself
  • Using the stage
  • Leveraging interaction
  • Managing Q&A
  • Managing hostility
  • What if something goes wrong?
  • Establishing credibility
  • When are you ‘on’?
  • Female and cross cultural things
  • Presenting academic research
  • Those first few moments
  • What if you don’t have an answer?
  • Conferences and networking
  • Video-taped presentation (+/- 5 minutes per person) + facilitated group feedback debrief
  • View and privately discuss video 1:1 with facilitator for further feedback
  • Goal-setting and action-planning
Session Two (1:1 meeting):
  • Private virtual consultation 1:1 with facilitator
  • Possible Zoom recording of a presentation or self-introduction - recording will be sent to the student 
  • Goal setting
Session Three (whole group):
  • Video-taped presentation (+/- 10 minutes per person) + facilitated group feedback debrief
  • Private consultation 1:1 with facilitator rotated with viewing own video and reflection/goal setting
  • Goal setting and sharing
  • Group discussion on how to support each other moving forward
In connection with the highly individual approach, 100% attendance and serious preparation for each session is required. The course is offered three times per academic year. Maximum number of participants is 10. Leerdoelen
  • Clarify what your current presentation strengths and development areas are
  • Understand what presentation techniques are received most positively by audiences
  • Learn what behaviors to avoid when presenting
  • Learn to effectively interact and engage your audience
  • Learn how to deliver your message clearly and concisely
  • Learn how to present to large groups at conferences successfully

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Accounting is the language of business. Given that the role profile of financial managers has broadened substantially in recent years with a particular emphasis on management skills, accounting and financial management graduates from our programme more than ever need to be able to communicate the key implications of this (sometimes complicated) language to a variety of different audiences in a convincing and easy manner.

Therefore, the department of Accounting and Control offers this 1 ECTS course to provide students with the necessary tools for preparing a good presentation and communicating its key messages effectively. It is mandatory for all incoming students in accounting and financial management.

The course format will be multiple sessions with experienced coaches from the J-building and companies. To pass this course, students will need to attend the sessions. An alternative assessment format will be to prepare a presentation on a subject recorded on video
 
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
Students in this course will learn:
  • How to prepare a clear presentation structure
  • How to create quality slides for different areas and audiences, such as research, real life cases, or executive summaries
  • How to make impact on the audience
  • How to present themselves effectively

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>‘Preventie en bestraffing’ gaat over de verschillende manieren waarop we reageren op criminaliteit. Het gaat dan in de eerste plaats om straf. Straf is niet alleen een reactie achteraf, maar de dreiging van straf dient ook om criminaliteit te voorkomen. We bespreken in dit vak uitgebreid het onderzoek naar de effectiviteit van verschillende vormen van preventie van criminaliteit, zowel door straf, als door sociale en situationele interventies. We kijken ook naar ontwikkelingen in het bestraffingsbeleid, in historisch en internationaal perspectief. Hoe soft of streng is Nederland in vergelijking tot andere landen en hoe heeft het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid zich ontwikkeld in de afgelopen 30 jaar? Deze ontwikkelingen worden geduid met behulp van het begrip beheerscultuur.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>In dit vak zullen jullie kennis opdoen van de verschillende strafdoelen, hun onderlinge relatie en de mate waarin zij in het huidige sanctiebeleid tot uitdrukking komen. Tevens biedt dit vak inzicht in de doelstellingen en effectiviteit van verschillende resocialiserende interventies en andere mogelijkheden tot preventie van criminaliteit, met als doel voor verschillende criminaliteitsproblemen aanbevelingen te kunnen doen voor effectieve interventies, en kritisch te kunnen reflecteren op de waarde van effectiviteitsonderzoek van interventies. Voorts zullen jullie in dit vak leren om de ontwikkelingen in het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid in een historisch kader en internationaal vergelijkend perspectief te plaatsen. Daarnaast kunnen jullie, na afloop van het vak, de huidige verhouding tussen dader, slachtoffers en maatschappij verklaren aan de hand van het begrip beheerscultuur. Dit biedt het kader om diverse aspecten van het huidige sanctiebeleid met elkaar in verband te brengen en de maatschappelijke consequenties ervan te kunnen doorgronden.</body>
</html>

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Pricing approaches have evolved from very restrained economic and financial perspectives to a broader consumer-oriented framework. In this course, we will study different approaches to have a comprehensive understanding of the economic, strategic, and behavioral considerations that impact a pricing strategy. We will study theoretical concepts linked to economic and behavioral approaches to pricing, price customization/discrimination, price bundling and multi-part tariffs, value-based pricing, dynamic pricing, retail pricing strategies, pricing for goods/services with externalities, and pricing in two-sided markets. We will use examples and case studies from various product categories such as consumer packaged goods, financial services, healthcare plans, and cell phone plans.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Understand the economic and financial aspects of pricing: estimate the demand curve, estimate customer willingness-to-pay, and calculate profit-maximizing prices.
  • Develop a value-based pricing strategy that also considers the effect of non-price factors on perceived value.
  • Learn to spot all relevant aspects of pricing in the marketplace, through business applications, examples and case studies.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. J de Vries', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']
text:
Inhoud
Onderwerp
Primaire processen omvatten de product- of diensten-voortbrengende processen, waarmee bedrijven hun geld verdienen. Activiteiten die hierbij ondersteunend zijn (informatiemanagement, financieel management, personeelsmanagement en dergelijke), worden aangeduid als secundaire processen. Primaire processen in organisaties omvatten het inkoop-, productie-, verkoop, distributie-, service- en retourverwerkingsproces. In dit college wordt ook de ontwikkeling van productieprocessen tot de primaire processen gerekend. Het geheel van aan elkaar gerelateerde activiteiten behorende tot het product- of dienstcreatie en -realisatieproces noemt men in het Engels Operations Management. Voor industriële ondernemingen omvat dit aspecten als mechanisering en automatisering inclusief de bijbehorende informatietechnologie, logistiek, maar ook capaciteitsplanning en layout. Alle functies in een onderneming - van Research tot Marketing - hebben direct of indirect relaties met de voortbrengende processen. De aandacht van het vak is zowel gericht op industriële als op diensten-voortbrengende ondernemingen.
Relevantie
Elke organisatie heeft primaire en secundaire processen. In de primaire processen wordt toegevoegde waarde van het product of dienst gecreëerd. In de automobielindustrie bestaan de primaire processen uit het ontwikkelen en productierijp maken van nieuwe modellen en features, het efficiënt inkopen en assembleren van ingekochte componenten, zorgen voor efficiënte aan- en afvoerlogistiek, het vinden van de juiste afzetkanalen, het collecteren, demonteren en herverwerken van auto's aan het eind van hun levensloop. Bij een bedrijf als McDonald's bestaat het primaire proces uit het ontwikkelen van nieuwe producten, het vinden van goede leveranciers (wereldwijd), aan- en afvoerlogistiek van leveranciers naar de verschillende distributiecentra, fabrieken en restaurants, het productie- en verkoopproces in het restaurant en de recycling van het afval dat overal wordt gegenereerd. Het is duidelijk dat de primaire processen van dergelijke organisaties veel verschillen vertonen. Er zijn echter ook overeenkomsten.
  Leerdoelen

Leerdoelen

na afronding van het vak is de student in staat om:
  • De relatie tussen verschillende proceseigenschappen en prestatiemaatstaven te begrijpen
  • De eigenschappen van prestatieanalyse, procesontwerp, en planning te begrijpen
  • Kwantitatieve problemen op het gebied van prestatieanalyse, procesontwerp en planning op te lossen
  • De implicaties van de uitkomsten van kwantitatieve problemen te evalueren

course_title: Principles of Ecology: Biodiversity & Nature-Inclusive Design
college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course provides a background in the fundamental principles of ecology, including concepts of natural selection, population and community ecology, biodiversity, and sustainability. Students will acquire an "ecological literacy" about how the natural world works, and develop an understanding of how scientific methods are used to construct ecological knowledge. The course will also explore some of today's major ecological challenges, and the important research that is being done to address these concerns. As the course description suggests, ecology is aimed at giving students an overview of the field of ecology and how it applies to the sustainability of human societies. If you are curious about how the interactions between individual organisms and their environments scale up to global ecosystems, this course will provide you with a good introduction to nested complexity of the natural world.
  Leerdoelen
After completing this course, you will be able to:
  • analyse how biotic and abiotic interactions give rise to patterns of abundance and distribution of organisms at several scales;
  • design a management plan for the conservation of biodiversity in a world region by assessing the conflicts and opportunities on the use of natural resources by local populations.
  • apply ecological principles to current environmental challenges and conservation concerns;
  • characterize patterns and processes in nature through direct experience with local ecosystems;
  • assess the effects of human disturbance on ecosystems through ecological succession and alternative-stable states theory;
  • use ecological models to illustrate the abundance of organisms and the dynamics of populations over time;
  • compare structural and functional features between different types of ecosystems;

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud

Does Okun’s law hold in practice? Does the Phillips curve really exist? In this course you will learn how to perform empirical analyses to answer this kind of questions. The course is strongly build upon what you have learnt in Basic Statistics and Intermediate Statistics I and is specifically aimed at students with a major in economics.

During the course we will discuss important concepts for time series such as stationarity, unit roots and autoregressive models. Moreover, you will learn how to perform the analyses in the software program Stata.

Leerdoelen After succesful completion of this course, you:
  • Understand the main concepts related to simple and multiple regression;
  • Are aware of common techniques and concepts for time series analysis;
  • Are able to apply ordinary least squares;
  • Can perform basic analyses in Stata and are able to interpret Stata output;
  • Can formulate a research question and testable research hypotheses on the basis of previous research and economic reasoning;
  • Can apply statistical methods to answer a research question;
  • Are able to structure and discuss the research findings through a written report.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. BA Demena', 'dr. Z Zarepour', 'JM Cruzatti Constantine', 'prof.dr. SM Murshed', 'Y Li']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
This course lays the groundwork for financial modeling in Market-and Bank-Based Financial Markets. We start by discussing sources of company financial information, how different financial statements are connected, and procedures for financial statements forecasting, accuracy assessments, and valuation. In particular, we discuss how data analytics can help in this process. 
The results of such analyses are important for investors who use them in assessing the risk and return of investments in corporate credit and equity markets. In each of those two markets we derive a standard optimization representations both for individual investments as well as for portfolios. We link these representations to real-world applications such as platform (P2P) lending, asset management, robo-advising, and high-frequency trading.

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  1. Know which financial statements firms report and how these inform financial markets
  2. Understand how data analytics can help to assess the accuracy of accounting information
  3. Understand the methods and data issues involved in forecasting financial statements and estimating equity value
  4. Be able to apply large-scale forecasting and valuation techniques
  5. Understand the link between risk and expected returns in financial markets
  6. Understand how this is different for equity and debt markets
  7. Be aware of market imperfections
  8. Express investment problems as standard data learning/optimization problems
  9. Be able to apply this approach to FinTech business models
Belangrijk om te weten

Course Information 

  • Pre-requisites: The students are expected to master the material offered in the Canvas pre-courses on Finance and Accounting 
  • Attendance of lectures is not compulsory, but the content covered in the lectures, including the discussions during the lectures are part of the exam material.  
  • Topics covered 
  • Overview of workload (e.g. reading and/or assignments and/or activities each week) 

The course is structured as follows: 

  • Week 1: Financial statements 
  • Week 2: Sources and accuracy of financial statements 
  • Week 3: Forecasting financial statements and equity value 
  • Week 4: Investing in debt and equity markets 
  • Week 5: Standard screening problems: applications in portfolio selection, insurance, liquidity provision, credit applications, and more 
  • Week 6: Risk preferences and profiling: applications to robo-advice

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud

The course Principles of Management will introduce you to the field of business administration and its various sub-disciplines. Business Administration is an interdisciplinary and a context-based field of study concerned with the organisation and the market environment of businesses. It is a problem-oriented discipline focusing on issues within organisations (how does an organisation set different goals and objectives?) and the interaction and relationship of the business with its surrounding (how do political factors affect the business?).

Similar to the discipline itself, this course will be context-based, using cases and examples presenting the latest business developments and current challenges business face for students to better understand the business world. Topics that will be discussed include the global context of business (business environments and business types), the business of managing, people in organisations (Human Resource Management, leadership and teams), managing information (IT), principles of marketing and finance, and political, social, economic, technological and ethical considerations affecting business. The course will provide basic knowledge on business therewith preparing you for more specialised 200 and 300 level Economics & Business major courses.

Leerdoelen After the course, students are able to:
  • Understand the main theoretical perspectives on management and how they relate to the tasks, processes and content of managerial work in organizations;
  • Understand the different elements that comprise an organization and relate these to organizational structure and organizational performance;
  • Define and critically reflect on the (international) business environment;
  • Discuss theories and applications of human resource management;
  • Describe and explain the processes, tools and content involved in managing strategy;
  • Explain how marketing can add value to the business, identify the marketing environment and its stakeholders;
  • Discuss and critically reflect on generic methods of control and performance management, including financial measures to assess performance;
  • Critically reflect on how information systems, and ERP systems in particular, can transform organizations and what the antecedents for its success are;
  • Evaluate the significance of contemporary issues in business and management.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Negotiation training requires both intellectual training and developing skills. The main assumptions of this course are: (a) negotiating is a process that can be understood and (b) negotiating is a skill that can be taught and can be learned. The core questions posed in this course are:
 
  • What are the advantages and disadvantages of various strategies?
  • What do these strategies require for success?
  • When would these strategies be most appropriate?

The course is a combination of reading & understanding theory (through the assigned book and academic articles) as well as applying the theory in simulated negotiation role-plays and a research project. The minor consists primarily of plenary lectures based on required theoretical literature. Each lecture consists of a part of discussing the theory and a part where students are applying this theory (e.g. online/offline role plays). In parallel students prepare and execute a research project (e.g. field experiment, survey-based study) where they actively apply insights from the theory while focusing on a topic of their choice.

The main contents covered in this course are:
  • The theory of negotiation, including behavioral decision making & decision analytic perspectives,
  • Conceptual frameworks to analyze conflict situations in personal and business-related settings and to design negotiation strategies to successfully resolve them.
  • Negotiation techniques and their underlying theoretical explanations.
  • Multi-party and intercultural negotiations.
  • The role of power, influence and persuasion in negotiations.
  • The role of emotions in negotiation situations.
  • Online negotiations using software agents.
  • The role of gender and personality style in negotiations
  • The role of non-verbal communications and lie detection in negotiations
  • How to manage difficult negotiations/people and the role of negotiation ethics.
Leerdoelen
The learning objectives of the course in terms of academic knowledge are:
  • Learn various negotiation theories.
  • Analyze conflict situations and design negotiation strategies to successfully resolve them.
  • Identify negotiation techniques and their underlying theoretical explanations.
  • Understand multi-party and intercultural negotiations.
  • Comprehend the role of power, influence and persuasion in negotiations
  • Identify the role of emotions in negotiation situations.
  • Gain insights on the role of gender and personality in negotiations
  • Understand non-verbal communication and detect non-verbal cues in negotiations
  • Investigate the role of negotiation ethics.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

De cursus Privaat- en ondernemingsrecht bevat een inleiding in het (privaat)recht. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan de verschillende soorten ondernemingsvormen in het eerste deel van de cursus. In het tweede deel van de cursus staat het verbintenissenrecht en het vermogensrecht centraal. De voorgaande onderworpen worden getoetst door middel van een schriftelijk tentamen. De onderwerpen die in de cursus worden bestudeerd:

  • Inleiding recht (algemene begrippen)
  • Personenvennootschappen
  • Rechtspersonen (overwegend de besloten vennootschap en de naamloze vennootschap)
  • Fusies en overnames
  • Bronnen van verbintenis
  • Overeenkomst en onrechtmatige daad als bron verbintenis
  • Niet-nakoming van verbintenissen
  • Begrippen goederenrecht en overdracht (inclusief derdenbescherming)
Leerdoelen
  • Als econoom zal de student bij het nemen van beslissingen oog moeten hebben voor de bestaande juridische problemen en de oplossingen hiervoor. Na het volgen en behalen van deze cursus moet de student derhalve niet alleen in staat zijn het juridische probleem te beschrijven, maar moet hij tevens de relevante rechtsregels kunnen vinden, waarmee het probleem tot een oplossing kan worden gebracht. De student wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met de belangrijkste grondslagen en begrippen op het gebied van het recht. In het bijzonder wordt in deze cursus aandacht besteed aan het verbintenissenrecht, het vermogensrecht en het ondernemingsrecht.
  • De basisbegrippen van het recht toepassen.
  • Ten aanzien van de personenvennootschappen de noodzakelijke rechtsregels ten aanzien van oprichting, vertegenwoordiging, aansprakelijkheid en verdelingen van winsten en verliezen toepassen.
  • De voorgeschreven theorie omtrent de rechtspersonen (in het bijzonder de besloten vennootschap en naamloze vennootschap) toepassen.
  • De verschillende vormen van fusie- en overnames toepassen.
  • De bronnen van verbintenis benoemen en de samenhangende begrippen hieraan relateren.
  • Beoordelen of er een rechtsgeldige overeenkomst tot stand is gekomen, wat de inhoud daarvan is en wat de gevolgen zijn als er niet aan de noodzakelijke voorwaarden is voldaan.
  • Beoordelen of er sprake is van een onrechtmatige daad of een kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid en deze leerstukken kunnen toepassen.
  • Het leerstuk van de niet-nakoming toepassen om te beoordelen of een recht op schadevergoeding ontstaat en of ontbinding of opschorting mogelijk is.
  • De overdracht van verschillende soorten goederen (inclusief de derdenbescherming) toepassen.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Vanaf studiejaar 2021-2022 wordt theoretische delen uit het hoorcollege aangeboden via kennisclips. In het college wordt vervolg meer aandacht besteed aan casuïstiek, vaardigheden  en een verdere uitwerking van verschillende onderdelen.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['JJ de Vogel', 'mr. JHG Verweij - Hoogendijk', 'mr. MM van Campen', 'mr. MP van Eeden - van Harskamp', 'mr. MR Hebly', 'mr. ZH Duijnstee - van Imhoff', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'prof.mr. KJO Jansen', 'prof.mr.dr. HN Schelhaas']
text:
Inhoud In dit vak wordt het Rotterdamse credo ‘where law meets business’ in de praktijk gebracht. Het vak rust inhoudelijk op de drie pijlers van het vermogensrecht: delictueel aansprakelijkheidsrecht, contractenrecht en goederen- en insolventierecht. Het vak omvat bedrijfs- en kantoorbezoeken, masterclasses, schriftelijke en mondelinge opdrachten en is geënt op problemen in de praktijk, die op een juridisch-academische wijze worden opgelost. Leerdoelen
  • argumenten uit de bestudeerde literatuur inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module onder woorden brengen en analyseren en de verschillende invalshoeken synthetiseren tot een afgewogen standpunt;
  • de huidige stand van de rechtspraak inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module onder woorden brengen en analyseren en deze toepassen op een concrete casus;
  • identificeren wat de voornaamste praktijkproblemen zijn inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module en het belang en de omvang van die problemen inschatten;
  • in samenwerking oplossingen aandragen voor een juridisch complex praktijkprobleem en kan binnen die samenwerking zich een eigen visie vormen en die motiveren.
  • met betrekking tot een complexe juridische praktijkkwestie een inhoudelijke positie schriftelijk innemen en in een mondeling debat verdedigen.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Popular accounts of privacy assert that it is a kind of commodity that may be ‘traded’ in exchange for security, or even convenience. This often overlooks how popular and even scholarly understandings of privacy are shaped by technological affordances as well as ideology. Moreover, these accounts shape what is considered appropriate and even ethical for media users, including researchers. This course considers how privacy is made meaningful as a legal/policy requirement, a cultural reference, and an ethical guide. Students will apply multidisciplinary accounts of privacy to various professional contexts, including their own scholarship.

This course aims to develop the students’ critical thinking about privacy and ethics issues of new technologies. It does so by exploring how privacy thought has evolved from being the ‘right to be let alone’ to being key for a free and democratic society, the introduction of the GDPR and the legislative focus on consent. Further to privacy, this module discusses the ethical dimension of Artificial Intelligence and ethics in research, which it will help provide the students with a solid foundation to conduct future research and work. Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge and understanding of:

  • Multi-disciplinary accounts of privacy and other related concepts.
  • How new technologies may impact public perception of social and ethical conditions.

Students have developed the skills to:

  • Critique technological advancements and applications in terms of their ethical and privacy impacts.
  • Design and implement privacy-oriented tools, such as, privacy impact assessments and research ethics considerations.
  • Differentiate between the different privacy conceptualisations and discuss their importance to the development of the concept of privacy.
  • Formulate research problems related to privacy in socio-technological systems.

course_title: Privacy, Surveillance and New Media Technologies
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Contemporary surveillance is a multi-directional, multifaceted and technologically-mediated phenomenon. Social media, mobile communications, sensor networks are already part of the surveillance activities of many public and private organizations. At the same time, privacy enhancing technologies and regulations as well as peer surveillance give people room for negotiation and action. In this course we will study and critically analyse these practices and associated technologies. This involves reflection on our relation to technologies and their role in our contemporary culture as well as on our understanding of surveillance and privacy and the way they are construed in different genres of media and in academic literature. Leerdoelen This course aims to give students a broader understanding of surveillance and privacy in our technologically mediated culture. At the end of the course students can:
  • Discuss key surveillance concepts and metaphors.
  • Understand and apply theories of privacy, surveillance, and technology to a variety of situations/contexts.
  • Identify the role of new media technologies in contemporary global surveillance practices.
  • Identify privacy issues in these practices and develop strategies for resilience and solutions to resolve them. 
Students have developed skills to:
  • Analyze contemporary practices of surveillance and of privacy protection.
  • Present arguments defending or criticizing influential conceptualizations of surveillance.
  • Integrate theoretical and practical knowledge on surveillance, privacy and new media technologies into a written paper.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
From very humble beginnings in the 1980s, Private Equity has become a very large Asset Class. Although fundraising has levelled off in 2019 and 2020 from an all-time record in 2018, still, at the end of 2020 over $2 trillion of “dry powder” globally is looking to be invested by PE funds. 

This course aims to give students a solid introduction to the world of Private Equity (including Venture Capital and Buyouts). It focuses on the following (along with practical insight from prior transactions) main areas of knowledge that underpin the PE environment: 

  • "Organizational” topics related to PE funds & investing; 
  • Cash flow analysis & modeling (we will be using a PE/LBO model for that); 
  • Review of corporate valuation methods; 
  • PE investment process (a complete cycle from a purchase idea to a completion of acquisition; and from putting the asset up for sale through to a complete exit) - we will follow a “live” (recently completed) transaction; 
  • PE transaction structuring; 
  • Negotiation of a Term Sheet/Letter of Intent and Share Purchase Agreement (SPA); 
  • Finalization of the transaction price (Locked Box and Completion Accounts mechanisms); 
  • Practical key lessons from prior transactions, i.e. practical experience; 

With the exception of item 1 (above), where some theory and “informational” delivery (deliberately kept to a modest minimum) is scheduled, this course focuses on practical aspects and transaction based learning. 


Entry requirements or required background knowledge 
As the course is based on the understanding of finance concepts developed in core courses, it requires a reasonable knowledge of accounting, corporate finance, basics of theoretical valuation as well as proficiency in Excel. It assumes students have taken appropriate pre-requisites. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • Understand PE general concepts, how PE funds are formed, how they are managed and operate, how they pursue value creation for their stakeholders. 
  • Be knowledgeable about the key attributes of private equity as an asset class; be able to apply specific Private Equity valuation and modelling techniques. 
  • Understand the PE process and all components needed to successfully complete a PE transaction (valuation, leverage, transaction structure, transaction due diligence SPA signing, closing and post-closing). 
  • Understand how market conditions impact the Private Equity industry: leverage & credit markets, equity market valuations. 
  • Anticipate events and trends within the Private Equity industry and gain deeper insight of advanced corporate finance.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. E Themeli, LL.M', 'PP Penasthika', 'prof.mr.dr. XE Kramer']
text:
Inhoud The PAX Moot is a young international moot competition for law students. Initially it was organised between French Universities, but in 2018 the turning point came, and the event opened its doors to students from all over the world. With each edition more teams from Europe and worldwide decide to join the PAX Moot and compete in solving an imaginary case on matters of private international law (for more information see https://paxmoot.com/).   
The Erasmus School of Law (ESL) teams participated in the competition since the first international edition in 2018 and managed to secure good results with each participation.
 
The preparation for the competition begins with the publication of the fictional case in January each year and ends with the oral rounds that are scheduled in late May. In preparation for the pleading rounds, each team has to write and submit written memoranda for the claimants and defendants. These are due in April, after which the preparation for the oral pleadings begins. The selected ESL students will be preparing the PAX Moot from January to May.
 
This elective course gives students a unique opportunity to put their legal knowledge, research and advocacy skills into practice. During the course, the students will have to work on the fictional case dealing with matters of private international law, as well as some related aspects concerning EU law, international law, human rights and/or arbitration. The first months of the course will be dedicated to legal research and the development of legal argumentation in preparing the claimants and defendants memoranda. Following the submission of the written memoranda, the students will have to start pleading for the parties they are representing (claimants or defendants) in training oral rounds. This part will be completed with the pleading rounds of the PAX Moot before panels of judges composed of specialists in private international law, judges, and lawyers.
 
All the preparation of the PAX Moot is carried out under the careful supervision of professors and researchers of the Erasmus School of Law. Students taking this course will have the chance to test their knowledge, ideas and persuasive skills in writing and during the numerous pleading rounds organised with the trainers and lawyers at law firms. Finally, the students will have an opportunity to challenge themselves and respond to the challenges of the other participating teams when acting as councils for the claimants or the defendants in the rounds of the PAX Moot.
 
Both Dutch and international students registered at ESL for Master or advanced Bachelor programmes can decide to participate in the selection for the ESL PAX Moot team. From the group of applications received usually a number of four students will be selected to prepare for the PAX Moot. Leerdoelen During this course the students will:
  • build an in-depth knowledge of private international law, with a focus on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement, and applicable law in international disputes, as well as connected areas such as EU law, international law, human rights and/or arbitration;
  • develop their analytical skills;
  • gain experience in conducting legal research;
  • develop their writing skills, more specifically the drafting of memoranda and pleadings;
  • develop their practical skills, including legal English proficiency;
  • develop the presentation skills, especially oral advocacy skills and persuasion;
  • learn to plead the (subjective) legal position of one of the parties to a case;
  • learn to operate and excel in a team environment.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. M Grith', 'dr.ir. S Schalk', 'TWL ter Horst', 'YN Hoogendoorn']
text:
Inhoud

Continuous random variables, continuous distributions, moment generating functions, discrete and continuous joint distributions, independence , conditional distributions, conditional expectations, variance, covariance, functions of random variables, transformation methods, Central Limit Theorem, stochastic convergence, sampling distributions.

Leerdoelen
  • Understand the basics of probability theory, including central concepts and proofs of central results.
  • Obtain knowledge of and proficiency in reasoning and calculating with probabilities: continuous and discrete random variables, functions of random variables, transformation methods, joint and conditional distributions.
  • Obtain insight and experience in the use of probability theory in statistics: sampling distributions, central limit theorem.
  • Gets insight into basic results in probability theory that are important in econometrics.
  • Gets experience in applying mathematical concepts and techniques of probability theory.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The content of this course is the same as last year. The treatment of topics has been adjusted slightly, inspired by conversations with and remarks of students, by past experiences with the course process, and from discussions with fellow lecturers. Extra It is not allowed to use a programmable calculator during the (re-)examination.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Discrete and continuous random variables, moment generating functions, discrete and continuous joint distributions, independence , conditional distributions, conditional expectations, variance, covariance, functions of random variables, transformation methods, Central Limit Theorem, stochastic convergence.

Leerdoelen
  • Understands the basics of probability theory, including central concepts and proofs of central results.
  • Obtains knowledge of and proficiency in reasoning and calculating with probabilities: continuous and discrete random variables, functions of random variables, transformation methods, joint and conditional distributions.
  • Obtains insight and experience in the use of probability theory in statistics: sampling distributions, central limit theorem.
  • Gets insight into basic results in probability theory that are important in econometrics.
  • Gets experience in applying mathematical concepts and techniques of probability theory.
Extra It is not allowed to use a programmable calculator during the (re-)examination.

course_title: Production Cultures in the Streaming Industries
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This is an exciting and transformative moment for streaming industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, streaming platforms that provide different types of content directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. For example, the global expansion of streaming video on-demand services like Netflix both reflect and drive change within traditional audiovisual media industries like television and film. Yet, the proprietary nature of streaming audience data and the near total lack of data transparency offered by streaming companies themselves (e.g. Netflix, Spotify, YouTube) creates a variety of challenges for media industry researchers. 
  Leerdoelen The main goal of this research workshop is to train students to overcome these challenges using the “production culture” approach. This approach, sometimes called media historiography, media industry studies, or trade press analysis, is grounded in the academic perspective that understands media industry discourse as centrally important to understanding media industry practice.
 
Students will learn how to gather and analyze relevant data about the streaming industries from a variety of publicly available secondary sources including but not limited to trade press articles, press releases, trade and popular press interviews, videos of industry events, annual reports, policy reports, and financial documents. Students will formulate a research question related to a specific streaming service situated within a broader streaming industry. Students will create a qualitative research design, collect and then analyze data. Their efforts culminate in an academic research paper.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. J Alkema', 'JJ Werkhoven, MSc', 'NI Postma, MSc', 'prof.dr. MC Schippers']
text:
Inhoud

Course overview

The rise of automation and AI causes rapid changes in our private and professional lives often outpacing peoples’ ability to adapt. The future of work therefore calls for the adoption of lifelong learning and places more and more importance on higher cognitive, social and emotional, and technological skills. It is no longer enough to simply obtain a university degree. Those who want to remain employable and successful throughout their careers and fully participate in society need to embrace a growth mindset and muster the discipline and self-motivation to constantly develop themselves and others.
In addition, our increasingly globalized world leads to higher levels of ambiguity and many of the problems managers are confronted with today and in the future are characterized by increasing complexity that require the careful consideration and evaluation of different trade-offs and stakeholders. Those who want to become agents for positive change need to understand how to navigate these complexities with integrity, how to develop political savvy and how to build communities to initiate and sustain that change.
It is evident that for future managers to be successful it is not sufficient that they are content experts and understand the intricacies of subjects such as finance, marketing, and operations management. Instead, they need to be equally skillful when it comes to e.g., time- and self-management, emotion management, stakeholder management and moral decision-making.
The Professional Development & Mentoring Course aims to support students in developing these skills. This requires continuous self-reflection, feedback and above all practice. Therefore, particular emphasis is put on small-scale workshops in which students will actively practice the skills taught through lectures, online modules, and self-study. Throughout the course students will regularly reflect on the progress they have made and receive peer feedback.
  Leerdoelen

Learning goals

After following this course, the student is able to:
  • effectively schedule their time, analyze their development progress and accept personal responsibility;
  • work collaboratively in diverse teams by employing active listening and perspective-taking, as well as constructively giving and receiving feedback; and give substance to the joint responsibility for group work;
  • demonstrate a mindset of curiosity and open-mindedness;
  • critically analyze current societal issues taking into account the needs of different stakeholders and formulate recommendations on how to deal with wicked problems;
  • demonstrate basic coaching skills;
  • use academical referencing appropriately.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course overview
The world is demanding new leadership for an ever more complex and dynamic world. Professional Development is a course organized by the department of Business-Society Management and focuses on the role of the business leader. The goal of the course is to offer students information, tools and skills to better understand, engage in and change the self, the other person, the organization and the world. 

Professional Development should not only include tools for understanding and influencing the environment, but also exploring and questioning the students’ own frames of reference. Professional Development is based on the principles of transformational learning which means that the course is both outside in and inside out. This makes Professional Development a rather provocative course, with much time spend on self-exploration, living up to RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change by addressing the role of business and business leaders in both locally and globally relevant problems. The course points at the responsibility of the business leader to understand her or his own frames of reference as a foundation for contributing to positive change in the world.
Students are required to formulate personal learning goals right at the start of the course, which will later on serve as a point of reference for the personal essay. Leerdoelen Learning goals

After following this course, the student is able to:
  • Monitor the realization of several more personal learning goals by critically incorporating the results of self-reflection, peer- and tutor feedback.
  • Master presentation, writing, coaching and negotiation skills to a level that allows the student to adapt application of the skills to variation in intrinsic (personal) and extrinsic (environmental) factors in a practical context.
  • Critically review and transform his or her personal frame of reference.
  • Explain new insights to change and apply these in their own personal, professional, and/or educational environment.

course_title: Professional Development Part I: Research Design
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This module focuses on research design. The primary goal is to enable students to design social science research in the area of international public management and policy. We will split the design process in a number of steps including research question, concept and hypothesis specification and research design. For each step we will discuss tradeoffs and relevant quality criteria, such as relevance, internal validity and external validity. This will be done through a series of lectures. Students will make a number of weekly assignments that together will cover all elements of a research proposal. Assignments will be discussed in working groups. Note that there will be one or two sessions prior to block 3, to allow you to focus your assignment on the topic of your thesis. Although most students have had a proper introduction to social science methods, they should not underestimate the difficulty of developing a relevant and rigorous research project that meets the standards of a master program. Leerdoelen After passing the module professional development students will be able:
  • to develop a relevant, feasible, and rigorous research design;
  • to indicate the trade-offs in designing research and to defend their choices made in developing their research project;
  • to evaluate research in terms of relevance, specificity, measurement reliability and measurement validity, internal validity, and external validity (generalization).
Belangrijk om te weten Core readings to be announced

course_title: Professional Development Part II: Preparation Labour Market
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud The module Professional Development focuses on the preparation for the labor market. The program is composed of:
  • a four-days study-trip to International Organizations and Non-Governmental Organizations in Geneva. The study-trip is mandatory and involves extra costs [airfare ticket, lodging];
  • a one day visit to the European institutions in Brussels
  • a series of guest-lectures by practitioners and labor market experts to make students familiar with the and to help them to find their way at the international labor market.
The trip to Geneva takes place in the Fall, the visit to Brussels in the Spring. Students are kindly invited to participate in the design and organization of the program. Leerdoelen After passing the module professional development students will be able:
  • to describe the main features of the international labor market, including selection procedures and entrance requirements of international organizations;
  • to understand the [inter]cultural differences in work practices;
  • to write an application letter and to design a resume that meets international standards in order to be successful on the international labor market.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The Professional Development Trajectory achieves two interconnected goals: to facilitate your personal development as a professional in your chosen field, and to equip you with the state-of-science methods to help others grow. Your personal development is achieved by sessions that are designed to help you a) become more aware of your values and life purpose b) clarify your strengths and weaknesses, and c) set and achieve the developmental goals that will lead you closer to your purpose.
The course also unpacks the science behind the sessions. By introducing theories of developmental psychology, we explore three fundamental questions: how individuals obtain knowledge, how employees develop their skills, and how followers grow into leaders. By learning and experiencing the science of personal development, you will be empowered to be a better trainer, coach, and mentor yourself.
This trajectory culminates in a closing session where you take stock of your own learning throughout the one year. Together with your classmates, you ready yourself for a life-long journey of personal development of yourself as well as others who will work with you.
  Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives

  • Become more aware of your values and life purpose; 
  • Clarify your strengths and weaknesses;
  • Set and achieve the developmental goals that will lead you closer to your purpose.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['A Mamede Soares Braga, MSc', 'dr. I Merkelbach', 'dr. M Dewies', 'dr. PL Kocken', 'dr. T Magnee', 'S Shagiwal, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

In this course, students will have the opportunity to acquire skills necessary for employment in the professional practice of interventions and policies aimed at health behavior change. They will learn skills in evaluating their own achievement in critically reflecting on personal and professional development in the context of health psychology and behavior change. After the course students have the skills to carry out the steps of planning behavior change programs and reflect on their personal and team skills to manage such programs. The course runs in combination with the course Health Psychology and Behavior change and students will have the chance to develop skills they can apply when developing the behavior change intervention in that course.

The professional skills course addresses four topics:

  • Team skills: with whom do you collaborate and how?
  • Managing the process of project planning: how do you organize your project and use time management or budgeting?
  • Inclusiveness in health policy and interventions.
  • Diffusion, implementation and communication: knowledge brokerage aimed at your target population such as policy makers.
Leerdoelen
At the end of this course you will be able to...
  • Critically assess personal strengths and weaknesses with regard to study skills, self-management skills and team skills.
  • Distinguish the stages of planning behavior change programs.
  • Apply the skills and methods for , i.e. creation of a basic logic model, stakeholder analysis, activity break down, time management and budgeting.
  • Critically argue the importance of accounting for diversity in target populations of interventions and policies.
  • Understand theories of diffusion, dissemination and implementation.
  • Create a personal portfolio consisting of the results of the tasks and assignments of the professional skills course and reflections on the completed tasks.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. J Alkema', 'JJ Werkhoven, MSc', 'NI Postma, MSc', 'prof.dr. MC Schippers']
text:
Inhoud Het vak professionele ontwikkeling bestaat uit een reeks workshops die het hele bachelorprogramma doorlopen. Het is bedoeld om studenten de vaardigheden te bieden die ze nodig hebben als verantwoordelijke managementprofessionals in de samenleving en bereidt als zodanig studenten voor op de arbeidsmarkt. Het traject omvat drie opeenvolgende jaren van training in essentiële competenties die studenten moeten beheersen om te voldoen aan de verwachtingen die managers in organisaties en de samenleving van hen verlangen. Op deze manier zijn studenten bereid om een ​​kracht te worden voor positieve verandering in de wereld door bij te dragen aan de welvaart en het welzijn van de mensen die ze beïnvloeden door hun beslissingen en acties zowel binnen als buiten de organisatie waarvoor ze werken.
 
Managers hebben verantwoordelijkheden die soms lastig kunnen zijn. Als vertegenwoordigers van een organisatie moeten managers zich sterk bewust zijn van de complexiteit van de omgeving waarin ze werken en van de impact die ze hebben op anderen binnen en buiten de organisatie. Om de problemen en uitdagingen aan te pakken waarmee een organisatie op elk moment in haar bestaan ​​wordt geconfronteerd, moeten professionals beschikken over sterke analytische vaardigheden en over de bereidheid en het vermogen om verantwoordelijkheid te nemen voor en toezicht te houden op de consequenties van hun beslissingen voor een verscheidenheid aan betrokken stakeholders. Alleen door zo’n houding aan te nemen, kunnen managers hun 'license to operate' in de samenleving rechtvaardigen. In het onderwijsklimaat van onze school draait dit vermogen om de vier kernwaarden kritisch, creatief, zorgzaam en collaboratief. RSM-studenten zullen altijd informeren naar de grondslagen van en bewijs voor de kennis die zij toepassen in zakelijke contexten, zij zullen voortdurend streven naar creativiteit in de oplossingen die zij bedenken voor zakelijke problemen, zij zullen dit met zorg en empathie doen voor degenen die geraakt worden door hun inspanningen, en ze beseffen dat succesvolle oplossingen altijd afhankelijk zijn van constructieve samenwerking en partnerschappen met anderen. Het vak professionele ontwikkeling is erop gericht om deze waarden te gebruiken als basis voor het intellectuele en professionele onderwijs van studenten.
 
Het eerste jaar van dit vak richt zich in de eerste plaats op het ontwikkelen van vaardigheden in zelf- en teammanagement en communicatie- en kritisch denkvermogen, zowel voor academische als professionele doeleinden. Het vak volgt een integrale aanpak door een oefenterrein aan te bieden voor verschillende vaardigheden in nauwe afstemming met de behoeften van andere cursussen in het programma. Ondertussen worden studenten doorlopend uitgedaagd om na te denken over de fundamenten van hun rol als toekomstige managers. Vaardigheden kunnen worden beoordeeld zowel in de PO cursussen zelf als in de cursussen waarvoor de aangeboden vaardigheden vereist zijn.
 
Het vak professionele ontwikkeling speelt in op de specifieke behoeften van de studentenpopulatie. We zullen studenten faciliteren om hun plaats binnen ons programma te vinden en de grote verscheidenheid aan termen zoals onderwijskundige achtergronden, leefomstandigheden, etnische, sociaaleconomische, religieuze, genderoriëntatie of seksualiteit gebruiken om gezamenlijk een onderwijsomgeving te ontwikkelen waar studenten kunnen excelleren.
  Leerdoelen Tijdens de cursus leren studenten om:
  • hun studie effectief te organiseren, te plannen en te reflecteren en verantwoordelijkheid te nemen voor hun studievoortgang (doelen stellen, timemanagement, een actieve leerhouding aannemen, mindfulness),
  • de basisprincipes en soorten interviews te begrijpen als een methode voor gegevensverzameling en ze competent toe te passen in concrete bedrijfsonderzoeksinstellingen,
  • constructief te werken in teams en uitdagingen aan te pakken zoals de sustainable development goals, inclusiviteit en gemeenschapsvorming in groepsdynamiek om samenwerking te optimaliseren,
  • kritisch denkvermogen te ontwikkelen en gebruiken om (academische) bronnen en andere teksten te evalueren,
  • overtuigende argumenten te herkennen en te ontwikkelen en deze te gebruiken in een evenwichtig artikel of andere presentatie, door regels toe te passen met betrekking tot correcte verwijzingen,
  • diverse vormen van professionele communicatie te organiseren en uit te voeren, zoals presentaties, vergaderingen en het geven en ontvangen van feedback en
  • diverse opvattingen over managementprofessionaliteit te vergelijken, beoordelen en bediscussiëren met het oog op hun implementatie in de beroepspraktijk en hun impact op de samenleving in het algemeen.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
  • Week 1: Opfrissen Object-geörienteerd programmeren met Java
  • Week 2: Werken met interfaces
  • Week 3: Werken met inheritance
  • Week 4: Werken met datastructuren uit de Collections API
  • Week 5-6: Libraries, moderne Java features
  • Week 7: Samenvatting, andere programmeertalen (geen tentamenstof)
Leerdoelen
  • Het begrijpen van de belangrijkste verschillen tussen procedureel en objectgeoriënteerd programmeerparadigma's.
  • Het begrijpen van de basisbegrippen in objectgeoriënteerd programmeren (data hiding, interfaces, inheritance, exceptions, streams) en in staat zijn om efficiënt te programmeren met deze begrippen in Java.
  • Het begrijpen van de 'programming by contract' aanpak en in staat zijn de kernconcepten (pre-and post-conditions) te programmeren voor een foutvrij middelgroot programma.
  • Het begrijpen van het belang van unit testing en in staat zijn programma's te testen en te debuggen.
  • In staat zijn met relevante libraries te werken.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Dit jaar zal gezorgd worden dat het vak Programmeren goed aansluit op de vernieuwing van Inleiding Programmeren zoals die afgelopen jaar is doorgevoerd. Inhoudelijk is het doel nog wel min of meer dezelfde leerdoelen en werkstructuur aan te houden, maar de gebruikte vakmaterialen zullen wijzigen zodat het mooi aansluit bij de lijn die bij Inleiding Programmeren is ingezet.
  Extra Het is bij dit vak belangrijk om veel individueel programmeerwerk te doen. Het is hierom zeer aan te bevelen deel te nemen aan de practica, omdat u hier hulp krijgen voor de opdrachten die samen voor 60% van het cijfer meetellen. Het is ook belangrijk de theorie te beheersen voor het eindtentamen dat theoretisch van aard is.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
  • Week 1: Refresh Object-oriented programming Java
  • Week 2: Working with interfaces
  • Week 3: Working with inheritance
  • Week 4: Working with datastructes from the Collections API
  • Week 5-6: Libraries, modern Java features
  • Week 7: Summary, other programming languages (no exam material)
Leerdoelen
  • Understand the main differences between procedural and object oriented programming paradigms
  • Understand the basic concepts of object oriented programming (data hiding, interfaces, inheritance, exceptions, streams) and be able to program with these efficiently in Java
  • Understand the programming by contract approach, and be able to use its core concepts (pre- and post-conditions) to program medium-size error free programs
  • Understand the importance of unit testing and be able to test and debug programs
  • Be able to work with relevant libraries
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This year we will make sure that the course Programming connects well to new approach to the course Introduction to Programming as it was implemented last year. The content and structure of the course will remain more or less the same, but the materials used in the course will be changed to connect as things have been set up in the Introduction to Programming course. Extra For this course it is important to do a lot of individual programming work. Therefore it is strongly recommended to participate in the tutorials, because here you can get help with the assignments that count for 60% toward your grade. It is important to master the theory for the final exam, which is theoretical in nature.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. J Bae', 'dr. J Zhang', 'dr. S de Snoo - Renes, LL.M', 'dr. W Cao']
text:
Inhoud

The general objective of this course is to acquire basic programming skills in R that students can use in data analytics. The topics covered are specified in the course objectives. The skills that you acquire during this course will be useful for the Seminar Data Analytics, Seminar Financial Accounting Research and the MSc Thesis.

Leerdoelen
  • import datasets from files
  • clean and merge datasets
  • present descriptive information on datasets using tables and figures
  • make use of loops, if-statements and functions in your code
  • debug programming code
  • perform simple statistical analyses on numerical data
  • make use of regular expressions, logical indexing and pattern matching
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar In response to feedback from students last year and recent developments, the course replace one lecture (i.e., Simulation) with textual analysis as below. 


The general objective of this course is to acquire basic programming skills in R that students can use in data analytics. After completion of this course, you will be able to

- import datasets from files
- clean and merge datasets 
- present descriptive information on datasets using tables and figures
- make use of loops, if-statements and functions in your code
- debug programming code
- search and manipulate texts
- perform basic textual analysis
- use external sources to find solutions to programming problems

The skills that you acquire during this course are necessary for the Seminar Data Analytics, Seminar Financial Accounting Research and the MSc Thesis.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
Ever done hundreds of repetitive actions on rows in tables? Ever copied daily update information from websites every day? Ever wondered how computer programs work, or how online shops keep track of all items for sale and their stock? 

Then, this is the elective module for you! You will be learning the basic components of computer programs, write your own programs in Python, trace bugs and inspect variables in Jupyter Notebooks. 

“Why would I want to be able to write computer programs, or tiny helpers?”, you may ask. Customized computer programs tailored to specific business are used in many companies. Being able, as a manager, to communicate with in-house or hired computer programmers is an asset. 

The course comprises of assignments in Jupyter Notebook, so you can practice your skills using a web browser, with the help of programmers at RSM, together with other students and at home. The results of these assignments form part of your total grade. For the other part you will be asked to solve programming challenges, also in Jupyter Notebooks during an exam. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • Combine the building blocks of computer programs
  • Write, inspect and trace bugs in computer programs
  • Simplify your (repetitive) daily tasks with (little) helper programs or scripts
