course_title: Programming for Data Science and Marketing Analytics
college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Introduction to the R language design
  • Data exploration and manipulation in R (base R / tidyverse)
  • Graphical visualizations (base graphs / ggplot)
  • Dynamic reporting with R-Markdown
  • Getting data in and out of R
  • Programming in R through functions and loops
  • Simple web scraping with rvest

  Leerdoelen R is probably the most widely used open-source software environment for data analysis and statistical graphics in academia and business. It has its own programming language which allows not only interaction with, but also extension of its system. With over 16.000 extensions the statistical and computational toolkit is huge making the R programming language the lingua franca of data science.

In this course you will master the basics of R. You will get to know the syntax, become familiar with the major data types and learn the fundamental programming concepts. You will learn how to perform data processing and analysis tasks, and how to build visualizations and present data. You will also learn how to efficiently automate tasks that are often repeated during data analysis. Moreover, you will learn how to record your work flow and to document your results by using the R environment in combination with the R Studio IDE. 


What students say about this course:
  • The introductory course on programming with R learned us all the relevant programming techniques and got us started to work with R. Therefore, the course was quintessential for all the other courses in the Master.
  • Learning how to code in 7 weeks, what an amazing introduction for the Master!
  • We started with the basics and slowly we became real programmers.



  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Situation dependent parts might be online.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course aims to strengthen your abilities as future managers with one of the most important yet mostly missing skills for managers: the art of programming. Managers with programming experience are able to be involved in the decision-making process of their developers. They can also --at high level-- understand whether or not each developer is performing well. In this course, we will focus on one of the most widely used programming languages: Java. This course also lays the foundation for learning other important programming languages. You should not expect to be developers in few weeks. You should rather treat this course as an intense programming tutorial for absolute beginners. It is assumed that the registered students have no previous knowledge of programming. After taking this course, you will learn how to excel in Java even further or to start learning a new programming language from scratch. Java is greatly structured to be an easy-to-learn, yet a powerful programming language.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The main objective of this course is to develop comprehensive knowledge about the fundamental principles and concepts of modern computer programming. In this course, the students will gain a broad understanding of problem analysis, solution design, coding and debugging of computer programs. In particular, upon completion of the course, it is expected that you will be able to:
  • Translate well specified problems into pseudo-code solutions and then code them in Java
  • Write small programs that allow you to accomplish useful goals
  • Understand the fundamentals of the syntax and semantics of Java programming language.
  • Define the necessary program structure in terms of the basic building blocks (classes, methods and properties)

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In order to get prepared to be real cultural entrepreneurs for the labor market the course is divided in three parts:

(1) Conceptual Development: development of a business plan;
(2) Realization: effectuation of the project; and
(3) Reporting and Evaluation: beyond realization, students will write a critical essay discussing “what happened?", “what I would have done differently?", and “what I learned from this experience?”.

The requirements for this seminar are basic knowledge about culture in general (performing or visual arts), and entrepreneurship.
  Leerdoelen The aim of this seminar is to learn from real life entrepeneurial experiences. Master students will realize an artistic production, a consultancy report or a case study with entrepreneurial aspects within three months. They will act as junior agents, performing as programmers, economists, planners, managers, marketers, auditors, fundraisers, etc. in an entrepreneurial way (with innovative elements) and with a holistic approach. They will develop competencies such as creative and critical thinking, practical (group) working skills, coordinating, collaboration, self-reflection, critical controlling, independent decision making, and performing under stress.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen', 'S.A. Kushner']

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud

The different psychological assessment instruments are important tools to gather information from clients for career advice, ‘diagnosing’ clients, or for companies to hire the best candidates. By using psychological tools, which are designed to be ‘objective and standardized measures of behaviour, affect and cognition’ one can provide recommendations that have the highest likelihood of success. A score on a well-constructed test reflect an underlying psychological construct such as personality, well-being, emotional functioning, aptitude or cognitive ability.
This course deals with both the psychodiagnostic theories as well as the application of the psychological tools and instruments that could be used in different settings including but not limited to clinical and work settings.
 

Leerdoelen

As has been said this course is an introduction to Psychodiagnostics. After completing the course Psychodiagnostics you will have acquired:

  • basic knowledge of how a professional consultation is conducted following the hypothesis-testing model
  • basic knowledge of personality testing, intelligence testing, neuropsychological testing and anamnesis
  • skills in administering, scoring and interpreting some commonly used tests
  • basic skills in anamnestic interviewing
  • an experience in providing feedback to a client about his/her test results

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This elective is aimed at psychology students who would like to learn more about psychology as a science. In this course you will learn how psychological questions can be investigated in a methodologically sound way and how scientific literature can be evaluated. Students learn step-by-step how to get from research question to data collection: which research designs are possible, how to avoid confounds and other interfering factors, which conclusions can and cannot be drawn from data and how to write up research in a clear and scientific way. As part of this course a small experiment will be conducted with the Implicit Association Test, which is often used to investigate stereotyping. Literature on this topic will be used to illustrate research design and the results of the experiment will be the basis of a research report. The structure and content of a research report will be discussed in several tutorial meetings. During practical meetings students will practice with Excel and SPSS and learn how to analyse data and create scientific quality graphs. The statistics covered in this course will overlap with BA1 and BA2, but students will get a deeper and more critical understanding of these topics. At the end of the course students can design, execute, analyze, and report scientific research. In addition, they will be able to critically read scientific articles. The grade for the course will be a combination of the grades for the theoretical exam, practical (open book) exam and the written reports. This elective connects to a special bachelor thesis track in which students perform their own research (under supervision) that will be written up in their bachelor’s thesis.  Leerdoelen Why do you forget someone’s name? Why do people who are in love get butterflies in their stomach? Are boys better in math than girls? Do you really use only 10% of your brain? Psychologists try to answer such questions, but they do not always agree. How do we distinguish chitchat from fact? And how do we acquire those facts?
In this elective students will attend lectures, tutorial group meetings and practicals to learn skills that are needed to understand and conduct scientific studies. They will conduct a small experiment on stereotyping and practice analyzing the results and writing a scientific report of this experiment.
During this course students can also start a supervised research project that will serve as the basis for their bachelor’s thesis. The research project will continue to run parallel to course periods 4 to 6. This special track of the bachelor’s thesis is not mandatory, but highly recommended for students who take this elective.
 
By the end of this course students will be able to:
 
  • Understand experimental and other research designs
  • Set up a simple experiment
  • Collect data
  • Test hypotheses
  • Interpret the results
  • Critically read scientific articles
  • Write a research report
  • Create graphs
  • Find relevant literature
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de samenstelling van de groep.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Door middel van het blok Psychologie van de opleiding Criminologie wordt een inleiding op verschillende perspectieven en thema’s binnen de psychologie gegeven. Daarbij ligt de nadruk op die perspectieven en thema’s die bij uitstek relevant zijn voor de criminologie. Bij de behandeling van deze onderwerpen wordt verwezen naar concrete maatschappelijke problemen en toepassingen in onderzoek. Er wordt in het blok bijvoorbeeld aandacht besteed aan de vraag: hoe kan antisociaal of crimineel gedrag worden verklaard aan de hand van psychologische mechanismen? Daarnaast wordt bekeken hoe psychologische mechanismen andere fenomenen uit de criminologie kunnen verklaren. Leerdoelen Na succesvolle afronding van het blok kun je:
 
  1. Belangrijke begrippen uit de psychologie en haar stromingen en bijbehorende klassieke onderzoeken omschrijven en uitleggen;
  2. Antisociaal gedrag, inclusief criminaliteit, verklaren met behulp van psychologische theorieën;
  3. Criminaliteit gerelateerde onderwerpen en reacties duiden en evalueren met behulp van kennis over de psychologie.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
In this course, we will explore core psychological principles that affect and shape the behaviour and decisions of actors in organizations. We start with a consideration of what guides independent individual choices and behaviour before gradually exploring how the social context and interdependence with other actors shape these factors. In the final part of the course, we consider settings in which teams work cooperatively to solve problems.

To explore these topics, this course relies on a series of interactive plenary sessions paired with a team project and a survey-based personal reflection assignment. During the plenary sessions we will discuss and analyse selected readings, cases, and research findings as well as engage in a variety of in-class exercises. For the team project, you will be tasked with tackling a practical challenge in individuals’ behaviour. And finally, based on peer feedback, you will reflect on your own behaviour in teams and develop concrete ideas to improve your own functioning in future teams. 
​

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The central purpose of this course is to give students insights into how psychological processes shape the behaviour and decisions of individuals acting independently and interdependently in organisations. Specifically, the course covers the following learning goals: 
  1. Knowledge acquisition & comprehension: After following this course, students should be able to recall, explain, and discuss core psychological principles and their effects on organizationally relevant behaviours and decisions. These include selected topics in judgment and decision making, persuasion, negotiation, team composition, team processes, and team effectiveness. 
  2. Practical application & experimentation: After following this course, students should be able to use the aforementioned theories and research findings to critically analyse and design an intervention to a) affect others’ choice behaviours regarding a societally relevant challenge and b) improve their own teamwork.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. B Van den Bergh', 'dr. L van Bunderen, PhD']
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
This course consists of two important domains in psychology as they are relevant for business:

  • human decision-making
  • behaviour in teams

The course is taught as a mixture of interactive lectures, in-class exercises, and workshops that allow students to explore key topics in organizational behaviour, e.g., essential concepts in judgement and decision-making, bias in decision-making, strengths and pitfalls in persuasion, cooperation and conflict, cognition and information processing, and diversity in teams.

Regarding human decision-making we will discuss the assumption of rational decision-making versus biases by normatively irrelevant factors. We will show that other people influence our choices. The course will give you an understanding of the psychology of judgment and decision-making, with the ultimate, overarching goal of making you a better decision-maker. How can you overcome your biases and improve your choices? How can you make sure that you and your collaborators finish your project on time? These are important challenges for anyone’s career, independent of your specific professional goals. Understanding these questions will help you improve your (personal) insights in the process of decision-making.

Regarding behaviour in teams, the course addresses the challenges associated with coordinating the efforts and expertise of different team members who are working towards a common team goal. Furthermore, we will explore different strategies that help teams overcome challenges and pitfalls in team collaboration. Special attention is given to diversity in teams and the impact it can have on team dynamics.

Complementing the lectures, the course includes a number of practical exercises and discussions of real-life cases that will allow you to engage with the course content on a more experiential basis and highlight how the theoretical concepts and models relate to management practice.

This course is worth 4 EC.

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
By the end of the course, students will:
  1. Discuss essential concepts in judgment and decision-making
  2. Use insights from psychology to persuade and resist persuasion
  3. Understand essential concepts in team dynamics
  4. Apply theoretical concepts on real-world situations

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['CA Onrust, MSc', 'G Korkmaz, MSc', 'prof.dr. LR Arends']
text:
Inhoud
Measuring features and skills plays an increasingly important role in everyday life. This course is about measuring in the social sciences. During this course students will discuss the meaning of measurement and how to evaluate the quality of psychological measurements. We emphasize that this course is not only about psychological tests, but includes all kinds of measurements that are used to say something about an underlying construct.
 
During this course, the most important psychometric attributes to be discussed are reliability and validity. These concepts will be explained according to classical test theory and their importance will be discussed in terms of psychological practice as well as scientific research.
 
This course will feature the following topics:
  • importance of psychological measurement
  • scaling
  • individual differences and correlations
  • test dimensionality and factor analysis
  • reliability
  • validity
  • threats to psychometric quality
Leerdoelen This course aims at introducing students to psychometrics and measurement in psychology and pedagogical & educationa sciences. At the end of the course, students will have gained insights into various psychometric attributes, so they will be able to apply these attributes when working with psychological tests and doing psychological or pedagogical research. Finally, once students have completed this course they will master the SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) skills needed to conduct psychometric data analysis.
  Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['CA Onrust, MSc', 'G Korkmaz, MSc', 'prof.dr. LR Arends']
text:
Inhoud
Tijdens dit practicum zullen studenten leren om psychometrische data analyses uit te voeren in SPSS. Tijdens elke sessie zullen oefeningen worden doorlopen met betrekking tot bijv. gestandaardiseerde en genormaliseerde scores, betrouwbaarheid van een vragenlijst, factor analyse en het onderzoeken van test bias.
Ook zullen studenten in dit practicum werken aan 7 individuele praktijkopdrachten. Elke praktijkopdracht bevat o.a. vragen waarvoor een bepaalde SPSS procedure moet zijn doorlopen. De 7 praktijkopdrachten samen vormen het practicumverslag.
Leerdoelen
Het doel van dit practicum is de studenten bekend te maken met de SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) vaardigheden die nodig zijn voor het uitvoeren van psychometrische data analyses.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['CA Onrust, MSc', 'G Korkmaz, MSc', 'prof.dr. LR Arends']
text:
Inhoud
Het meten van kenmerken en vaardigheden speelt een grote rol in het dagelijks leven. Tijdens dit blok zal het meten binnen de sociale wetenschappen worden behandeld. De studenten zullen bespreken wat de betekenis is van meten en hoe de kwaliteit van psychologische metingen geëvalueerd moet worden. We benadrukken dat het in dit blok niet alleen om psychologische tests gaat, maar om alle soorten tests die gebruikt worden om iets te kunnen zeggen over een onderliggend construct. 
Tijdens dit blok zullen de psychometrische eigenschappen betrouwbaarheid en validiteit centraal staan. Deze concepten zullen behandeld worden aan de hand van de klassieke testtheorie en het belang ervan bediscussieerd in het kader van zowel de pedagogische praktijk als wetenschappelijk onderzoek. 
In dit blok komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:
  • het belang van psychologische metingen
  • het schalen van scores
  • individuele verschillen en correlaties
  • test dimensionaliteit en factor analyse
  • betrouwbaarheid
  • validiteit
  • uitdagingen van psychometrische kwaliteit
Leerdoelen
Het doel van dit blok is een introductie te bieden in de psychometrie en metingen binnen de psychologie, de pedagogische en onderwijswetenschappen. Aan de het einde van deze cursus zijn studenten in staat om:
  • op basis van inhoudelijke en statistische informatie duiding te geven aan de validiteit en betrouwbaarheid van toetsen/vragenlijsten (eindterm 6; eindterm 8; eindterm 9; eindterm 14);
  • de principes van klassieke testtheorie te beschrijven, en deze te relateren aan de begrippen betrouwbaarheid en validiteit (eindterm 6; eindterm 14);
  • de voorspellende waarde van toetsscores te berekenen en te bezien vanuit de wetenschappelijke beperkingen die eraan verbonden zijn (eindterm 6; eindterm 14).

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
In deze cursus passeren verschillende vormen van psychopathologie de revue, die ontstaan of aan het licht komen in de kindertijd en adolescentie. Voorbeelden hiervan zijn pervasieve ontwikkelingsstoornissen (bijv. autisme en desintegratie stoornis), aandachtstekort en gedragsstoornissen en de oppositioneel opstandige gedragsstoornis. Om het ontstaan en voortbestaan van zulke stoornissen, evenals de behandelmogelijkheden te kunnen begrijpen, is kennis van de normatieve en de abnormale ontwikkeling nodig. In dit blok integreren we daarom kennis van hersenontwikkeling, ontwikkelingspsychologie, cognitieve psychologie en klinische kinder- en jeugdpsychologie.

Het blok is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).
Leerdoelen
De nadruk van dit blok ligt op (de ontwikkeling van) psychische en gedragsproblemen in de kindertijd en de adolescentie. Daartoe richt de cursus zich zowel op de normale als abnormale ontwikkeling.

course_title: Psychosociale aspecten in de pallatieve zorg
college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['A.P. Heikema', 'D. Van Aalst', 'dr. F.L. van Vliet', 'W.M. Bramer']

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud International public opinions matter more and more. In order to influence them, nations, but also international organizations such as NGOs or IGOs must develop public relations campaigns in coordination with their policies. Confronted with a growing number of new media that allow anyone to speak their mind globally, the United States is perfecting the concept of Public Diplomacy, in order to "Tell America's story". The U.S. is not alone to practice Public Diplomacy; a number of countries are also developing strategic communication campaigns in order to win the global battle of public opinion. In this course, students will explore the importance of public opinions in international relations. Techniques of strategic communication will be discussed and analyzed along with case studies on today's Public Diplomacy. Students will regularly meet practitioners in Public diplomacy. For that reason, a reasonable level of professionalism and flexibility will be required. Leerdoelen Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
  • Major perspectives on Public Diplomacy and its affiliates like Cultural Diplomacy, Nation Branding and Soft Power;
  • Role and importance of public opinions and strategic communication campaigns in international relations.
Students have developed the ability to:
  • Critically review current research on Public Diplomacy;
  • Apply theoretical concepts to real-life cases in Public Diplomacy;
  • Analyze and reflect on the use and impact of strategic communication campaigns in international relations.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['CC Luijten', 'dr. J Oude Groeniger', 'dr. KJ Grit', 'dr. MD Hilverda', 'dr. MPB van den Broek', 'prof.dr. AP Nieboer']
text:
Inhoud De minor Public Health is opgebouwd uit modules, die belangrijke probleemterreinen behandelen. Deze probleemterreinen zijn: infectieziekten, milieuzorg, geestelijke gezondheidszorg, jeugdzorg en zorg voor ouderen. Binnen elke module komen verschillende docenten aan het woord, waarvan een aantal werkzaam is in de dagelijkse praktijk in de grote stad, waardoor de diversiteit van de grootstedelijke problematiek duidelijk wordt.
Voorafgaand hieraan is er een introductieweek, waarin een algemeen beeld wordt geschetst van grootstedelijke gezondheidsproblemen en de aanpak hiervan en waarin de opzet van de minor nader wordt toegelicht.
 
Module Infectieziekten
De bestrijding van infectieziekten vormt de oorsprong van de huidige Public Health. Infectieziekten vormen historisch gezien een van de belangrijkste gezondheidsproblemen in de grote stad. Zij behoren wereldwijd nog steeds tot de grootste doodsoorzaken en ook in het westen is het probleem nog niet uitgeroeid. Vanwege hun besmettelijke karakter hebben de infectieziekten ook een belangrijke maatschappelijke dimensie.
Na een historisch overzicht worden de medische grondbeginselen van infectieziekten bestrijding uitgelegd. De omvang van de belangrijkste infectieziekten in Nederland wordt beschreven. Het gedrag van mensen als leden van een samenleving heeft grote invloed op infecties en wordt besproken. De belangrijkste soorten interventies en uitvoeringsaspecten worden gepresenteerd.
 
Module Milieu
Milieu als fysieke leefomgeving – denk aan zaken zoals luchtkwaliteit, water, verkeer, groen, geluid, hoogspanningsmasten, bodemverontreiniging – vormt het onderwerp van de tweede module. Zowel het publiek, de politiek als de gezondheidsdiensten maken zich regelmatig ‘druk’ om dergelijke milieu gerelateerde onderwerpen. Voorbeeld is het thema ‘fijnstof’. In deze module wordt uitgelegd hoe blootstellingen gedefinieerd en gemeten kunnen worden en hoe maatregelen worden ontworpen en geëvalueerd.
 
Module Openbare geestelijke gezondheidszorg
De Openbare Geestelijke Gezondheidszorg betreft de preventie op het gebied van de geestelijke gezondheid van kwetsbare personen en risicogroepen. Het gaat daarbij vaak om zorg voor mensen die niet voor zichzelf kunnen zorgen, bemoeizorg genoemd. Daarbij komt het spanningsveld tussen maatschappelijke dwangmaatregelen en individuele vrijheden aan de orde. Klassieke terreinen van de OGGZ zijn de zorg voor verslaafden en aan dak- en thuislozen. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan andere speerpunten op het gebied van geestelijke gezondheid: problematiek die veel minder zichtbaar is zoals depressie en angststoornissen en gevoelens van onveiligheid, vaak gerelateerd aan problemen zoals agressie en geweld.
Module Jeugd
Nederland vergrijst, maar in de grote steden is het aantal kinderen en jongeren voorlopig nog relatief groot. Ongeveer de helft van de jongeren in de steden heeft een buitenlandse herkomst. De gemengde groep kinderen en jongeren in de grote steden vormt enerzijds een bron voor de toekomstige welvaart, maar is voor het algemene publiek en voor de politiek ook een bron van zorg. Er zijn grote sociale-, en gezondheidsverschillen tussen groepen jongeren in de steden. In de minor komen zaken aan bod zoals de aanpak van kindermishandeling en de epidemie van overgewicht bij kinderen.
 
Module Ouderen
Het verouderingsproces leidt tot toenemende kwetsbaarheid door een samenspel van slechte mobiliteit, balans en spierkracht; verminderde cognitie en (dreigende) ondervoeding. Daarnaast is eenzaamheid een belangrijk probleem. De kansen en belemmeringen (van programma’s gericht) op ‘healthy ageing’ zullen aan bod komen tijdens deze module. Er wordt aandacht gegeven aan de belangrijke gezondheidsproblemen onder ouderen, zoals dementie. Daarnaast wordt een overzicht gegeven van de gezondheid van ouderen met een migratie achtergrond.


  Leerdoelen De minor Public Health richt zich op gezondheidsproblematiek, die typisch is voor grote steden zoals Rotterdam. Aan de hand van interactief onderwijs en interessante praktijkexcursies leer je de basisprincipes van het vakgebied Public Health. Aan de hand van casussen kom je veel te weten over recente ontwikkelingen op dit gebied en leer je om publieke gezondheidsproblemen zelfstandig te analyseren en erover te adviseren.
De overkoepelende leerdoelen zijn:
1. De student kan de basisprincipes en recente ontwikkelingen van de geselecteerde onderzoeksterreinen in de publieke gezondheid (Public Health) omschrijven.
2. De student kan zelfstandig een probleemgestuurde analyse van gezondheidsproblemen van de grootstedelijke bevolking toepassen.
 
Daarnaast zijn er per module de volgende leerdoelen:
Module infectieziekten
3. De student kan de stappen van planmatige aanpak voor bestrijding van infectieziekten omschrijven en toepassen op een specifieke casus over infectieziekten.
4. De student kan de belangrijkste soorten interventies ter bestrijding van infectieziekten benoemen.
5. De student kan bevorderende en belemmerende factoren voor een succesvolle implementatie benoemen en toepassen op een casus/interventie.
 
Module Milieu
6. De student kan omschrijven wat de invloed is van milieu op de volksgezondheid en hoe dit gemeten kan worden.
7. De student kan omschrijven hoe milieu-interventies worden ontwikkeld en worden beoordeeld op hun effectiviteit.
 
Module OGGZ
8. De student kan specifieke dilemma’s benoemen die spelen bij oplossingen voor problemen binnen de Openbare Geestelijke Gezondheid.
9. De student kan aan de hand van een specifieke casus verklaren en analyseren waarom een bepaalde aanpak voor een beleidsprobleem effectief is of niet.
 
Module Jeugd
10. De student kan de specifieke problemen bij de zorg voor de jeugd omschrijven.
11. De student kan aan de hand van een casus specifieke dilemma’s herkennen en benoemen waarmee zorgverleners in de praktijk mee te maken hebben.
12. De student heeft inzicht in effectieve beleidsinterventies in de zorg voor jeugd en kan deze toepassen op een casus.
 
Module Ouderen
13. De student kan de specifieke problemen benoemen die kunnen spelen bij de zorg voor ouderen.
14. De student kan voorbeelden noemen van effectieve interventies en kan aangeven wat de factoren zijn die de effectiviteit bevorderen/belemmeren.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. B Wouterse', 'J Stöckel, MSc', 'M Bar', 'prof.dr. PHM van Baal']
text:
Inhoud This course is about the interaction between public health, economics, and public health policy. Good health policies are impossible to formulate without some understanding of the relation between public health policies, individual behavior and population health. In this course students will be taught how to apply statistical methods and economic theory to questions such as: “How should we measure and summarize population health?”, “How do increases in (healthy) life expectancy influence health care spending and pension entitlements?”, “What is the impact of medical care on population health and what is the relevance thereof for cost effectiveness?”, and “What are economic arguments for and against public health policies?”.

The first 3 meetings will be spent on the measurement of population health. The lifetable approach developed in these first meetings is crucial for the rest of the course. In the meetings thereafter, these measures of population health will be linked to redistributions of wealth within populations, determinants and cost effectiveness analysis. Meetings 7, 8 and 9 each deal with a different case study on public health policy: obesity, infectious diseases and cancer screening.

Structure
This course consists of lecture and interactive workgroups. The lectures are a combination of online material (papers, videos and homework) and live Q&A sessions in which students can discuss the material and homework. During the work groups students work together in small groups on an in-depth case related to the course material.

Prior knowledge
The following courses from the HEPL/HE programme are necessary prerequisites as a lot of knowledge gathered in these courses will be integrated in this course around the topic of public health:
  • Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics (previously known as Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics)
  • Economics and Financing of Health Care Systems
  • Economics of Health and Health Care
  • Health Technology Assessment
Required computer skills:
  • Stata/SPSS or other similar statistical software
  • Microsoft Excel
Leerdoelen After following this course, students will be able to:
  • calculate various summary measures of population health, explain the differences between these methods, and interpret variation (across group or over time) in these measures;
  • construct simple models based on the life table to answer questions relevant for public health policy;
  • interpret empirical research within the domain of public health economics;
  • apply a welfare economic framework to policy interventions in the field of public health and use this framework to make policy recommendations

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud The purpose of this course will be on the one hand to introduce students to main concepts of contemporary international law, such as sources and subjects of international law, sovereignty and international responsibility; and on the other hand to explore how we are governed globally by looking at ideas, legal doctrines, institutional and administrative structures developed over the last century to organize and legalize international economic and political life. The readings will focus on various ways to think about the legal organization of global order, and on the history of legal efforts to organize and institutionalize international affairs.
  Leerdoelen (a) Critical Outcomes:
The course will contribute to the student attaining the following critical outcomes:
  • Collecting, analysing, organizing and critically evaluating information conveyed during lectures and further analyzed in the Tutorials;
  • Identifying and solving legal practical problems;
  • Demonstrating an understanding of the world as a set of related systems;
  • Successfully completing given tasks without supervision;
(b) Specific outcomes
Students successfully completing this course should be able to:
  • Understand and appreciate the nature of the international system, how it is organized and how it works
  • Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the key legal regimes operating in the international realm
  • Demonstrate the ability to identify various factors and forces that shape the contemporary international community and how problem-solving contexts are interrelated
  • Apply the knowledge gained from this cause to solve contemporary international problems

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. F Violi', 'mr. C Mannee', 'mr. L Said', 'mr. RM Klein Entink', 'N Pouls, LL.M', 'prof.dr. E Hey', 'prof.dr. R Repasi', 'R de Geus, LL.M', 'S Paulini']
text:
Inhoud The Bachelor 3 course in Public International Law builds on the Bachelor 1 mandatory introductory course, Introduction to International and European Law. The focus of the Public International Law course, which is instructed in English, falls on the structure of international law, how that structure manifests itself in particular core regimes of international law such as the law of treaties, the law of state responsibility, the law on the use of force, human rights law, law of immunities, international criminal law, international economic law and dispute settlement – and also, briefly, how the structure of the international legal order is changing, and why. Leerdoelen Doel/Purpose:
 
After following this course, students will be able to:
 
  1. Draw connections between the different fields of public international law and explain how the subjects are related to each other and how they fit in the (fragmented) system of international law (problem 8);
  2. Explain the terms ‘primary’ and ‘secondary’ rules of international law and distinguish between them in order to obtain a better grasp on the structure of international law;
  3. Examine and apply the secondary rules of state responsibility in order to solve case-studies in which primary rules of public international law have been violated (problem 1);
  4. Examine and apply the secondary rules of the law of treaties and their bearing on the application and interpretation of primary rules of public international law (problems 2 and 3);
  5. Describe how international dispute settlement works in the international legal order, and explain the different methods of dispute settlement in public international law (judicial means, diplomatic means and UN collective security). Students will be able to connect the phenomenon of proliferation of courts and tribunals to the myriad of dispute settlement mechanisms available under international law (lecture 2);
  6. Analyze the law of the use of force (and the threat of the use of force), including recent developments (especially since the 2000s) and explain how it relates to dispute settlement methods within the framework of the United Nations (lecture 2  and 3 and problem 4);
  7. Analyze the regime of international human rights law and contrast the different human rights instruments and enforcement mechanisms (problem 5);
  8. Analyze the law of immunity in terms of the differences and linkages between two types of immunity, namely: state immunity and immunity of high-ranking state officials (problem 6);
  9. Describe the role of international organisations (IOs) as actors at the international level and the impact of their activities on individuals and groups in society (lecture 4);
  10. Solve case-studies using the rules of international criminal law (problem 7);
  11. Analyze the existing institutional framework of international economic law and some of its problematic dimensions
  12. Analyze international case law and, on this basis, form and give an independent opinion regarding the legal merits of individual cases;
  13. Examine opinions and comments of commentators concerning various topics of the course.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. F Violi', 'mr. C Mannee', 'mr. L Said', 'mr. RM Klein Entink', 'N Pouls, LL.M', 'prof.dr. E Hey', 'prof.dr. R Repasi', 'R de Geus, LL.M', 'S Paulini']
text:

  12. Analyze international case law and, on this basis, form and give an independent opinion regarding the legal merits of individual cases;
  13. Examine opinions and comments of commentators concerning various topics of the course.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['E Kappenberg', 'EA van Gemert, MSc', 'prof.dr. W Schinkel']
text:
Inhoud Public issues are issues of public contestation whose formation often coincides with the formation of previously non-existent publics. This introductory core course studies the historical, geographical, socio-political and socio-technical aspects of such issues. We ask how issues are publicly imagined, and by which technological mediations and infrastructure this occurs. We also focus on the ways issues are intertwined with (potential) publics. This requires also that we investigate contemporary conceptions of the public sphere in an interdisciplinary way. In order to do so, you are made familiar with a number of key contemporary public issues, such as: climate change, racism, smart urban technologies, global drone warfare, sexism and contemporary neoliberal capitalism and the precarization of life.
These issues are analyzed by means of a conceptual vocabulary that centers on the social and material infrastructures (policy and politics, media, the internet, energy supply lines etc.) that underlie many public issues; the social imaginaries through which public issues come into being; the identities at stake in public issues; the interfaces that allow people to engage with such issues; and the investments and interests that are entangled with them. By means of this conceptual vocabulary, the course seeks to highlight the importance of composition in making things public, and to move from ‘the public’ and ‘the public sphere’ to the ongoing and uncertain constitution of a plurality of publics (policy makers are one particular public, or they can be part of publics). Publics, in other words, are composed out of a variety of people and things.
The course provides room for the development of your own engagement with public life and allows you to experiment with ways of unpacking the complexities of a public issue of your choosing in a paper.
  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will:
 
1. have insight into the main sociological theories and analyses of the contemporary public sphere
2. be familiar with cutting edge sociological approaches to the ways publics and issues emerge
3. be able to apply these approaches to a variety of current public issues
4. be able to write an academic paper on a current public issue and analyze it in sociological terms

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course brings together state-of-the-art theories on public knowledge, in-depth analyses of knowledge circulation in public issues, and exciting field experiments with inventive methods. The aim of this course is to develop your critical understanding of what knowledge can do in public issues. By studying exemplary cases and experimenting with methods, you will learn how research can itself be an intervention in and engagement with public issues.
As a start, you will become more familiar with a set of concepts and approaches that will allow you to analyze what knowledge can do. You will learn how methods, research and knowledge are performative: they do not disinterestedly describe but actively compose our common worlds and the issues through which we engage with it.
On this basis, you will be performing your own attempts at (re-)composing a public issue through social scientific research methods. Throughout the course you will be testing materials and methods as ways to intervene in public issues.
This course is expressly aimed at preparing you for your thesis trajectory. You’ll deepen your understanding of research methods, while also developing an initial mapping of the topic and field that you have chosen for your thesis. The final assignment of the course consists of a field exploration report that will become your launching pad into your master’s thesis research.
  Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will:
 
1. be familiar with the main cutting edge sociological theories and analyses of knowledge and expertise
2. be familiar with the different modalities of public intervention
3. be able to make a sociological analysis of the ways knowledge figures in the staging of public interventions
4. be able to judge the performative role of knowledge claims in the public sphere
5. be able to set up and conduct a study of a public knowledge controversy

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. AM Kanas', 'dr. W Belabas', 'IM Duivenman, BA', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']
text:
Inhoud Hoe en waarom wordt een probleem een ‘beleidsprobleem’? Wat is beleid, en hoe wordt het ontwikkeld? Wie neemt er besluiten over beleid? Hoe kun je zorgen dat beleid ook echt wordt uitgevoerd? En op welke wijze kun je bepalen of beleid succesvol is geweest, of niet?

Deze vragen staan centraal in de cursus ‘Beleid’. De cursus laat studenten kennismaken met de ‘beleidscyclus’ en leert de student vanuit meerdere perspectieven (rationeel, politiek, cultureel en institutioneel perspectief) een analyse te maken van beleidsprocessen. Op deze wijze krijgt de student inzicht in de meervoudigheid van beleidsprocessen waarin kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties een rol spelen.

Ideaaltypisch worden maatschappelijke problemen geagendeerd (agendavorming), waarna politici doelen stellen en beleidsambtenaren bij deze doelen instrumenten selecteren (beleidsvorming en -besluitvorming), en uitvoerders deze instrumenten toepassen (beleidsimplementatie). Vervolgens wordt in de fasen toezicht, handhaving en evaluatie gecontroleerd of het beleid conform de intentie van beleidsmakers is uitgevoerd, respectievelijk of met het beleid het achterliggende maatschappelijke vraagstuk is opgelost. Tevens wordt aandacht besteed aan de factoren die ten grondslag liggen aan beleidsverandering.

Gedurende de cursus zullen de perspectieven op de beleidscyclus worden toegepast op diverse maatschappelijke problemen. Dit zal bijdragen aan een beter begrip van de weerbarstigheid en complexiteit van hoe beleidsprocessen in de realiteit plaatsvinden Leerdoelen Na afloop van het vak kan de student:
  • de assumpties en kernelementen van het rationele, politieke, culturele en institutionele perspectief op beleidsprocessen benoemen;
  • een analyse maken van de rol van kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties in beleidsprocessen
  • de verschillende fasen van de beleidscyclus herkennen en toepassen op concrete maatschappelijke problemen;
  • een analyse maken van hoe en waarom beleidsproblemen op de maatschappelijke, politieke en beleidsagenda komen, of waarom agendavorming juist wordt voorkomen
  • een analyse maken van processen van beleidsvorming en besluitvorming rond een concreet beleidsprobleem
  • een analyse maken van hoe beleid wordt uitgevoerd, met aandacht voor aspecten van implementatie, toezicht en handhaving
  • een analyse maken van hoe de effecten van beleid kunnen worden bepaald (beleidsevaluatie) en welke factoren een verklaring bieden voor beleidsverandering.
  • strategisch adviseren aan beleidsactoren die een lobby strategie willen ontwikkelingen in het kader van beleidsprocessen
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud It is often (if not always) not what we communicate but how we communicate. Getting our message across (especially verbally, when having merely a limited amount of time), within the context of a highly internationalized (business) world, can be a cumbersome task from a personal or organizational perspective. Humans make a business run. Personal development (in this case learning ‘to speak out loud’), theoretical knowledge and practical skills as such, are essential aspects nowadays. Having an interview for a new job, speaking ‘out loud’, presenting or pitching in front of the class or in a future work-setting, and even ‘worse’, speaking in front of a group of people on a set ’stage’ or even in the board room during company meetings, can be very challenging. Not possessing public speaking skills (theory, strategy and practice) can nowadays truly make or break someone’s career (prospects) and can cause serious, unnecessary anxiety issues, not to mention hinder the ‘sales of knowledge, service or product’ with (personal, social, economic, stakeholder relation etc.) consequences to follow....
 
Public Speaking essentials, involve verbal and written storytelling and communication theories and practices; pitching/presentation training; all in all, based on the understanding and practice of effective verbal, written and body language strategies within a 21st century international business context. Several scientific fields / studies and work field practices are relevant in this case. To name a few: Leadership-, Management-, Organizational-, Entrepreneurial studies, Sociology, (Positive) Psychology and of course Communication sciences. This seminar is a strategy and implementation oriented ‘training’ with relevant and specifically selected theory as an additional solid backbone to accommodate university students in their next step towards ‘real life scenarios’.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • What we can consider public speaking (types)
  • Why public speaking is essential in a globalized 21st century (individual and business) context
  • What characteristics of verbal (and written) communication we can consider important when willing to be effective communicators
  • The difference between public speaking and storytelling
  • The importance of storytelling and other verbal, written and body language methods in public speaking
  • Why cultural differences matter in public speaking
  • The practice of public speaking: How to effectively speak in public
 
Students have developed the skills to:
  • To understand the difference between effective and less effective public speaking
  • To use storytelling in public speaking
  • To implement other, verbal, written and body language methods in public speaking
  • To be confident when speaking in front of a smaller or larger group of (multi-cultural) individuals
  • To be able to identify personal setbacks, fears and other blockages and potentially how to mitigate those to be effective in public speaking
  • How to communicate a properly structured text in public speaking (writing and by heart)
  • To evaluate the (inter-cultural) context within which public speaking takes place
  • To evaluate and learn from other public speakers

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Publiek management is het managen van publieke organisaties. Het gaat dan om twee soorten management. Ten eerste, het interne management ofwel de bedrijfsvoering van publieke organisaties. Dat betreft zaken zoals organisatiestructuren en -typen, personeel, financiën, communicatie, ICT, strategie en bedrijfsvoeringtechnieken. Ten tweede, het externe management ofwel het aangaan en onderhouden van contacten met tal van stakeholders, burgers en de politiek.
In dit vak gaan we in op beide soorten management in een serie colleges, kennisclips en praktische voorbeelden. De opgedane kennis wordt getoetst in een schriftelijk tentamen en toegepast in een groepsopdracht over een echte publieke organisatie. Daarbij kijken we niet alleen naar de overheid in enge zin, maar naar de publieke sector in de volle breedte.
  Leerdoelen Aan het eind van deze cursus is de student in staat om:
  • Verschillende onderdelen en vormen van publiek management te benoemen en in eigen woorden uit te leggen;
  • Organisatiestructuren en -typen te herkennen en de voor- en nadelen ervan te benoemen
  • Verschillende stadia van strategievorming te herkennen en adviezen te formuleren over de toepassing ervan door publieke organisaties;
  • Meerdere bedrijfsvoeringtechnieken te benoemen en de toepassing ervan te beoordelen of daarover te adviseren aan publieke organisaties;
  • Meerdere methoden voor extern management te benoemen, te herkennen in de praktijk en de voor- en nadelen ervan te benoemen;
  • Te adviseren aan publieke organisaties over het aangaan en onderhouden van contacten met stakeholders, burgers en de politiek; en
  • Kritisch te reflecteren op het managen van publieke organisaties en theorieën of modellen daarover.
Belangrijk om te weten Studenten worden geacht in groepen een analyse te maken van de inhoud en het functioneren van een strategisch plan van een door hen te kiezen publieke organisatie

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Leiderschap is een ‘hot’ onderwerp, waarover tal van wetenschappelijke en niet-wetenschappelijke publicaties verschijnen. Ook binnen de bestuurskunde is veel aandacht voor het thema waarbij wordt beargumenteerd dat de positie en rol van publieke managers door allerlei (externe) ontwikkelingen is veranderd.

De module begint met een inleiding over leiderschapstheorie waarna vervolgens wordt ingezoomd op het effect van de publieke context op leiderschap. Aan de hand van het boek van 't Hart zal vervolgens nader worden ingegaan op de uitdagingen en paradoxen waarmee publiek leiderschap heden ten dage wordt geconfronteerd. Complexity leadership theory zal daarbij worden behandeld als een relevante moderne theorie om de huidige ontwikkelingen beter te begrijpen.

  Leerdoelen Deze module kent de volgende leerdoelen. Na afloop van de module, kan de student:
  • De verschillende theorieën over leiderschap uiteenzetten en met elkaar vergelijken;
  • Beredeneren welke consequenties een publieke context heeft voor het geven van leiding;
  • Uitleggen op welke wijze de rol van publieke managers de afgelopen decennia is veranderd;
  • Algemene leiderschapstheorie toepassen op publieke managers;
  • onderzoek op dit terrein beoordelen op wetenschappelijke kwaliteit en toepasbaarheid voor de praktijk.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AG Nikulina', 'dr. LSG Ried, MSc', 'FZ Chen, MSc', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In its very essence, purchasing involves everything one receives an invoice for. But what is the more substantive definition of this business process, particularly from a management point of view? Over the years, numerous definitions have been provided for Purchasing and Supply Management (PSM). In broad strokes, one could depict the development of definitions over time as moving from more operational, to tactical, to more strategic. We define PSM as “The design, initiation, control and evaluation of activities within and between organisations aimed at securing inputs from suppliers at the most favourable conditions.” (Van Raaij, 2016; Wynstra, 2006). 

Central in any definition of purchasing and supply management is the process (at least as final objective) of acquiring inputs. As such, the economic transactions between actors are at the heart of purchasing and supply management. This is also the core difference with logistics or supply chain management, which focus on planning and controlling the amounts, routes and timing of flows of goods and services and associated information. 

As a management activity, purchasing and supply has a quite rich history. In the 18th century, the United East India Company (in Dutch: Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) already conducted make-or-buy analyses. While at a general level, the principles of purchasing and supply management may thus have remained largely the same, there are some particular areas of development in the last decade or so. 

There is a growing realization that purchasing and supply management can contribute not only to the ‘bottom-line’ of organisations, but also to the ‘top-line’. In other words, the buying organisation does not only seek to reduce costs but also to increase the revenue-generating potential of the acquired inputs.  Another development is that organisations place growing emphasis on strategy development at the level of so-called purchasing ‘categories’. More and more organisations apply an explicit approach to segmenting their spend in terms of characteristics such as financial importance and supply or technological risks, and apply explicitly differentiated strategies for the different segments. 

Last, but not least, PSM is changing due to the increasing digitalization. Digital procurement, or Procurement 4.0, brings new opportunities to the organisations, such as streamlined and simplified processes, data-driven purchasing decisions, and overall increased time for strategic activities. However, it also brings challenges: a complicated task to develop a suitable digital PSM strategy and choose appropriate IT solutions, but above all the need to rethink roles and skills of PSM professionals. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The objective of this core course is to provide students with the key concepts regarding purchasing and supply management. This course will cover the whole purchasing cycle, including strategic, tactical, and operational purchasing activities. Upon completing this course, students can: 
  • Explain the role of purchasing and supply management in the value chain; 
  • Analyse the relationships between buyers and supplier in a supply chain; 
  • Compare and apply different outsourcing and purchasing (category) strategies; 
  • Identify alternative approaches to enhance the sustainability of supplier relationships; 
  • Select appropriate types of contracts and justify their applicability; 
  • Define and apply supplier selection criteria and negotiation strategies; 
  • Identify and apply supplier development actions; 
  • Explain the importance of the effective an efficient organization of  operational purchasing process for organizations; 
  • Select effective organizational forms and performance indicators for purchasing given the business context.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

The content of each lecture is chosen one month in advance. It will always a mathematical topic of interest and its applications.
 

Leerdoelen

Q.E.D. or QED is an abbreviation for the Latin phrase "quod erat demonstrandum" ("that which was to be demonstrated"), a notation which is often placed at the end of a mathematical proof to indicate its completion.

The QED lecture series are extracurricular lectures. Needless to say, extracurricular means that presence is not required; these lectures are organized for all impatient students who do not want to wait too long to see how all mathematics you learn is used in practice, and for those students who are eager to know a bit more than the material which is strictly needed for the exams. The lectures will be in English but provided for all first-year Econometric students.

Each month there will be a lecture of one hour organized on a mathematical topic, given by my former colleague, dr. Jan Brinkhuis.  

Kind regards,

the organizers,

Jan Brinkhuis & Emö Oldenkamp

course_title: Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA): A set-analytic approach to studying organizational configurations
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course is structured in six sessions. In Session 1, you will learn about the history of QCA and its introduction and diffusion in management research. We will discuss the conceptual background of QCA and become familiar with QCA as an analytical approach. A hands-on tutorial during the Session will help illustrate the core methodological principles of QCA. In Session 2, we will situate QCA in the broader landscape of qualitative research methods, focusing on logics of case selection and research designs for inductive and deductive research. In Session 2 you will also have the opportunity to reflect upon your own research and current and alternative research designs to address your research questions. In Session 3, you will become familiar with the traditional, small-N QCA research approach, focusing on motivating a configurational study (conceptual background), central aspects in implementing a QCA analysis (calibration, model coefficients, etc.), and the importance of post-QCA case analysis. For so doing, we will draw on small-N QCA studies published in top management journals. In Session 4, we will focus on large-N QCA, a more recent and less formalized research approach in QCA. Again, drawing on QCA studies published in top management journals, we will contrast state-of-the art applications of large-N QCA vis-à-vis small-N studies. In Session 5, we will examine configurational research across the management literature (e.g., strategy, org theory, innovation, OB, HRM, entrepreneurship, etc.) focusing primarily on your research fields. Additionally, based on the material covered in Sessions 2-4, you will outline, and receive feedback, on a possible configurational research designs for your own research. In Session 6, we will cover recent and advanced topics in QCA, including for example longitudinal QCA, multi-level QCA, QCA in mixed-methods studies. 

This course is taught by Dr Johannes Meuer (Kühne Logistics Universityh). Leerdoelen After the course, you should be 
  1. Familiar with the history of QCA and its introduction and diffusion in management studies
  2. Understand the logic of set-analytic methods
  3. Able to distinguish different approaches to case selection and how they lead to QCA
  4. Develop a configurational research design for your own research field
  5. Able to explain the difference between small-N and large-N approaches to QCA
  6. Familiar with current advanced topics in QCA

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. J Gaybor', 'prof.dr. AI Chib', 'prof.dr. S Lwasa']

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. JFA Braster', 'dr. W Belabas', 'RA Goverts, MSc']
text:
Inhoud Deze module bouwt voort op de module ‘Ontwerpen van Sociaal Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek’ waarin studenten kennis hebben gemaakt met methoden en technieken van bestuurskundig en sociologisch onderzoek. Het vak bestaat uit hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. De module geeft studenten inzicht in het gebruik, de mogelijkheden en de beperkingen van kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden. Studenten verwerven kennis over het verrichten van kwalitatief onderzoek, en zij oefenen met diverse onderzoeksmethoden in de werkgroepen. Behandeld worden onder meer het opzetten van een goed onderzoeksdesign; de keuze voor en gebruikmaking van bronnen en methoden zoals interviews, audiovisuele data en digitale bronnen; dataverzameling, analyse en codering van het empirische materiaal en de rol daarbij van hulpmiddelen zoals memo’s, kwalitatieve datamatrices en computerprogramma’s zoals Atlas.ti. Leerdoelen Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
  • de keuze voor kwalitatief onderzoek onderbouwen op basis van wetenschapsfilosofische en methodologische overwegingen;
  • de sterkten en zwakten benoemen van een breed scala aan kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden;
  • alle stappen noemen die gezet moeten worden bij het maken van een onderzoeksopzet;
  • beredeneren welke kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethode het beste past bij een gegeven probleemstelling;
  • systematisch data verzamelen (o.a. interviews of geschreven bronnen)
  • verschillende kwalitatieve analysetechnieken toepassen;
  • de structuur en criteria van een onderzoeksrapportage benoemen.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The following topics are covered in this course in 4 consecutive weeks: (1a) qualitative “versus” quantitative research; (1b) measurement and operationalization in qualitative research settings; (2a) data collection: interviews, participant observation, textual documents, unobtrusive data, and visual materials; (2b) data analysis: data reduction, causal inference, and qualitative data analysis software (NVivo, Atlas.ti, fs/QCA, et cetera); (3a) ethnography; (3b) grounded theory methods; (4a) case study methods; and (4b) content analytical methods and discourse analysis.
Leerdoelen

The goal of this course is to equip students with the intellectual baggage necessary for the design, execution, and publication of truly excellent qualitative research studies. The emphasis in this course will be on getting acquainted with: (a) the canonical steps of the qualitative research process in general, and (b) four exemplary qualitative research designs in particular.
Central to this course is that students acquire an advanced understanding of the qualitative research process in general, and of several commonly used qualitative research designs in particular. Students are also expected to get acquainted with and learn how to use qualitative data analysis programs, such as NVivo, Atlas.ti, DICTION, fs/QCA, or MAXQDA.

course_title: Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['C Modugno, MSc', 'dr. AM Diallo', 'dr. AMM Hermans', 'dr. CE Aalberts', 'dr. DD Dumitrica', 'dr. G Evolvi', 'dr. JF Pereira Campos', 'dr. JH Pridmore', 'G Bidassi, MA', 'JR van Keulen, MA', 'LSJ Sasse', 'Q Huang']
text:
Inhoud In order to understand, analyze and make sense of diverse changes in the social world, research is paramount. This course aims to provide theoretical and applied knowledge in the different methods of qualitative social scientific research and an understanding of how to analyse and interpret the data gathered through these methods. This course first focuses on methods of qualitative data collection (e.g., focus groups, interviews, observation) and then on different forms of qualitative data analysis and interpretation. Within a qualitative tradition students will increase their skills in developing a comprehensive qualitative research plan and should be able to critically assess the methodological approaches of published qualitative research. The focus within this course is on developing students’ abilities to design their own research using qualitative methods for use in their future research courses and thesis development.
 
Note: Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • How and when to use common qualitative research methods in the field of media and communication;
  • The benefits and challenges of these methods;
  • How to develop a research design and how to collect and analyze qualitative data.
  • An understanding of the relationship between theory, methodology and methods in qualitative research.
Students have the ability and/or propensity  to:
  • Critically evaluate qualitative research in terms of methodological soundness;
  • Develop a qualitative research design;
  • Collect and analyze qualitative data;
  • Present qualitative research plans in a systematic and clear manner.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud
The course aims to acquaint students with key qualitative research methods, their application as well as conceptual underpinnings. Students learn what kind of research questions can be effectively addressed by qualitative methods. Participants of the course learn how the application of qualitative methods allows one to move from collecting information to its analysis. Course materials highlight that the application that qualitative methods spans not only across disciplinary boundaries but also across both empirical and interpretivist traditions in social and behavioural sciences. The course shows that qualitative methods adhere to the same ‘excellence criteria’ as quantitative approaches do, namely validity and reliability, as well as being able to provide a poignant critique of existing social order and practices. By focusing on contemporary societal and environmental challenges, students will learn how qualitative methods can be of help not only in identifying causes of these problems but also contribute to the development of their solutions. Throughout 7 lectures and 7 seminar sessions students will get acquainted with various forms of qualitative data collection, sampling and analysis, namely various forms of cases studies and process-tracing, interviews and focus groups, ethnography, discourse and qualitative content analysis, visual methods, fieldwork as well as the potential ethical challenges that the application  of these instruments entails. The lectures embed qualitative methods in various research traditions

as well as highlight strengths and weaknesses of particular approaches. The seminars will introduce students to the application of qualitative methods as well as acquaint them with examples of best practice in using distinct qualitative approaches.
 

Leerdoelen The goal of this course is to equip you with basic knowledge of the principles of the scientific method and the most important methodological concepts in the social and behavioral sciences. With this knowledge and hands-on practice, you will be able to evaluate research articles in terms of their methodological quality and design your own research. The course will give you insight into the current controversies surrounding the integrity of research in the social and behavioral sciences. It will also prepare you for subsequent courses on statistics and a capstone project where you will apply all this methodological and statistical knowledge and skills in performing your own research project.
 
You will gain knowledge of:
  • the scientific method, its principles, and criteria for evaluation
  • the most important types of research and research designs
  • measurement, measurement methods, and criteria for evaluation of measurement instruments
  • sampling and sampling techniques
  • ethics and integrity in science
 
You will gain experience in:
  • evaluating research articles in terms of their methodological quality
  • identifying solutions for methodological weaknesses found within (published) academic articles
  • establishing your own research question
  • proposing a research design for a given research question

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Why do people do what they do? People can have many different motives for doing things and
often construct their life worlds with others. Qualitative research is specifically suited to study the
meaning systems of the participants in social life. In this course you will take the approach of the
qualitative researcher. We will introduce you to the fundamentals of qualitative research and
different qualitative research methods. Like all skills courses, we use a hands-on approach: in teams
of 3-4 students you will think of a theoretically relevant research problem, write an interview
protocol and then go out to conduct interviews. For data analysis, you will learn about analytical
methods based on the Grounded Theory approach, start to code your own data using the software
program Atlas.ti, and identify and analyse patterns across the data. At the end of the course you
will outline your findings (your theory) in a research report and also present them to your fellow
students in our mini-conference. Leerdoelen At the end of the course, you will be able to:
  • Connect your research question to relevant theory
  • Discuss the appropriateness of different data collection methods for qualitative research questions
  • Design, conduct and analyze semi-structured interviews
  • Analyze semi-structured interviews using the software program Atlas.ti
  • Write your own research report

course_title: Qualitative research in Strategic Management & Strategic Entrepreneurship
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The challenges of qualitative research such as case studies are widely underestimated. While it is obvious that quantitative research cannot be conducted without mastering relevant statistical or mathematical techniques, many researchers engage in qualitative research without having the requisite knowledge and skills. This course seeks to endow prospective researchers with the insights needed to adequately perform one type of qualitative research: case studies.
It seems easy to collect and analyse cases, because information about business organisations is abundantly available and all students have a certain experience in interpreting and writing texts. However, a number of thorny issues render qualitative research a challenging task. First, how to know whether the focal research topic lends itself to the use of this type of research? Second, if qualitative research is indeed a suitable method, how to determine what data are most relevant and how to access those data? Third, once all data has been gathered, how to reduce the vast amount of data to manageable proportions and how to make sense of the data? Fourth, after the data analysis, how to report relevant findings in an insightful way? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting qualitative research (such as case studies).

Format
Five workshops. Four sessions deal with all critical aspects of qualitative studies: research design, data collection, data analysis, and data reporting. They comprise different formats, including lecturer explanations, group discussions, and hands-on training. In the fifth session, groups present the outcomes of their field research project.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • To create understanding when qualitative (especially case study) research methods are appropriate
  • To develop the ability to select and tap into different qualitative data sources
  • To develop the skills to systematically analyse qualitative data
  • To develop the skills to report findings from qualitative (especially case study) research in a structured and concise yet complete way

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. JJ Schuurmans', 'dr. MB de Graaff', 'dr. V Petit - Steeghs', 'IWH van de Voort', 'JFL van de Sande', 'KE Mujica Gastelbondo', 'MJC Aspria, MSc', 'NJ van Pijkeren, MSc', 'prof.dr. RA Bal']
text:
Inhoud Quality and safety are very much on the agenda of health care governance throughout the world. In this course we engage students to actively explore theoretical backgrounds to, as well as the major themes of, quality and safety governance. In general, the course takes the position that quality and safety in health care are emergent properties that need continuous work. Consequences of specific interventions to improve quality and safety are often unpredictable, hence we take the position that a straightforward ‘how to’ improve quality and safety is, at best, not very productive. Instead, we emphasize in this course the need for both ‘top-down’ and ‘bottom-up’ approaches to quality and safety, and place particular stress on theories of the 'middle' - the level where the work of management and leadership usually resides. The course explores six challenges that come from this 'mangle of the middle'. These challenges are said to face each quality and safety improvement effort, and can be structural, political, cultural, technological, emotional and educational.

Taking these challenges and their relations as a core theme, the course invites students to explore amongst themselves, and with their tutors, several recent cases of quality and safety improvement efforts. Guided by given concepts and theories, students formulate their own questions about and answers to these cases, and while doing so they can explore strategies and instruments that can be taken in dealing with each challenge. These include processes of mediation and quantification as well as instruments related to organizational cultures and leadership.

Language: Obligatory literature and lectures are in English. Workgroups are in Dutch, assignments and the exam can also be written in Dutch. Leerdoelen The goals of the course are to give students an understanding of the theoretical backgrounds to and challenges of quality and safety in healthcare settings, to train students in reflexively working with these theories and in exploring specific quality and safety issues from a multi-dimensional perspective. Using active participation in class focused on professional behavior, peer review and a written take home examination, we aim for this course to help students in developing a self-reflexive and concrete academic mode of argumentation.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Relevance
In many situations, making decisions solely based on intuition does not suffice. Especially in situations with uncertainty, following your intuition might lead to suboptimal decision making. A structured and systematic approach based on sound analysis of the relevant data can improve the quality of the decision making process. In addition, making decisions based on intuition makes it hard for managers to justify decisions in the future, especially when decisions turn out to have negative consequences. This course provides students with the methods and tools to make better, more responsible, decisions. The methods and tools are not only discussed conceptually during lectures and exercise sessions, but are also implemented using spreadsheet modelling software.

Topics
In this course, we cover three main topics related to quantitative decision making:

Decision analysis
In many managerial decision making situations, there is uncertainty about the future consequences of a decision which makes the decision making more complex. This uncertainty can, for example, come from unknown future demand for new products. This course provides tools to improve decision making by structuring decision problems using pay-off tables and decision trees.

Monte Carlo simulation
In complex business situations, multiple uncertain processes are interrelated and together determine the outcome of a decision. A common mistake is to ignore the uncertainty and consider the average value of an uncertain process as its true value. This is called the flaw of averages. Monte Carlo simulation is a strong alternative method to analyze systems with interrelated uncertain processes and better account for the uncertainty.

Integer linear programming
Optimization is the process of selecting the best solution with respect to a given objective function satisfying a set of constraints. Companies often face optimization problems when deciding upon the best allocation of their resources. One of the most broadly applicable optimization techniques is linear programming. We introduce the main concepts of linear programming and discuss how to find optimal solutions both conceptually as well as with the use of spreadsheet models.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals

Content related learning goals
After successful completion of this course, students are able to:
  • Explain the most important concepts related to decision making under uncertainty and risk
  • Explain the most important concepts related to Monte Carlo simulation to analyze complex business systems with uncertainty
  • Explain the most important concepts related to modelling basic business decision problems as (integer) linear programming problems
Skills related learning goals
After successful completion of this course, students are able to:
  • Implement and analyze decision models using payoff tables and decision trees conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
  • Implement and analyze a Monte Carlo simulation conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
  • Implement, solve and analyze (integer) linear programming problems conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
Belangrijk om te weten Course structure
This course consists of three modules. Each module consists of 1 or more lectures and associated exercises. Each lecture covers the material for 1 week and is divided into 4 recorded videos. In total, each lecture contains approximately 1 hour of video material. For each lecture, a set of exercises is available which can be divided into two categories: written exercises and computer exercises. In the written exercises you are asked to apply the material to small problems that can be solved on paper. In the computer exercises you are asked to implement the material in Excel so that larger problems can be solved.

The lectures will be made available on Monday morning. Each week, we will organize an online office hour during which students can ask questions related to the lecture or the exercises.

The course will be concluded with an exam that will consist of two parts: a computer part and a written part. In the computer part, we test the implementation of the models in Excel. This part determines 33.33% of the final grade. During the written part of the exam, we test solving smaller problems on paper. This part of the exam determines 66.67% of the final grade.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
