college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. B van Besouw', 'dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'dr. JC van der Vlies', 'dr. JJ Euwe', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. MF van Dijck', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'J Quak', 'J Siegel, MA']
text:
Inhoud
Quantitative skills are an important asset for historians. Data can be summarised in a clear manner using statistical techniques, empirical data can be accurately analysed using statistical programs and quantitative models can form the basis for testing theories. This course will deal with the collection, description and analysis of quantitative data. Many scientific articles are incomprehensible to researchers without a thorough knowledge of some basic statistical techniques. Moreover, the popular media also refer to quantitative data to provide insight into societal phenomena. Data and numbers are so important in contemporary society that academics should be able to cope critically with this kind of material.
 
Students will learn to interpret and perform statistical research in this course. This course mainly deals with descriptive statistics but some basic principles of interferential statistics will also be introduced. After a brief introduction about the collection and processing of quantitative data, different methods for summarising the data will be reviewed and practiced. Students will learn to create tables, draw graphs and calculate central tendencies and measures of dispersion. Index numbers, moving averages and trend lines are also covered in this course, as these are essential tools for understanding historical evolutions. During the second part of the course, students will discover how they can determine the relationship between two variables. Finally, they are also introduced to multiple regression analysis. These skills will be practiced in tutorials using SPSS. The assessment consists of a couple of assignments during the term and a final written examination in the PC labs.
 
Quantitative Historical methods is a mandatory course in the bachelor history at Erasmus University.

This course is in line with the specific profile of the history programme in Rotterdam with a strong emphasis on the connection with the social sciences. Most historians rely on qualitative methods, which are dominant in the humanities, but a social science approach urges historians to use quantitative methods. This course is programmed in the first term of the second year, because this enables students to make use of quantitative methods in their papers during the second and third year. Quantitative methods are for instance essential to understand historical analyses of economic developments, social inequality and international relations.
  Leerdoelen
This course has four main objectives:
  • Students can explain statistical terms and use these terms correctly in their own research.
  • Students can critically evaluate the use of statistical analyses in historical research.
  • Students can process historical data using SPSS and interpret the statistical analysis of these data.
  • Students can use the results of statistical analyses in research reports.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In this course we will learn some general principles about financial modeling in Excel. We will read through a selection of classical finance studies and will try to replicate these studies in Excel. The topics we will cover range from asset pricing and performance evaluation to bond markets and private equities. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After having followed this course students are able to build Excel models using best-practice modelling techniques, and using a wide range of Excel functionalities required for financial calculations and for presenting results, knowing which technique is appropriate for which purpose and knowing how apply each technique correctly.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['B Van Os, MSc', 'prof.dr. DJC van Dijk']
text:
Inhoud

This course provides an introduction to the field of Quantitative Finance by studying modern econometric techniques that are widely used in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management and derivatives pricing and hedging.
The course can be divided into three parts:

  • In the first part, we consider models for time-varying volatilities and correlations of asset returns, which are crucial inputs for quantitative risk management. We also consider concepts such as Value-at-Risk and Expected Shortfall of an asset or portfolio of assets. The most important techniques for computing and evaluating these risk measures are studied. Ample attention will be given to the practical implementation of these techniques.
  • In the second part of the course, we study factor models, which are commonly applied in asset pricing and portfolio management. For example, constructing a portfolio with optimal risk-return characteristics requires an estimate of the covariance matrix of asset returns. In practice the number of assets typically is large (100+), such that the number of unknown parameters becomes too large. Factor models then are an attractive way to reduce the dimensionality of the problem. Again, ample attention will be given to the practical implementation and use of these models.
  • In the third and final part, we provide an introduction to the most important derivative securities, including options, forwards and futures. Popular models for computing the fair price of these derivatives are discussed, while we also consider the use of derivatives for hedging risk involved in other assets.
Leerdoelen
  • To understand modern quantitative techniques that are widely used in various financial applications such as portfolio management, risk management and derivatives pricing and hedging.
  • To have a good overview of the field of Quantitative Finance.
  • To be able to apply econometric tools used in the empirical analysis of asset pricing models, and for portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing and hedging.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

The following quantitative models will be treated:

  • Facility location (single and two-echelon): both formulation, adaption and basic solution methods
  • Inventory management (single stocking point EOQ, POQ models, (s,S) models with normally distributed demand)
  • Warehouse design and operation (sizing warehouse and order picking routes)
  • Network design for multimodal systems and operational resilience
  • Long-haul (freight) transportation (network design)
  • Short-haul (freight) transportation (vehicle routing, TSP, arc routing)
Leerdoelen
  • To be able to understand, analyse and adapt quantative models.
  • To be able to apply quantitative models for: facility location; inventory control; warehousing; vehicle routing; transportation.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This year we will schedule the assignments such that they don’t interfere too much with lectures and other activities.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

This course surveys modern finance theory as well as econometric and time series techniques that are used for modeling and forecasting (the term structure of) interest rates.
Topics include:

  • Bond market concepts: bond prices, interest rates, yields, forward rates and the term structure of interest rates
  • Empirical features of the yield curve
  • Theories of the term structure (expectations hypothesis, asset pricing theory)
  • Models of the term structure (Nelson-Siegel, Vasicek, CIR, Affine) in discrete and continuous time
  • Yield curve forecasting
  • Interest rate derivatives
Leerdoelen
  • To gain a profound and state-of-the-art insight into quantitative methods in fixed income, both from a theoretical and empirical perspective.
  • After passing the course, students have a solid knowledge of different models for the dynamic behavior of the term structure of interest rates and other fixed income products.
  • Students are able to apply advanced econometric tools for modeling and forecasting interest rates. In particular, they are able to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specification testing, and forecasting.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar A new topic this year is zero lower-bound models. Interest rates around the world are (or have been) at or near (or even below!) zero. There is a recent class of models that incorporates this feature. We will spend time on this in lecture 8. 

Furthermore, the course will be in a blended learning format, with also activating elements during the lectures.

course_title: Quantitative Methods in Media and Communication
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['A Correia Semedo', 'BG Zerebecki, MSc', 'dr. A van Prooijen', 'dr. AM Diallo', 'dr. J Kneer', 'dr. JF Ferreira Goncalves', 'dr. K Riskos', 'dr. L Zheng', 'MC Eickhoff, MA', 'N Maru', 'TTV Nguyen, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
This course aims at getting students involved in quantitative research. Students learn how to formulate appropriate research questions and hypotheses, how to operationalize key constructs, and how to use an online data tool (i.e., Qualtrics) for collecting data. Furthermore, students will learn how to write the Methods and the Results section of a scientific publication which uses quantitative data. Finally, students gain the knowledge of different data analyses (i.e., factor analysis, reliability analysis, ANOVA and mediation analysis using regression) by using SPSS and learn how to interpret results. 

The course has a dual structure. First, students gain a thorough understanding of a variety of commonly used quantitative research methods. Second, students engage in practicing on specific methods in-depth and analyze data using statistical analysis.
 
Note
  • Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication.
  • Students should have completed the course Introduction to Statistical Analysis (CM1005) before they may enter Quantitative Methods in Media and Communication.
 
Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • How and when to use common quantitative research methods in the field of media and communication;
  • The benefits and restrictions of these methods;
  • How to develop a research design and how to choose the right data analyses.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Critically evaluate research reports on its methodological soundness;
  • Develop a research design;
  • Identify the right method for data analyses.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Data can be collected through a variety of methods: peering through a microscope, measuring brain activity, retrieving records from large databases, excavating ancient artifacts, etc.; the list is virtually endless. Often, the data collected are quantitative in nature. This course will provide you a solid foundation for making well-informed decisions from quantitative data and turn data into understanding, insight, and knowledge.
 
The skills you develop in this course include the collection, organisation, analysis, interpretation and presentation of quantitative data. Doing this by hand  is  often  slow,  tedious  and  error  prone. With the rise of information technology, powerful tools have been developed to support us conducting these activities. You will learn how to import and export data, explore and manipulate data (i.e. recoding, transforming, aggregating and combining datasets), and create data visualizations using freely available statistical programming tools. Furthermore, you will learn about basic statistical theory to draw valid inferences from your datasets.
Leerdoelen  After completion of this course you should master (i.e., know, understand and be able to explain) the following:
  • The major statistical indices used to describe variables and relations between variables;
  • The basics of probability theory;
  • How to draw statistically valid inferences about a population from samples;
  • How to use SPSS to process and analyze data, and make graphs.
Evidently, a single course cannot teach you all there is to know about statistics. In later years, depending on the major that you choose, more advanced courses on statistics (and research methods) will be offered.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

The course focuses on modern, quantitative methods for measuring risks faced by financial institutions. It covers:

  • Various risk measures and risk measure theory (Value-at-Risk, expected shortfall, coherency)
  • General method used for quantifying risks (analytical method, historical simulation, Monte Carlo)
  • Market risk and risk aggregation (dynamic volatility model, normal mixture distributions, Extreme Value Theory, copula)
  • Model validation and backtesting
  • Credit risk (Merton model, threshold model, Bernoulli mixture model)
  • Systemic risk
Leerdoelen
  • To understand the risk management process from the perspective of financial institutions as the process by which various risk exposures are identified, measured, and controlled.
  • To understand various quantitative techniques and econometric theories that are widely used in financial risk management. The course focuses on modern, quantitative methods to measure and manage the risks faced by financial institutions.
  • To be prepared for the role of a risk manager in financial markets and to have necessary skills for future research in risk management.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. JA Holland', 'HJ van de Lande, MSc', 'IMJ Laurent']
text:
Inhoud

In Quantitative Methods (organized in parallel with the practical SPSS)  you will develop your knowledge of and skills in quantitative, social-scientific research. The range of quantitative methods available to social scientists is vast—this course will teach you some of the basic tools to get you started.

In this block, you will learn how to use collected data to test your hypotheses and answer your research questions. Understanding statistics is not only useful for testing your own theories. It also allows you to understand and critically evaluate research that has been conducted by others and the mass of quantitative information in the world around you.

Leerdoelen By the end of the course 1.4C Quantitative Methods, you will be able to:
  • Explain the four levels of measurement
  • Calculate measures of central tendency
  • Explain how measures of central tendency describe a distribution
  • Calculate the variability/variance of values
  • Calculate z-scores
  • Calculate probabilities
  • Explain the differences between a sample and a population
  • Calculate and compare sample- and population characteristics
  • Calculate t-values
  • Formulate hypotheses to match research question, and which can be tested using statistical tests
  • Choose the correct analysis to test a research question: t-test, chi-square test, correlation, bivariate regression, multiple regression
  • Report statistical results
  • Explain the constructs of reliability and validity
  • Explain the use of scale variables
  • Use Cronbach’s alpha as an estimator of reliability
  • Interpret correlations between two continuous variables
  • Interpret the outcomes of bivariate and multiple linear regression analysis.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

course_title: Quantitative research in Strategic Management & Strategic Entrepreneurship
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In this course students will learn how to do empirical research. The course touches upon the fundamentals of research design and quantitative research, in addition to more advanced statistical tools. In addition to the lectures, a set of video tutorials provide deeper insights into the specifics of using statistical software and running various models therein. The course is attended jointly by students from two programmes: Strategic Entrepreneurship and Strategic Management.

This course seeks to provide students with the practical tools and theoretical vocabulary required to understand conduct, and critically evaluate quantitative empirical research. During the course, students are exposed to the key types of models, their assumptions, common data collection approaches, and statistical software needed to become a successful, independent researcher.

The following key questions are addressed in the course: First, what research design is the best fit with my research question? Second, how do I measure the concepts underpinning my research question? Third, what data do I need to collect to address this question, and what tools should I use to collect this data? Fourth, what statistical models are best suited to analyse these data? And, finally, how do I report the results of my analyses in a rigorous and statistically sound manner? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting quantitative research. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The course touches upon the following subjects and learning goals:
  • Understanding the key considerations in designing and implementing a quantitative empirical study.
  • Developing the skills to utilize the most appropriate statistical model and construct measurement.
  • Developing the vocabulary required to communicate research design choices and empirical results.
  • Developing the ability make an informed decision regarding different data approaches.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud The course deals with key concepts of rationality and choice:
- preferences and their interpretation, representation, and measurement,
- intertemporal decision-making,
- behavioural economics,
- game theory and its interpretation. Leerdoelen This course gives an advanced introduction to problems of rationality and choice. In doing so, we will encounter and analyse a number of foundational problems associated with both decision and game theory. After having completed this course, you will be able to:
(i) name, understand, and criticise key concepts in rational choice theory from a philosophical perspective and in terms of their role for the foundations of economic theory,
(ii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to decision theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,
(iii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to and uses of game theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,
(iv) critically evaluate and engage with philosophical and economic literature in rational choice theory and any literature in the humanities and social sciences that employs rational choice theory, in an independent way.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
text:
Inhoud If there is one problem that health care systems face and share, it is making the best use of the available resources in health care. Despite growing health care expenditures, there are never sufficient resources to meet all health care needs and demands. This means that health care somehow needs to be rationed. Baily (2003) defined rationing as follows:

“To limit the beneficial health care an individual receives by any means – price or non-price, direct or indirect, explicit or implicit.”

Hence, we somehow decide or organise that some care, that would benefit certain patients, is not provided (timely or freely). Although perhaps necessary and unavoidable, rationing (even the word itself) has been, is, and likely will remain a contentious topic in both politics and society.
This course focuses on this important topic mainly from an economic perspective, making use of behavioural economic insights. The topics that are discussed are rationing in general, demand and supply side rationing, and principles of rationing. Moreover, you will gain insight into how different countries ration health care. 
 
The course consists of 6 weeks of interactive lectures.

  Leerdoelen

To acquaint students with principles and practice of rationing health care from an economic perspective.

To provide a thorough understanding of supply side and demand side rationing and their advantages and disadvantages

To give insight in how different European countries deal with this difficult topic

college: Erasmus University College
Erasmus University College
Erasmus School of Philosophy
lecturers: ['dr. CB Binder', 'dr. E Dekker', 'dr. F Van De Putte', 'dr. HCK Heilmann', 'dr. N Vrousalis', 'dr. S Wintein', 'prof.dr. JJ Vromen', 'prof.dr. RE Backhouse']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

This subject explores the factors that shape contemporary Africa and its people, through the lens of multiple disciplines from the three participating institutions. The course objective is to gain a foundational understanding of significant factors that shape contemporary Africa, with the goal to establish a broad understanding of Africa’s past, present and future.

With time scheduled for discussions and debates, the seminars will foster a greater understanding of this extremely diverse and richly endowed continent. Students will receive further reading and references to online material to deepen their knowledge, and through creating a multimedia country profile they will showcase their ability to integrate different factors that shape an African country.

Leerdoelen

Upon successful completion students will have:

  1. Acquired a foundational understanding of:

  • Significant factors that shape societies and cultures in contemporary Africa;

  • Dynamic characteristics and diversity of African states and their people;

  • Africa’s role in a globalised world and the socio-economic and geo-political issues at play;

  • Methodological and ethical approaches to African studies.

  1. Developed skills and competencies to:

  • Critically search, structure and evaluate information about African states;

  • Consider relevant aspects in the analysis of complex questions;

  • Communicate own secondary research data through multimedia sources;

  • Reflect on how Africa’s past, present and future relates to own discipline.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Real Estate Economics covers the economic processes underlying our built environment. Based on insights from Urban Economics we look at markets for residential and commercial real estate. In this course we cover land use and land pricing, hedonic pricing, implicit prices of urban amenities, land negotiations, zoning, development, valuation and real estate as a specific class of assets.

Leerdoelen
  • Reproduce and interpret theories and views on the spatial-economic development of cities and the functioning of urban land and real estate markets.
  • Reproduce and interpret theories on real estate economics, dealing with investment decisions and real estate development.
  • Apply economic reasoning to analyse current issues in the development of urban areas on various spatial levels: from region to neighbourhood to dwelling.
  • Apply theories, concepts and research methods from contemporary literature to practical examples.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course has been updated with an up to date assignment. We strive to create a new assignment each year together with employers in the field. In addition, we update the required literature with new relevant papers.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In this course the focus is on financial topics related to Real estate investment and financing (corporate Real estate, commercial Real estate and residential). The course provides a theoretical framework to study these topics; ample empirical facts and actual practices of agents in Real estate and finance markets will show business relevancy.
 
This course prepares students to understand the risks and rewards associated with investing in and financing Real estate. There are three main topics:
  • Market analysis;
  • Real estate valuation, and most importantly,
  • Real estate finance.


Entry requirements or required background knowledge 
Students should have followed introductory courses in corporate finance (particularly discounted cash flow method) and investment before taking this course. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After having followed this course students should have
  • A thorough knowledge of the working of real estate capital and space markets;
  • The knowledge to identify and analyze different investment opportunities in these markets;
  • The skills and tools to apply the knowledge in practice.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. FL Stevens', 'JS Lebbink, LLM', 'mr. C Mannee', 'mr. HJ de Kloe', 'mr. I Cune - Noten', 'mr. LE Kooreman', 'mr. M de Mooij', 'mr. MN Kuijer', 'mr. O Oost', 'mr. RG van Hemert', 'mr. S Alatag', 'mr. SR Sripal', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'N van Toor, LLM', 'prof.dr. CA Schwarz', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr. N van Tiggele - van der Velde', 'prof.mr.dr. AR Houweling', 'prof.mr.dr. MA Verbrugh', 'prof.mr.dr. T Cohen Jehoram']
text:
Inhoud In het eerste deel van het vak, de eerste zeven weken, komt de basis van de rechtsgebieden Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht aan bod, alsmede de integratie van deze drie rechtsgebieden. In het tweede deel van het vak, opnieuw gedurende zeven weken, werken studenten in groepsverband aan een praktijkgericht dossier op het gebied van het Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht, waarover ze contact hebben met één van de aan Recht & Bedrijf verbonden bedrijven. Over de uitwerking van het dossier wordt een presentatie gegeven aan het bedrijf. In het dossier komen alle drie de rechtsgebieden aan bod en studenten schrijven drie adviezen, elk advies op één rechtsgebied. Ook reflecteren studenten op de onderlinge samenwerking.
In het laatste deel van het vak krijgen studenten de kans zich in één van de drie rechtsgebieden verder te verdiepen, door een individuele schrijfopdracht te maken. Dit deel duurt één week. Leerdoelen Het vak Recht en Bedrijf draait om de samenhang van de rechtsgebieden Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht. Het vak duurt in totaal 16 weken (blok 4, 5 en 6, inclusief een onderwijsvrije week) en bestaat uit drie delen. Het vak beslaat in totaal 21 EC.
Het doel van het vak is studenten behalve de hoofdlijnen van het Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht, en Ondernemingsrecht, ook te leren een maatschappelijk probleem vanuit de verschillende perspectieven van de drie rechtsgebieden te analyseren.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In dit vak wordt eerst ingegaan op de verschillende rechtsgebieden en rechtsbronnen. Dan wordt het Nederlandse staatsrecht behandeld. Daartoe worden enkele algemene thema's belicht, zoals het juridisch staats- en wetsbegrip en de leerstukken rond bevoegdheid (legaliteitsbeginsel, attributie-delegatie-mandaat).
Bij de behandeling van de Nederlandse Grondwet komen de functie van de staatsorganen en de grondrechten uitgebreid aan bod.
Bij het onderdeel bestuursrecht leert de student kennis maken met en begrip krijgen van de hoofdlijnen van het formele en materiële bestuursrecht en komt de toepassing van de Algemene wet bestuursrecht aan de orde.
Ook de verhouding tussen nationaal en internationaal recht en de plaats van Nederland in de communautaire rechtsorde van de EU worden aan de orde gesteld. Leerdoelen Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
  1. conflicten en vraagstukken een plaats geven in verschillende rechtsgebieden;
  2. de verschillende vormen van regelgeving in de nationale rechtsorde benoemen en kunnen aangeven welke organen bevoegd zijn om deze regelgeving tot stand te brengen
  3. staatsvormingsbeginselen als legaliteit, verantwoording, machtenscheiding en grondrechten aangeven;
  4. de juridische opbouw van Nederland als gedecentraliseerde eenheidsstaat, democratische rechtsstaat en het overheidsbestuur reproduceren;
  5. de (wijze van) samenstelling en de functies van parlement, regering en Raad van State benoemen;
  6. de normen voor bestuurlijk handelen, reguleren en handhaven aangeven en een schending van de algemene beginselen van behoorlijk bestuur herkennen;
  7. in een gegeven situatie de toepasselijke rechtsbeschermingsprocedures van bezwaar en beroep tegen bestuursorganen selecteren;
  8. beredeneren waar beginselen en (grond)rechten onderling kunnen botsen;
  9. aangeven op welke wijze internationaal publiekrecht doorwerkt in de Nederlandse rechtsorde en in verband brengen met de begrippen dualisme en monisme;
  10. de definities van publiekrechtelijke leerstukken en rechtsbeginselen herkennen;
  11. wetsartikelen en regels identificeren van publiekrechtelijke rechtsgebieden.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['EM Linthorst, LL.M', 'mr. CA Bol', 'mr. KGM Fleetwood Bird']
text:
Inhoud In deze Minor maakt u kennis met rechten van verschillende partijen in de gezondheidszorg. U wordt geconfronteerd met de theorie en praktijk van dit rechtsgebied en u zult ervaren dat praktijk en theorie niet steeds naadloos op elkaar aansluiten.
Een van de functies van het recht in onze samenleving is het voorkomen van conflicten en, als conflicten al bestaan, om deze op te lossen. Dit geldt ook voor het terrein van de gezondheidszorg, waar men soms van andere regels moet uitgaan dan in andere maatschappelijke sectoren gebruikelijk is. In deze Minor staat die specifieke wetgeving op het terrein van de gezondheidszorg centraal.
We hebben te maken met een sterke juridisering van de samenleving als geheel en van het terrein van de gezondheidszorg in het bijzonder. Medisch-technologische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen als de vergrijzing en fraude in de zorg, werpen niet alleen vragen en dilemma’s op rond medische, juridische, communicatieve en ethische zaken, maar ook op het gebied van de kostenbeheersing binnen de gezondheidszorg en de daarmee samenhangende toegang tot de zorg.
De Minor staat allereerst uitgebreid stil bij de rechtsbetrekkingen tussen de belangrijkste partijen in de gezondheidszorg: de burger als patiënt, de zorgaanbieder (dokter, ziekenhuis), de zorgfinancier (de verzekeraar) en de burger als verzekerde.
Aan bod komen onder meer de geneeskundige behandelingsovereenkomst, het beroepsgeheim, de rechten en plichten van patiënten, de rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaars, de aansprakelijkheid voor medische missers, het medisch tucht- en klachtrecht, medezeggenschap in de zorg, (good) governance, marktwerking, rol en taak van de overheid in de sector en het zorgverzekeringsrecht. Ook de uitdijende internationaalrechtelijke dimensie van gezondheidszorg komt aan bod. Het recht op gezondheidszorg is immers een mensenrecht en ook op dit terrein wint de Europese Unie aan invloed. Leerdoelen In deze Minor wordt u geprikkeld om op juridisch-medisch-ethische, sociaaleconomische en communicatieve vraagstukken te reflecteren en om op grond van de geldende regelgeving en heersende morele opvattingen hier beargumenteerd over te kunnen discussiëren. De vraag op de arbeidsmarkt naar gezondheidsrechtelijke expertise is momenteel groot. De Minor voorziet wat dat betreft in deze behoefte.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Waar mensen samenleven en goederen schaars zijn, ontstaan onvermijdelijk conflicten. Het recht biedt oplossingen voor deze conflicten. Rechten worden dus toegekend en plichten worden opgelegd omdat ze ergens toe dienen, omdat ze een functie vervullen. In R.E.M. wordt het recht bestudeerd vanuit de functie van het verlagen van kosten voor de samenleving als geheel.
De verschillende rechtsregels vormen samen een aaneensluitend geheel van oplossingen die ervoor zorgen dat verschillende soorten kosten voor de samenleving als geheel verminderd worden. Bij deze kosten kan gedacht worden aan bijvoorbeeld ongevalskosten, vervuilingskosten, overlast en hinder, schade doordat regels en afspraken niet worden nageleefd, kosten door criminaliteit et cetera. In het vak komen voorbeelden aan bod uit onder andere het privaatrecht (eigendom, contract, onrechtmatige daad), het strafrecht en het bestuursrecht. Ook worden fiscaal recht en internationaal en Europees recht aangestipt.
Bij het analyseren van de effecten van rechtsregels is, naast theoretisch onderzoek, empirisch onderzoek van belang. In R.E.M. worden enkele voorbeelden van zulk empirisch onderzoek kort besproken.
R.E.M. dus gaat over de maatschappelijke rol van het recht, waarbij de verschillende rechtsgebieden worden gezien als onderdelen van een samenhangend geheel, en waarbij niet alleen aandacht aan theoretisch maar ook aan empirisch onderzoek wordt besteed. Op deze manier beoogt het vak een ‘scharnier’ te vormen waarmee inzichtelijk wordt dat alle vakken uit het eerste bachelorjaar, alsmede uit de verdere rechtenstudie, met elkaar verbonden zijn.
  Leerdoelen Na dit blok kun je:
  1. Uitleggen dat het recht een functie in de samenleving vervult.
  2. Uitleggen hoe de rechtseconomie de functie van het recht in de samenleving invult.
  3. De ex ante en ex post benadering van het recht vergelijken en uitleggen welke benadering de rechtseconomie hanteert.
  4. Beargumenteren hoe efficiëntie en rechtvaardigheid samen kunnen gaan.
  5. Vanuit rechtseconomisch perspectief schetsen hoe verschillende rechtsgebieden één systeem vormen.
  6. Alternatieve juridische oplossingen voor een samenlevingsprobleem met elkaar vergelijken aan de hand van een prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse.
  7. Concrete voorbeelden uit wetgeving en rechtspraak beoordelen aan de hand van de prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr. C van Noortwijk', 'prof.dr. PTM Desmet', 'prof.mr.dr. F Weber', 'prof.mr.dr. LT Visscher']

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['MC van Gorkom', 'mr. TC van Schendel', 'prof.mr.dr.drs. WSR Stoter', 'R Kegge']
text:
Inhoud Dit vak beoogt een verdieping te geven van het onderdeel bestuursprocesrecht van het verplichte vak Bestuursrecht.

De verschillende procedures, te weten de bezwaarschriftprocedure, het beroep bij bestuursorganen en bij de bestuursrechter, de voorlopige voorziening en procedure en het hoger beroep zullen worden behandeld.

Er wordt ingegaan op de posities van de verschillende partijen die betrokken zijn bij een bestuursrechtelijk geschil, te weten de burger, het bestuursorgaan en de beoordelende instantie. Zowel de theorie als de praktijk van het bestuursprocesrecht komt aan de orde. Leerdoelen De doelstelling van het vak Rechtsbescherming tegen de overheid is het aanleren van een kritische houding ten opzichte van de theoretische achtergronden van het geldende bestuursprocesrecht.

Het verwerven van kennis van en inzicht in het geldende bestuursprocesrecht staan centraal. Met de verworven vaardigheden zijn studenten in staat een concrete casus te beoordelen op de procesrechtelijke consequenties en de daarbij behorende strategische keuzes.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['D Daineko', 'dr. EM Galenkamp', 'dr. MJ Luth - Morgan', 'dr.mr. CA Zweistra', 'EP Wesselius, MSc LLM', 'FG Kwekel, LL.M', 'mr. CDM van Hacht', 'mr. HJ Kok', 'mr. O Kirman', 'mr. WJ Schaap', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg']
text:
Inhoud Het overkoepelende thema van dit vak is ‘recht, staat en samenleving’. Onderwerpen die onder andere aan bod zullen komen zijn de belangrijkste ethische theorieën (utilisme, deontologie en deugdenethiek) en juridische beroepsethiek, grondrechten, democratie en rechtsstaat, maatschappelijk onrecht, de problematiek van multilevel legal orders en global legal pluralism, theorieën van het sociaal contract, theorieën van verdelende rechtvaardigheid, het debat over liberalisme, legal moralism en paternalisme,  strafrechtstheorieën en het debat over universalisme versus relativisme.

De relevantie van de vaak abstracte theorieën zal inzichtelijk worden gemaakt door middel van terugkoppeling naar actuele casus, onder meer in de hoorcolleges en in de actualiteitencolleges. Leerdoelen De algemene doelstelling van het vak valt in twee delen uiteen. Het eerste doel is om de studenten kennis en inzicht te laten verwerven in de normatieve grondslagen en de achtergronden van het recht en de vier grote rechtsgebieden: privaatrecht; staats- en bestuursrecht; strafrecht; internationaal en Europees recht. Het lezen van rechtsfilosofische teksten – moderne én klassieke – is een van de methoden hierbij.

Het tweede doel van het vak is om de studenten te trainen in de schriftelijke vaardigheid om filosofisch te reflecteren op het recht en een beargumenteerd eigen normatief standpunt in te nemen. In het onderwijs worden vaardigheden, kennis en inzicht zoveel mogelijk op elkaar betrokken.
De schrijfvaardighedentraining vindt plaats in de vorm van vaardighedencolleges en  zelfstudiemodules. Bovendien krijgen studenten tijdens de cursus een take-home schrijfopdracht waarin zij een rechtsfilosofisch advies moeten schrijven. Deze training biedt ook een goede voorbereiding op het tentamen. Dit bestaat in beide rondes uit twee essayvragen.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['D Daineko', 'dr. EM Galenkamp', 'dr. MJ Luth - Morgan', 'dr.mr. CA Zweistra', 'EP Wesselius, MSc LLM', 'FG Kwekel, LL.M', 'mr. CDM van Hacht', 'mr. HJ Kok', 'mr. O Kirman', 'mr. WJ Schaap', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg']

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud De rechter moet achterhalen of de verdachte schuldig is aan het tenlastegelegde feit. Dat doet hij door te bekijken of er in het dossier voldoende wettige bewijsmiddelen zitten die hem overtuigen van de schuld van de verdachte. In deze minor wordt ingegaan op wat er allemaal mis kan gaan bij dit proces. Ook wordt ingegaan op een alternatieve, rekenkundige manier van bewijsweging, de zogenoemde Bayesiaanse benadering. Bewijsmiddelen die aan bod komen zijn: getuigenverklaringen, herkenningen en bekentenissen. Verder wordt onder meer ingegaan op leugendetectie, verhoren en tunnelvisie.

Voor meer info zie minoren esl Leerdoelen Tijdens dit vak worden deelnemers bekend gemaakt met de volgende onderwerpen:
  • Diagnostische waarde.
  • Bayesiaanse analyse.
  • Tunnelvisie.
  • Waarneming en geheugen.
  • Getuigen- en verdachtenverhoren.
  • Leugendetectie.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This class examines recognition within the art world. As in most fields, recognition and renown can lead to various types of artistic success, from economic gain to critical acclaim. However, recognition in the arts is better understood as a social phenomenon, rather than exclusively the consequence of an artistic creator or artwork’s characteristics. Field conventions dictate what is created and "greatness" is evaluated according to the standards of time, place, and those professionals credentialed to offer their opinion. In this course, we will take such a sociological perspective in order to arrive at a better understanding of why certain creators are celebrated, while the majority of art and artists are largely unknown. We begin by thinking about what is recognition in the art world and what the different forms of recognition are. Next we discuss what factors contribute to differences in exposure and value. As this course is a research workshop, once we have discussed these questions, we will begin to empirically find answers. Students will conduct a small research project in which they examine recognition in the art world.
Note: It is highly recommended for entry into this course that students have completed the first year course on Methods.
 
Note: The maximum number of participants is 18.
  Leerdoelen There are several objectives for this course. First, students gain insight into the sociological examination of the art world and are able to decipher how artistic recognition is formed and what social factors contribute to valuation. Second, students are able to critically read, reflect upon, and synthesize research articles and, ultimately, use them in forming their own research design. Third, students are able to conduct a small research project on recognition in the art world and report on the final work both through written and oral description.

lecturers: ['A. Oudijn', 'dr. J.W. van Neck', 'dr. M.J. Koudstaal']

lecturers: ['dr. E.M. Bunnik', 'dr. F.M.S. de Vrij', 'dr. H.M.M. van Beusekom', 'dr. ing. B.C.J. van der Eerden', 'PhD R. Narcisi', 'prof. dr. L.J.W. van der Laan']

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. A Quintavalla', 'dr. EKE von Bone', 'dr. NS Efthymiou']
text:
Inhoud Staatsrecht en bestuursrecht zijn opgebouwd uit rechtsnormen en praktijken die betrekking hebben op verschillende elementen van de uitoefening van openbaar gezag door de overheid. De plaats van de Grondwet en de Algemene wet bestuursrecht verdient uiteraard centrale aandacht, maar daarnaast zijn ook de ongeschreven publiekrechtelijke rechtsnormen – vertrouwensregel, conventies, algemene beginselen van behoorlijk bestuur – van groot belang, en is er de rechtspraak van verschillende hoogste rechters die heeft bijgedragen aan de ontwikkeling van het publiekrecht.
Het vak Regeren en besturen zal studenten vertrouwd maken met de organisatie van de overheid en de instrumenten die zij kan hanteren. Vragen van verantwoordelijkheid en verantwoording (accountability), legaliteit, machtenscheiding, checks and balances, en evenwicht van machten, behoren tot de onderwerpen die in dit vak aan de orde (kunnen) komen. Leerdoelen Het vak Regeren en besturen is een staats- en bestuursrechtelijk integratievak. Het beoogt de studenten vertrouwd te maken met problemen die zowel in het staatsrecht als in het bestuursrecht aan de orde zijn. Daartoe zullen ook de historische ontwikkeling van het publiekrecht in Nederland, en de internationale en Europese context waarbinnen dat publiekrecht heden ten dage functioneert, aan de orde kunnen komen.
Het doel van het vak Regeren en besturen is om studenten te vertrouwd te maken met de organisatie van de overheid en de instrumenten die zij kan hanteren. Het verkrijgen van inzicht in vragen van verantwoordelijkheid en verantwoording (accountability), legaliteit, machtenscheiding, en het verkrijgen van de vaardigheid om onderzoek te doen naar - en deel te nemen aan een juridisch debat over – die vragen, behoren tot de leerdoelen van dit vak.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

We are moving from studying the economist inside the human being to studying the human being inside the economist.

This minor teaches the foundations of relational economics, an emerging field in economics in which relationships between human beings are of central interest. Relational economics explores interpersonal social connections. While traditional economics has generally viewed relationships as a way to reduce transaction costs in case of specific investments, recent scientific developments suggest to see the nature of relationships between humans from a more holistic perspective. Traditional economic tendencies (such as interpersonal cooperation and competition) and subjective ethical tendencies (such as altruistic reciprocity and intrinsic mutuality) are allowed to co-exist, with economists identifying how exactly humans create value through these complex interactive processes.

Among many other things, the minor demonstrates how today’s broadening of concepts like welfare and wellbeing are in agreement with early works on economics (as these were actually often highly relational in scope). As the course progresses, concepts that originate in psychology (in the case of values) and in organizational science (in the case of leadership) are introduced. The focus thus shifts gradually to the side of relational economics that specifically deals with theories on human values as well as theories on leadership.

As part of the applied economics department, the minor allows you to use relational economics as a viable lens to analyse and study governance, organizational behaviour and the psychology of human motivation. Through an interactive case method and project-oriented teaching style, you will acquire the basic analytical tools to relate to pressing contemporary issues of your choice.

Should you wish for additional information on the course, please contact the course coordinator with your questions by email.

Leerdoelen

General learning objectives:
• To know and be able to recall the discussed theoretical and empirical mechanisms that have been developed regarding the three concepts of values, leadership and relational economics.
• To understand theoretical frameworks for modelling relationships in economics and how to apply these to real-life topics and problems.
• To improve the academic skills of academic presenting, group work and assessment, writing and performing critical review and analysis and carrying out independent research projects.

Specific learning objectives:
• You know why economists are increasingly interested in values and relationships.   
• You understand that the trade-off between commitment and flexibility reflects a trade-off between cooperative relationships and competition.
• You know and are able to recall the evolutionary (socio-)biological and philosophical grounds of values in human beings and groups.
• You have a reasonable grasp of the social dynamics of interpersonal value priorities in various social contexts.
• You understand and are able to explain the benefits and drawbacks of i.a. behavioural, cognitive and microeconomic theory and methodology concerning the study of leadership phenomena.
• You can explain in what ways leadership behaviour can be used to establish, maintain and diminish personal and social commitment, form reciprocal relationships and promote cooperation and mutuality.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'M Meqdad, MA', 'prof.dr. D Douwes']
text:
Inhoud In this course we look at how religion is variously defined in relation to its content and performance as well as to the ways in which religion is organized and impacts on society. Believers rather than believes are central in our approach, religion being considered to be part of particular historical and cultural contexts and, often, wider global networks. In the lectures Christianity and Islam figure prominently, representing the two largest religious traditions on the globe, but due attention will be paid to other religious traditions and trends, including new religious movements, such as Wicca, but also counter movements such as Pastafarianism. For their assignments and final papers students select and define their own topic in one of following fields:
  • Religion and colonization (missionaries, colonial policies, local responses, postcolonial developments)
  • Religion, migration and citizenship (diaspora’s, transnational communities, debates and policies concerning (national) identities, including issues of gender)
  • Living religion (religion as lifestyle, rituals and beliefs ordering daily life and –possibly- the hereafter)
Leerdoelen

Students acquire knowledge of the various concepts and definitions of religion and of the changing nature of religion and religious organization and within a global perspective. They acquire the skills to analyze specific cases of social and cultural developments in modern history in which religion is or appears to be a key element as well as the skills to present their findings in a scholarly final paper.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)

course_title: Representation, the People and Contemporary Democracy
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
lecturers: ['dr. GH van Oenen', 'J van der Klaauw, MA']
text:
Inhoud

This course is part of cluster 1: Representation: Democracy, Science, and Culture. 

Ever since the concept of ‘we the people’ was born, with Rousseau and the American and French revolutions, there has been a search for how to represent this sovereign yet elusive entity, ‘the people’, the product of the abolition of fixed social categories like estates. Social relations have now become a matter of contestation and proclamation fueled by association and mobilization. Combined with processes of emancipation, and division of labour, this had led to ever shifting ideas and practices of who represents whom. Parliament, government, the magistrature, labor unions, new social movements, the media, populist politicans all claim to speak in name of the people and to somehow represent either some part, or all of the people.

Democracy, as it unfolds in thought and in practice, both enriches and complicates representation through its claim that ‘the people themselves’ are both willing and able to participate in processes of representation. In its radical form this implies that the people could, and should, represent themselves. As ‘natural’ or traditional representation has vanished, yet ‘the people’ can never be present, the place of power in democracy is ‘empty’, or structurally vacant, and the shaping of both the people and whomever represents them becomes a matter of symbolic practices, which temporarily assign roles and legitimize procedures.

In this course we look at manifestations, conceptualizations, and institutionalizations of the people in forms such as crowds, masses, parliaments, movements, and assemblies. We discuss phenomena like populism, anarchism, communism, and post-politics in their relation to more established forms and ideologies of politics and democracy. We will be reading and discussing authors such as Claude Lefort, Frank Ankersmit, Jodi Dean, Nadia Urbinati, Warren Breckman, Chantal Mouffe, Michel Foucault, and Judith Butler.

Leerdoelen - understanding the basic concepts around democracy and representation;
- understanding the relation of the basic concepts around democracy and representation in historical and cultural context;
- understanding how to apply the basic concepts around democracy and representation to societal issues and problems

course_title: Representing War in Popular Historical Culture
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud World War II until today is an important reference point in popular historical culture, both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Other large-scale conflicts, such as the First World War, the Cold War  and the recent wars in the Middle East, are as well appealing historical experiences with an impact on the collective memory. But the way wars are represented and collectively remembered is anything but immutable and unambiguous. The ways in which wars of the past were brought to the fore (usually outside of academia) during the 20th and 21st centuries for a variety of audiences are quite diverse: ranging from museum exhibitions to comics and novels, and from films and musicals to games and new media. In this course the focus is on the question in what kind of historical representations of war all these elements have resulted, and what meanings are assigned to it? What are the expectations of both producers and consumers regarding different ways of presenting this past, and which views exist on understanding and – in as far as possible - 'experiencing' past wars. The emphasis will be on war representations in the popular historical culture of the Western world with a special focus on the medium of comics


Note: The maximum number of participants is 25. Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to gain knowledge and understanding of the ways in which wars from the early 20th century to the beginning of the 21st century are represented and framed in popular historical culture. Students learn in what ways a diversity of media and other forms of historical presentation reflect memories and visions of various large-scale conflicts and how developments in these representations relate  to historical interpretations.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
text: Inhoud In this module you will perform a quantitative research project in groups of 3 students, within the topic of behavioural health economics. You can collect your own data by means of an experiment, a nudging study or a survey, or analyse an existing dataset. The results have to be reported in a research paper. Examples include the empirical implementation of the intervention you proposed as part of the assignment in ACUB, measuring health-related preferences in a survey (e.g. as a preparation for a nudge), or testing particular hypotheses related to health behaviour (e.g. concerning the presence of specific biases and heuristics) in a lab, online or field experiment.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
The research clinic prepares the student for writing the thesis proposal. The clinic will provide insights into types of research questions and their requirements. It will provide an overview of research strategies and the appropriateness of these related to various types of research questions. Furthermore, various forms of data collection and analysis techniques – related to the research strategy – are discussed. As students follow a ‘master in management’ students will learn how to discuss and think about the managerial relevance of their research question.

To properly discuss and learn about types of data collection and data analysis the research clinic is organized in various tracks running in parallel for different groups of students depending on their choice of a thesis topic and the exact research question. Students will participate in one of the following tracks:

  • Track for students who want to write their thesis in Finance
  • Track for students who want to conduct a quantitative analysis
  • Track for students who want to conduct a qualitative analysis

These tracks provide hands-on exercises to help students to collect their data adequately and conduct their analysis in the thesis autonomously. The thesis proposal is conditional for the thesis.

This course is worth 1 EC.

Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Being able to define a relevant research question in the current business context
  • Formulate a research plan
  • Provide a relevant and coherent overview of the most relevant literature
  • Understand the managerial importance of the research question

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Francesca Sotgiu (VU)


Course content:

During the course, students write a research proposal for possible PhD and/or grant applications. In this process, they start by fine-tuning their own curriculum and cover letter to highlight the potential
of the proposal. When writing their proposal, they focus on aspects that all committees and referees look at: the novelty of the idea, its relevance, impact and feasibility. Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:


- Identify the key elements of a successful cover letter and elevator pitch supporting their idea

- Explain the key elements of their proposal

- Address important questions pertaining to the novelty and relevance of their idea (“So
what?” & “Who cares?”)

- Identify ways to engage their audience during presentations.

Leerdoelen By the end of the course, students will be able to:
  • Identify relevant business problems
  • Understand how data science can be used to address these business problems.
  • Show an understanding of business that allows them to broadly read and understand the current scientific literature in business and management, and follow scientific debates across these sciences
  • Written proposal of a research project.

course_title: Research Clinic Strategic Entrepreneurship & Strategic Management
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The aim of this course is to offer the foundational considerations for starting your thesis project. Specifically, it focuses on a variety of topics around the first, theory-focused part of your thesis (rather than the empirical part)—including topic choice, research question formulation, framing, and hypothesis development. These topics will be addressed in a series of lectures, building on published work on doing research as well as the experiences and submissions of prior students.
In addition to these subjects, a key aim of the course is to provide students with practical insights with respect to writing academic work, including but not limited to: identifying relevant literature, the issue of plagiarism, writing style, referencing style, reading academic papers, organizing your notes, and using the TOP system.   Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The course touches upon the following subjects and learning goals:
  1. Identifying a research topic.
  2. Formulating a relevant and feasible problem definition and research question.
  3. Positioning this research question in the wider academic literature within your research topic.
  4. Articulating both academic and managerial contributions that the research, if successfully completed, is likely to add.
  5. Outlining a conceptual model to be developed in full in the thesis.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. RB Bouwman', 'dr. RFI Moody', 'F de Haan']
text:
Inhoud
In this course various aspects of the research design are discussed and applied in a research proposal that students develop for their master thesis that they will start in the 3th and 4th block.
In interactive sessions research designs, and research methods are introduced and discussed.
Leerdoelen After this course students are able to:
·         Describe the most important methodological considerations in choosing a certain research strategy and research methods.  
·         Choose a research strategy and research methods that fit with a certain research question; 
·         Draft a research design that is coherent in terms of its problem statement, research question, theory, and methods for data collection and –analysis.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. IF van Meerkerk', 'dr. NB Sakizlioglu Uitermark']
text:
Inhoud This course will focus on creating a research design for the master thesis. In this course the topics of the research question, the theoretical framework, conceptual design, operationalization and methods are discussed. For each topic a separate session (interactive lecture) is scheduled.

While the final master thesis will be written in the third and the fourth block students will also already have 2 sessions in this course with their supervisor.
  •  
Leerdoelen After this course students are able to:
  • Describe the most important methodological considerations in choosing a certain research strategy and research methods; 
  • Choose a research strategy and research methods that fit with a certain research question; 
  • Draft a research design that is coherent in terms of its problem statement, research question, theory, and methods for data collection and –analysis.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. AM Diallo', 'dr. I Awad Cherit', 'dr. SJ Opree', 'prof.dr. MNM Verboord']
text:
Inhoud Research design refers to a series of interrelated decisions about the kinds of questions that can be answered empirically (and ethically) and the theoretical and social justification for those questions. It also involves considerations on how data should be sampled, collected and analyzed, and on how (certain kinds of) inferences and conclusions can be drawn.

In this course, students strengthen their research design skills by scrutinizing successful research proposals and designing a research project (proposal) of their own. They formulate scientifically sound research questions, make and justify decisions about literature review, data collection and analysis, data management and research ethics. By presenting and discussing their work in class, they also engage in peer review processes, sharing and receiving suggestions for and from their peers. Seminar discussions pay special attention to the relationship between theory and research; alternative methodological approaches and styles/traditions of research within the social sciences, as well as the pros and cons of combining methods; personal involvement and/or bias; research ethics and data management. Practical constraints that affect research decisions are also considered.
 
The course is meant to advance and systematize previous knowledge and experience students already have in social scientific research in general. It prepares students for the more specialized methodological courses that follow. Leerdoelen Students have advanced knowledge and understanding of:
  • The different decisions involved in the design of empirical research in the fields of sociology of culture, media and the arts.
  • The epistemological, practical, and ethical implications of these different decisions.
Students have developed skills to:
  • Review qualitative, quantitative or mixed methods research designs in the sociology of culture, media and the arts.
  • Design a research project of their own.

college: Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS)
lecturers: ['arquitecto(a) JM Skinner, MD MSc', 'BG Calzada Olvera', 'dr. A Baliga', 'dr. A Los', 'dr. J Fransen', 'dr. NB Sakizlioglu Uitermark', 'dr. OM Brilhante', 'dr. P Nagler', 'dr. PHT Scholten', 'E Luo, MSc', 'F Vanelli', 'I Lionggo, MSc']
text:
Inhoud This course will develop an understanding of the basics of research design and writing a research proposal offer practical guidance for it by working with hands-on exercises. The course will focus on how various elements of a proper research design should be developed in social science research, including: 
  1. Problem statement, research objectives, research questions
  2. Literature review and conceptual framework,
  3. Operationalization
  4. Research strategy (survey, case study, desk research, quasi-experiment)
  1. Identification of appropriate data collection and analysis methods
  2. Important design considerations: validity, reliability, ethics

The Research Design course, UDAI & II and the Research Workshops (RWs) of the different master tracks are closely aligned with each other. Within those courses students learn and apply methodological skills that support them in completing their theses.
  Leerdoelen The course introduces the basics of social science research and offers a practical guide to developing the research design.
After completion of the course students will be able to:
  • Apply criteria to design a consistent problem statement, research objective and research question as building blocks for thesis proposal.
  • Explain how ethics are involved and can be addressed in social science research as well as reliability and validity.
  • Develop a systematic review of relevant academic literature and develop a conceptual framework that is linked to this review.
  • Draft a research design that is coherent in terms of its problem statement, research question, research strategy, theory, and methods for data collection and –analysis.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. A Bouabid', 'dr. A Naudé - Fourie', 'dr. J Hoevenaars', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'prof.dr. EF Stamhuis, LLM', 'prof.dr. K Heine', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'prof.dr. P Mascini', 'prof.dr. RHJM Staring', 'prof.dr.mr. T Wallinga', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg', 'prof.mr.dr. F Weber', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema', 'WC Puper']
text:
Leerdoelen Writing your research proposal

Part 1. Research question
You will learn what is necessary to move from a broad PhD topic to a researchable and relevant research question. After this module you can distinguish the academic relevance of your research from societal relevance.

Part 2. Theoretical framework and literature review
You will learn: what the importance of a good literature review is and what the building blocks for making it are. You will understand the role of a theoretical framework and the differences between different types of frameworks, most importantly theoretical (in an empirical setting) and normative (in a legaldoctrinal setting).

Part 3. Research method
You will understand the need to specify your overall methodology and the elements that determine the choice of specific methods (research question, approach, skills). Research Method seminars In this part of the course you will learn the basic principles of various research methods that are used in the research into legally relevant phenomena. During these seminars you will receive an explanation by several teachers about the specific method and how to apply it.

The following Research Method Seminars are offered in this course:
  1. Doctrinal Legal research
  2. Comparative law
  3. Legal philosophy
  4. Legal History
  5. Law & Economics
  6. Empirical legal research (a basic part and an in-depth part)
  7. Law & Ethnography
The aim of these modules is:
  1. To introduce PhD students to the different methods of legal research.
  2. To create awareness about the possibilities of these methods for their project.
  3. To highlight the risks connected with each method.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. F Violi', 'dr. J Hoevenaars', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema', 'WC Puper']
text:
Leerdoelen The Academic Writing Process

In this course we will focus on one of the most important parts of academic life: the writing process. All experienced writers know that writing a paper, a chapter or even a book is never a straight march from the idea to a finished product. While writing you will likely go through many drafts, go into blind alleys, and even make new discoveries that may lead you to rethink your entire project. In the end, a lot of what is in your early rafts will not even make it into the final version. One of the most important skills you will learn during your PhD is working your way through this process of drafting, reviewing, rewriting, receiving and incorporating feedback and refining your work. In this course we will go through this process together. We will not only focus on writing itself, but also on giving and receiving feedback. In this course we will focus on 3 general steps that will help all researchers in their struggle towards a well-written and convincing product:
  1. Strategy, how do you get started with writing and what should be included in your text.
  2. Inter-vision, how to read other peoples’ work and how to provide as well as receive feedback.
  3. Revising your work and incorporating any feedback.
First you will write an abstract in which you briefly introduce your research, second you will write a first version of your introductory chapter, and finally you will write the revised and final full version of your chapter.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: Ines Lindner (VU).
 
Course content:
Scholars and companies deal every day with large and big data. This course allows the students to put their knowledge to the test and apply it to different fields. They will analyze big data, identify possible solutions with the help of specialized second-year research master students or PhD students. The course offers an important meta-learning experience, conneting all the teachings preceding the course and thought simultaneously. While during the first year, they will focus on different business problems, second-year students will dedicate their attention to the assignments related to their specialization.
Leerdoelen After the end of this course, students will:
  1. Demonstrate prior methodological knowledge and a clear understanding of key business principles.
  2. Apply this theoretical and methodological knowledge and experience in group assignments.
  3. Identify relevant research questions
  4. Analyze and evaluate different methodological approaches and findings
  5. Have worked on a research project in a team with written and oral presentation

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. HC Dibbits', 'dr. I Gusc', 'dr. L Green', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. MF van Dijck', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. RJ Adriaansen', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'dr. Y van Hoef', 'prof.dr. CR Ribbens', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann', 'prof.dr. RD Futselaar']
text:
Inhoud During the Master’s program, students have the opportunity to explore a professional field of interest by means of a Research Internship. Arrangements have been made with around 15-20 national and international archives, museums, research institutes, educational organizations and business companies for research projects which students may select as the subject for their Master’s thesis. Please note that this is not a policy-related internship; it involves an academic research project. The final product may be a publication, an international workshop, website, object analysis or exhibition storyline. This research activity covers 18 working days (5 ECTS). Some internships are linked to the research of a master thesis.
All internships will be announced at the end of term-1 on BlackBoard; there is also an indication whether an internship is linked to a master thesis subject. The internships will also be presented at the Master Thesis Market.
 
Each student formulates a working plan after consultation with the faculty supervisor and the supervisor of the internship institution. Based on that working plan, an official Agreement Research Internship Master History of Society will be signed by: the student, the supervisor of the institution and the faculty supervisor. The research internship will be completed with a report, written by the student according to the guidelines of the master. The report contains also appendixes with important outcomes and products (written or images of the products). The whole report and internship will be assessed during a final interview with the supervisors. Based on this interview the supervisor of the institution will write a general assessment. The faculty supervisor will assess whether the student
has reached the aims of this internship; there is no grade. For an explanation see the documents on the websitehttp://www.eshcc.eur.nl/english/history/mahs/current/researchinternship/. Leerdoelen
  • Students can apply historical skills and knowledge in a professional organization
  • Students can explain how their historical knowledge and skills are transferable to different sectors of employment: business, culture, education, government, research
  • Students can reflect on their internship activities in an internship report

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['MH Kox, MA', 'MJ Davarci, LLM', 'mr.drs. IR Bluijs', 'SD Kruit, MSc']
text:
Inhoud In het vak Research Lab – de Basis (dat je gedurende het hele jaar volgt) van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit vak richt zich in vier modules op onderzoeksmethoden (bestaande uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses), (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden, het toepassen van rechtsregels en het schrijven van een juridisch betoog. Dit zijn allemaal vaardigheden die van pas komen in de dagelijkse werkpraktijk van de criminoloog. Leerdoelen Na afloop van dit vak is de student in staat om:
 
  1. op basisniveau kwantitatieve (beschrijvende en verklarende analyse) en kwalitatieve (interviewen) onderzoeksmethoden uit te voeren;
  2. op basis van wetenschappelijke bronnen en empirische gegevens gestructureerde wetenschappelijke teksten te schrijven;
  3. het interpreteren en toepassen van rechtsregels, het begrijpen van rechtelijke uitspraken en een juridisch betoog te schrijven.

lecturers: ['CE Weeda, MSc', 'dr. TFC Fischer', 'drs. CCF van Guldener', 'jonkvrouw TMA van Suchtelen, MSc', 'M Moussane, MSc', 'M van den Heuvel', 'MH Kox, MA', 'MJ Davarci, LLM', 'mr. JH Mantel, BSc', 'mr. LE Kooreman', 'mr. RF Shaikh Mohamedbux', 'mr.dr. H Weijers', 'mr.drs. IR Bluijs', 'mr.drs. JCA Tonino', 'S Nieuwland', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SR Matthijsse, MSc']

  2. op basis van wetenschappelijke bronnen en empirische gegevens gestructureerde wetenschappelijke teksten te schrijven;
  3. het interpreteren en toepassen van rechtsregels, het begrijpen van rechtelijke uitspraken en een juridisch betoog te schrijven.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['A Merz, MA', 'dr. F Coman Kund', 'dr. J Jansen, MSc', 'drs. VD van Santvoord', 'GJ Koops - Geuze, MSc', 'JM de Dood, MSc', 'M Moussane, MSc', 'MH Kox, MA', 'N Pouls, LL.M', 'prof.dr. FM Weerman', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SR Matthijsse, MSc']
text:
Inhoud In het vak Research Lab – de Toepassing (dat loopt van blok 3 t/m 6) van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit blok richt zich in vier modules op onderzoeksmethoden (bestaande uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses), juridische analyse en (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden. Deze gevorderde vaardigheden worden toegepast op een criminologisch relevant en blijvend actueel onderwerp: surveillance door de overheid. Dit zijn allemaal vaardigheden die van pas komen in de dagelijkse werkpraktijk van de criminoloog. De tijdens dit geschreven stukken en verzamelde data vormen de basis van het bacheloronderzoek, waarmee jullie de bachelor Criminologie afsluiten. Leerdoelen ​De student kan na het succesvol afronden van deze cursus:
 
  1. Literatuuronderzoek uitvoeren en een vraagstelling afbakenen over de mening over en beleving van surveillance door de overheid en hierover schriftelijk rapporteren.
  2. Wetenschappelijke kennis vergaren over de mening over en beleving van surveillance door de overheid aan de hand van het uitvoeren van kwantitatief en kwalitatief criminologisch onderzoek.
  3. Wetenschappelijke kennis vergaren over surveillance door de overheid en asiel en migratie aan de hand van juridisch onderzoek.
  4. Een pleitnotitie opstellen en pleiten voor rechters in een Moot court.

text:
Inhoud In het vak Research Lab – de Verdieping (dat je gedurende het hele jaar volgt) van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit blok richt zich in vijf modules op onderzoeksmethoden (bestaande uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses), (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden, argumenten opbouwen, mondelinge vaardigheden, observeren en het toepassen van strafrechtelijke kennis. Dit zijn allemaal vaardigheden die van pas komen in de dagelijkse werkpraktijk van de criminoloog. Leerdoelen ​De student kan na succesvol afronden van deze cursus:
 
  1. Op gevorderd niveau kwantitatieve (beschrijvende en verklarende analyse) en kwalitatieve (analyse van verschillende kwalitatieve bronnen) onderzoeksmethoden uitvoeren.
  2. Op basis van theorie, wetenschappelijke bronnen en empirische gegevens gestructureerde wetenschappelijke teksten schrijven.
  3. Argumenten logisch en overtuigend kunnen overbrengen in een mondeling betoog en schriftelijk paper.
  4. Criminologisch relevante fenomenen wetenschappelijk observeren.
  5. Juridische, meer specifiek strafrechtelijke, kennis toepassen op casuïstiek.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. I Awad Cherit', 'dr. JS Lee', 'dr. SJ Opree', 'PM Leendertse, MA', 'prof.dr. JC van Sterkenburg', 'prof.dr. MNM Verboord', 'prof.dr. MSSE Janssen', 'Z Hammana, MSc']
text:
Inhoud The course is devoted to practical and ethical issues related to the academic field of the social sciences. In these meetings, students will learn about several key aspects of this field, including aspects that are particularly relevant for PhD students and other junior researchers. Each meeting starts with an introduction/presentation  by a staff member, which is followed by an open and informal discussions between all participants. This format is explicitly meant to leave plenty of opportunities for students to raise relevant issues themselves. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • A variety of practical and ethical issues related to the academic field of the social sciences
Students are able to:
  • Make strategies for presenting at academic conferences and publishing in academic journals
  • Reflect on ethical issues in the academic field.
  • Give high-quality academic presentations.
  • Develop a career plan.
